Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of Russell Offices, ACT. The Russell Office complex is the administrative centre and headquarters of the Australian Defence Force. Most of the existing buildings were constructed during the 1950s and the 1960s and are not suitable for refurbishment to provide the modem office accommodation required by Defence. Under the proposed works eight of the older buildings will be demolished, four buildings will be refurnished and three new office buildings will be built. The complex is located at the third apex of the national triangle, and the proposed redevelopment includes roadworks that the National Capital Planning Authority sees as necessary to complete the triangle. The Public Works Committee, in its report tabled on 29 March 1995, concluded that there is a need for the project and recommended that it proceed, subject to the following recommendations. Firstly, the redevelopment should proceed, provided the agreed amendment of the national capital plan amendment No. 12 Russell does not require changes to the design and siting of roadworks and buildings. Secondly, if the agreed amendment to the national capital plan-that is, amendment No. 12 Russell-requires changes to the proposed redevelopment, these changes will need to be considered by the committee. Thirdly, the provision of space for a senior officers suite should be reallocated for more essential services. Fourthly, the Department of Defence should proceed with the study of the impact on the staff efficiency and productivity of open office space and other forms of office accommodation as a matter of urgency. Fifthly, further value management studies should be undertaken to reduce the cost of the project. The Department of Defence agrees to all of the above recommendations and will institute measures to conform and, where appropriate, report back to the Public Works Committee. A draft amendment to the national capital plan was prepared to create sites for the new buildings proposed. It was considered by the Joint Standing Committee on the National Capital and External Territories which reported to the parliament on 5 June 1995. The report recommends that the draft amendment be approved, subject to several recommendations. The Defence development is affected only by some of the recommendations, and Defence accepts those recommendations. It is estimated that construction for the project will commence in July of 1995 and be completed by the end of the year 2000. I would like to thank the members of the committee for their support and to commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Approval of Work

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of a multi-level car park for the Federal Airports Corporation at Melboume Airport. Melbourne airport, the second busiest airport in Australia, is subject to continuing growth and passenger movements. As a consequence, the present short-term car park is suffering severe congestion and frequent closure. As this growth in passenger numbers is forecast to continue for the foreseeable future, it is necessary for the corporation, in order to provide an appropriate level of service to its customers, to increase the capacity of the short-term car park. The Public Works Committee tabled its report on 1 June 1995 recommending the project at an estimated cost of $55 million. In its report, the committee raised a number of issues to which the FAC has provided the  as part of its contract with the project manager for design and construction for a thorough re-evaluation of the concept design for the car park which was considered by the Public Works Committee. The re-evaluation will involve a review of a range of considerations, jncluding the location, size and performance requirements for the links between the car park and the terminal-in particular, the width of these links, which is directly related to the considerexpectations. ation of the provision of the moving walkways within them; the location of the hotel car park and future rail station locations and the interrelationships between them to ensure the final site selections represent the best planning outcome for the airport; and a design development process which includes close consultation with the airlines on all design issues, including the location and functionality of the proposed loading dock and associated service tunnel connecting the loading dock to the terminal. The pAc will also consult with the Melbourne metropolitan fire brigades on the design of the car park and, should they a-ise, refer matters which depart from the Building Code of Australia to the Building Appeals Board for dispensation. If approved, construction of the first stage of the project is expected to commence in September 1995 with completion by April 1996. A second stage will then be commenced with final completion expected in mid-1997. I would like to thank the committee for its report. I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Public Works Committee Refer-nce

Speaker: Mr WALKER
Title: COMMITTEES
text: I move: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed works be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Provision of living-in accommodation at HMAS Harman, ACT. The aim of the proposal is to provide an increase in the current living-in accommodation on the base from 232 personnel to a total of 428 and to replace the existing, unsuitable and substandard accommodation for 54. This equates to a total provision of living-in accommodation for approximately 85 per cent of those entitled to live in. The 15 per cent reduction is to take account of the estimated number of those entitled to live in who will choose to live out at their own expense. The proposed accommodation will provide a level of amenity consistent with community This increase in the live-in accommodation will require a corresponding increase in messing facilities and car parking and a new gymnasium to replace current substandard facilities that are beyond their economic life and unsuitable for extension to meet the additional demand. The project will be undertaken at an estimated out turn cost of $18.3 million. It is estimated that the costs of providing the proposed living-in accommodation will be recouped in less than 10 years through savings in allowances paid to navy personnel presently unable to be accommodated atHarman. It is anticipated that construction will start in January 1996 and continue until late 1997. I commend the motion to the House. Question resolved in the affirmative. Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes measures announced by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in the superannuation policy statement of 28 June 1994. In that statement, the Treasurer outlined several major initiatives to enhance the government's retirement incomes policy and to alleviate the small amounts problem. Some of the measures in the bill, such as the employee share scheme provisions, are new and largely self-contained. These have been drafted in the new tax law improvement style. Other measures in the bill either amend existing provisions of the law or interrelate with concepts already contained in other parts of the law; for example, the late lodgement penalty and interest provisions. For these reasons, it has not been possible to fully the new drafting style as this would entail changes to a much broader range of provisions. The tax law improvement project will be redrafting the tax law over the next three years. Employee share schemes The bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide a new income tax regime for the taxation of employee share schemes. The new regime will generally apply from 6 p.m. in the ACT-and the equivalent time elsewhere-on 28 March 1995. Transitional arrangements will apply so that, in certain circumstances, the existing provisions of the income tax law will continue to apply to shares or rights to shares acquired after the tax law. date of commencement of the amendments. The government is making these changes to reduce the exploitation of the existing legislashare tion and to ensure that the tax concessions that are available under the new arrangements are directed at share schemes which encourage employees to own shares in the company in which they are employed or a holding company of the employer. The measures will increase the taxation benefits available to employees under these schemes; The amount to be included in a taxpayer's assessable income in respect of the shares and rights acquired will be the difference between the value of the share or right and any amount paid by the taxpayer to acquire the share or right. Generally, the amount is to be included in assessable income in the year that the share or right is acquired. However, in certain circumstances, a deferral of taxation of up to five years without any upper limit on amount will be available. Conditions have to be satisfied before a share or right qualifies for the deferral concession. The share or right must be acquired under an employee share scheme. At the time the share or right is acquired, or at an earlier time, each permanent employee should have been entitled to acquire shares or rights of the employer or holding company of the employer. The shares or rights should be ordinary shares or rights of the employer· or holding company. The employee should also not hold more than five per cent of shares or voting rights of the adopt employer company or holding company. An exemption concession will apply for certain shares or rights that are issued to employees under a scheme operated on a nondiscriminatory basis. The employee can elect that the discount received be included in his or her assessable income in the income year in which the shares or rights are acquired. Where this electiori is made, benefits up to a limit of $500 for an income year will be exempt from tax. If the exemption concession applies, the provider of the benefit will be entitled to a tax deduction for up to $500 of benefits provided to each employee. This deduction will apply if the deduction is not allowable under the other provisions of the The bill will also amend the capital gains provisions and the fringe benefits tax law to ensure that there is no double taxation of or right benefits. The nature of these measures is such that a reliable estimate of the revenue impact cannot be provided. Capital gains tax-rollover relief for merging superannuation funds The bill will amend the capital gains tax, CGT, provisions to allow certain superannuation funds which merge to defer any CGT gains or losses that would be realised at the time of the merger on the assets transferred. Although the government remains of the view that CGT should, in general, be payable on assets realised when entities merge, it considers that special circumstances exist that justify this concession. For example, the government recognises that the new member protection rules may put greater pressure on supera,nnuation funds to merge to improve their economies of operation. It also realises that current CGT rules may affect the short-term liquidity of such superannuation funds. This temporary relief will improve the efficiency and performance of the industry. The amendments will apply to superannuation funds that merge on or after 1 July 1994 and before 1 July 1997. The notional cost to the revenue from the proposal is estimated to be $50 million for each of the three years of its operation. The actual cost to the revenue will be less because many funds would not merge if rollover relief was not available. Superannuation guarantee-jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission The bill clarifies the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, AIRC. It is generally accepted that the operation of the superannuation guarantee legislation has not affected the jurisdiction, powers or functions of the AIRC. However, there is no express statement in the superannuation guarantee legislation or the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to this effect. For this reason, and because there has been doubt expressed in some quarters concerning the power of the AIRC to continue to arbitrate on superannuation, the amendment makes it clear that the superannuation'. lation does not alter in any way the substantive jurisdiction, functions and powers of the AIRC. The amendment will apply from the commencement of the superannuation guarantee law on 1 July 1992. The amendment has no impact on the revenue. Superannuation guarantee-flat dollar contributions The bill also amends'the superannuation guarantee law to ensure that the percentage level of superannuation support actually provided for an employee for flat dollar contributions is calculated based on actual contributions, rather than the amount specified in the award. The current provision causes problems where contributions differ from the award amount. The effect of the amendment will be to make it easier for some employers to satisfy their superannuation guarantee requirements. The amendments will take effect from 1 July 1994. There is no cost to the revenue from the change. Superannuation guarantee-local government councillors The bill proposes to generally exempt from the superannuation guarantee law the payments received by local government councillors in the course of their duties. The paymerits will not be regarded as salary and wages for superannuation guarantee purposes, enabling councillors to claim deductions under the income tax legislation for any personal superannuation contributions. The exemption will not apply to payments from certain local government bodies. Local government councillors will retain their status as employees for the purposes of the superannuation industry supervisory legislation to prevent some funds which have councillors as members from being treated as public offer funds, which entails higher compliance costs. The amendments will apply from 1 July 1993. Cost to the revenue in the 1994-95 and subsequent years will be less than $500,000 per annum. Superannuation-various amendments to guarantee legisthe income tax law Following the Security in Retirement statement of 30 June 1992, the government has introduced a number of changes to the income tax law to encourage superannuation pensions and annuities, and to ensure that superaimuation moneys are kept within the superannuation system until withdrawal. This bill makes some minor adjustments to some of these changes to clarify their operation and further ease administrative requirements. In addition, the bill changes the income tax law to ensure that superannuation pension and rollover annuity recipients who started receiving a pension or annuity before 1 July 1994 will be able to change providers without losing tax concessions. This change will allow pensioners and annuitants to move their investment without being disadvantaged by a different tax treatment. The bill also amends the income tax law to ensure that tax concessions for employer superannuation contributions are restricted to superannuation funds established primarily for the benefit of employees. The amendments are not expected to have any significant impact on the revenue. Superannuation-miscellaneous amendments The bill also makes a small number of miscellaneous amendments to superannuation law administered by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The two main amendments allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to undertake statistical surveys of the superannuation industry and change the method of collection of the superannuation supervisory levy. As a result, the manner in which the late payment penalty for the levy is calculated is also changed. The bill also makes some other more technical amendments. No overall impact on revenue is expected to result from these amendments. State and territory bodies Amendments in the bill will create broad new exemptions "from income tax and sales tax for certain state and territory bodies. These amendments arise from an agreement reached at the 1994 Premiers Conference, which aims to promote efficiency and competitive neutrality in markets in which state and territory trading enterprises operate. One aspect of this is removing the tax advantage enjoyed by state and territory trading enterprises over private businesses. It was agreed that the tax advantage could be eliminated if the states and territories imposed tax equivalent regimes on their trading enterprises. A tax equivalent regime is basically equivalent to Commonwealth income tax and sales tax in its principles and the rates imposed. Before tax equivalent regimes are introduced, the states and territories need to be certain that their trading enterprises will be exempt from Commonwealth income tax and sales tax. Certain state and territory bodies will, therefore, be made clearly exempt. Some bodies will be specifically excluded from the exemption, including bodies prescribed by regulations. These amendments will not change the tax status of many of these bodies. For the 199495 year, the bodies which were taxable at the time of the 1994 Premiers Conference will remain taxable. These bcidies will in most cases become exempt from 1 July 1995. The amendments are expected to be revenue neutral. Late lodgement penalty The bill introduces a new penalty regime for late lodgement of income tax returns. The. penalties will apply to 1994-95 and later year returns where the due date for lodgement occurs after the later of 30 June 1995 or 60 days after the date of royal assent of the bill. Companies, superannuation funds and certain trusts will be liable for a flat rate penalty of $25 for each week that a return remains outstanding up to a maximum of $500. All other taxpayers who are late in lodging an income tax return will be liable for additional tax of eight per cent per annum on the amount of net tax payable for the year of income. In addition, they will also be liable for interest on the net tax payable at the same rate that applies to underpayments and late payments of income tax. That interest rate is currently 10.8 per cent per annum. The additional tax and interest will be calculated from the due date for lodgement until the return is lodged. A reliable estimate of the impact on the revenue cannot be provided. Refunds of tax file number amounts deducted in error The bill will also amend the income tax law in a number of respects to ease compliance costs encountered by investment bodies when they are required to refund tax incorrectly deducted by them because of a mistake concerning an investor's tax file number. One amendment limits the refunds to be made by investment bodies to requests for refunds received on or before 15 July following the year of income in which the incorrect deduction of tax file number amounts occurred. This will reduce investment body tax compliance costs associated with refunds that they are presently required to make in respect of amounts deducted in earlier years. Any incorrectly deducted amounts not refunded by the investment body within the 15 July time frame would normally be allowed as a credit to the investor upon assessment of the investor's tax return for the relevant income year. However, where it is not reasonably appropriate for an investor to wait until an assessment has been issued, the Commissioner of Taxation will be required to make refunds directly to an investor. This will ensure that an avenue for a refund is always available to an investor. A further amendment will provide for investment bodies to choose to offset any amounts that they refund against other amounts they deduct during the same year. This will also reduce compliance costs for investment bodies. These amendments will have no impact on the revenue. Pensions, allowances and benefits When the mature age partner allowance was introduced, it was exempted from income tax. This is inconsistent with the treatment of the mature age allowance which is taxable. The bill ensures that, as from 1 July 1995, the mature age partner allowance will be taxable. Recipients of the allowance will generally be eligible for the pensioner rebate, which will offset the tax on the allowance subject to any other income received. The financial impact of this measure is a negligible gain to the revenue. The bill also makes a number of minor technical amendments of tax provisions related to social welfare matters which have no impact on the revenue. Sales tax-new credit ground for unregistered exemption users Under the existing sales tax law, an assessable dealing is taxable unless an exemption applies. An exemption applies when a quotation is made or the goods in question are always exempt goods. The law requires that a quote for a dealing be made at or before the time of the dealing for it to be effective. If a person does not quote for a taxable dealing, then the dealing is taxable. A credit ground currently exists to enable a registered person to obtain a credit of tax paid on a dealing for which they had borne tax even though they were entitled to quote a registration number. The bill proposes to insert a similar credit ground to enable unregistered persons to obtain a credit of tax paid on a dealing for which they had borne tax even though they were entitled to quote an exemption declaration. The effect of this amendment on the revenue will be negligible. Sales tax-exemption for UHF transmitters The bill proposes a limited extension to the operation of an earlier exemption from sales tax for certain UHF transmitters for use in commercial television broadcasting to cover the period 1 January 1994 to 31 December 1995. The new exemption will apply to transmitters for use in connection with the equalisation program which aims to provide services in regional areas comparable to those in capital cities. The government considers that the extension is appropriate because the equalisation program is not yet completed in Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia, and it would be inequitable to deny licensees in those states the benefit of the incentive which had been available to eastern mainland licensees. The total cost to the revenue for the period of the exemption is likely to be about $2 million. Minor amendments The bill also makes a number of minor technical amendments which have no impact on the revenue. I also foreshadow that the government will be moving amendments in the House to the provisions relating to employee share schemes and state and territory bodies. Copies of the amendments and supplementary explanatory memorandum have been circulated to members. Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr COSTELLO
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) is an omnibus tax bill dealing with tax exemptions for state and territory bodies, employee share acquisition schemes, refunds of tax file number amounts deducted in error, pensions, allowances and benefits, superannuation measures, late lodgement penalties and sales tax. The most substantive changes in this bill are contained in schedule 2, which deals with the tax treatment of employee share acquisition schemes. This is the government's third attempt in 13 months to change the tax rules on employee share acquisition schemes. The approach taken by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and his office on this matter could only be described as bloody-minded and intransigent. It has been part of a continuing pattern to restrict and marginalise employee share acquisition schemes. In commending the bill to the House, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said in relation to these measures: 'The nature of these measures is such that a reliable esiimate of the revenue impact cannot be provided.' The government cannot say it is doing this to raise revenue or, if it is defeated, that it will revenue. The government says itself that it cannot give any estimate of the revenue impact. Probably closer to the truth is the fact that the government cannot estimate the revenue implications because this is not so much designed at revenue; it is designed to have the effect of restricting or wiping out employee share acquisition schemes. If that be its effect, there would be no revenue implications as a result. When it was clear to everybody that the Treasurer's plan to bring employee share ownership plans into the net of fringe benefits was atrocious and would effectively destroy the operation of all existing schemes, the Treasurer carried on regardless, not listening to anyone, steadfastly ignoring industry concerns, and seeking to push ahead with his plan, under cover and with all sorts of outlandish claims. The Treasurer and his office even ignored warnings and advice coming from their own department. In a particularly poor display, the Treasurer .lashed out at his critics as supporters of tax avoidance. That has never been the case. If there is any rorting going on under the current system I make it clear, and those companies which support our stand on this matter make it clear, that it should be identified and such amendments undertaken as would prevent it. The Treasurer was finally forced to concede at the end of March this year that his plan to impose fringe benefits tax on employee share acquisition schemes was ill-conceived and ill considered. He was forced into a humiliating backdown. He had to admit that he was wrong, that the charges that he had levelled against his critics were wrong, that they were right, and that his charges had been nothing more than an attempt to cover up a major policy bungle. So has he got it right the third time with the proposals that have been brought back to this House for debate today? The answer is a resounding no. Wrong the first time, wrong the second time, wrong the third time. Three strikes and you are out. We the coalition will vote against that part of the bill. The government could have amended section 26AAC, taking out the flaws, but it cost has chosen to introduce a new regime with onerous features designed, one can only surmise, to make employee share acquisition schemes less attractive and less available to the Australian work force. The government's legislation threatens the viability of current schemes and restricts the potential for further expansion of employee share ownership in Australia. Last year we had the quite amazing spectacle of the Treasurer asserting a massive conspiracy and growth industry of evasion in respect of employee share ownership plans. That, he said, was the rationale behind the FBT plan. But when it came to the cold hard facts the government has unable to produce any evidence to substantiate these charges. The Treasurer failed to identify the alleged problem which he was trying to counter. I give this undertaking to the government: the coalition will support any amendments to current section 26AAC to prevent any rorting that can be identified; however, we will oppose the implementation of provisions covering employee share ownership plans as contained in this bill. We will vote against them. We call on Independents and fair minded parties in the Senate not just to support us but to support those companies that have taken the step to distribute shares to employees and, even more importantly, to support those employees who have taken up shares in companies that they work for and that they want to invest in not only with their time and their labour but also with their financial security. We recognise that existing provisions in section 26AAC could be improved, but this legislation goes way beyond addressing any flaws. By acting to retain the existing law, the coalition will secure the existence of plans currently in force. In government we will iron out the flaws but we will iron them out in the context of expanding employee share ownership in this country-not in the niggardly way of the Treasurer of trying to restrict it. The Treasurer has merely replaced his FBT mess with an income tax disaster. There may be no FBT but the government seeks to impose a complex set of income tax rules. The bill seeks to replace one section in the Income Tax Assessment Act with 40 new sections. The coalition will once again stand up and defend employee share ownership schemes, which are under attack by this Labor government, and assist and encourage the hundreds of thousands of employees who want a stake in corporate Australia. The qualifying conditions for obtaining the tax discount under this proposal are far too tight. They mean that many plans would have to be substantially modified to take advantage of them. Overseas and international share plans cannot be quickly modified to meet Australian requirements when they are operating on an international basis. It is far more likely that they will be modified to exclude Australian employees rather than amended to include them and have an effect on employees in each and every other country in which they operate. The tax treatment of share options is still a complete disaster. The taxing of options is inequitable and harsh. It taxes a potential gain that may never be realised. This is contrary to the general principle that income is taxable only on realisation. No allowance or concession is provided for employees participating in schemes operated by foreign parent .companies, where options may be issued with a maximum exercise period of 10 years. Employees in Australia would be forced to pay tax either up-front or five years after acquisition. The five-year minimum deferral period will result in virtually all international share option plans attracting tax before the employee acquires a share, leaving employees with a tax liability to be met most probably by selling options in that case for the benefit of paying the tax accrued. The Treasurer's flawed proposal will discourage employers, especially international companies, from offering employee share plans to their Australian employees. In a joint submission to the Treasurer the American Chamber of Commerce, the Business Council of Australia, the Corporate Tax Association, the Taxation Institute of Australia, the Institute of Chartered Accountants and the Australian Society of CPAs said, if this proposal were enacted in its current form, they expected many international companies would cease offering participation in their share plans to Australian employees. This legislation contains a very limited right to refund of tax paid on acquiring rights. It provides no entitlement to a refund of tax paid where the option lapses owing to a variety of circumstances, including the non-fulfilment of performance in length of service conditions or where the option is not exercised because the market value of the share has fallen below the option exercise price. The valuation rules contained in the legis lationare complex and unrealistic. The valuation of options is yet another minefield contained in this legislation. It is quite unreasonable to ignore restrictions in conditions when valuing options. In government, the coalition will address such flaws as exist in the current scheme and introduce a new scheme designed not to discourage but to encourage wider employee share ownership. We will seek to promote and enhance the growth of employee share ownership plans and let them flourish right across the work force. These schemes have an important part to play in lifting workplace productivity and raising international competitiveness. The coalition wants employees to have the opportunity to take a stake in the businesses which employ them. We want to see as many employees as possible owning shares through employee share schemes. Through these schemes we can promote greater industrial harmony. This is one vehicle which can be used to break down the barriers between management and employees, to break down the division which has been created through a complex and legalistic industrial relations system. It is this Labor government which stands in the way of a new enterprise culture and consensus emerging within the Australian work force through the widespread promotion of employee share ownership schemes The level of private share ownership in Australia is still far too low. Although the level has risen in recent years, it is still below that of the United States and the United Kingdom. Promotion of employee share ownership has a critical role to play in raising Australia's scarce level of national savings. The coalition will increase participation in employee share schemes by opening up access to the discount available to employees in such plans by giving them fair treatment and allowing them to qualify. We plan to expand employee share ownership as part of our policy on national savings. As I said before, this matter has been on the books now for 13 months. This is the third strike, the third failure, that has come from this government. But corporate Australia, those that already offer employee share plans, those that already have employees joining together in their companies with common stakes in its financial productivity and its financial success, has been watching this very carefully. I have received a myriad of letters over the last couple of days from companies protesting this government's stand and supporting the coalition in its efforts to promote employee share ownership. A letter from Cadbury Schweppes stated: "The Coalition's decision to oppose the proposed amendments is wholeheartedly welcomed by this company ... It is our view that employees will participate in share plans because they believe they will increase their wealth ... We applaud the Coalition's opposition to this Bill." The Lend Lease Corporation stated in a letter: As major practitioners of employee share ownership in Australia we support the position outlined in your Press Release of 20 June 1995. It is referring to my press release. Ernst and Young went on to state: On behalf of the following organisations: - The American Chamber of Commerce in Australia - The Business Council of Australia - The Taxation Institute of Australia - The Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia - The Australian Society of CPA's - Ernst and Young I confirm the support of those organisations for the Coalition position that Section 26AAC should be reinstated subject to the introduction of appropriate safeguards to protect the revenue. The letter sent from Coles Myer stated: ... the position of Coles Myer Ltd. is that it has a clear preference for the retention of the present Section 26AAC over the proposals contained in the Government's current draft bill. Finally, BHP stated in a letter: BHP is only too happy to see any of the supposed tax avoidance schemes addressed through existing or new legislation, but agrees completely with you that the present proposal has consequences far beyond this objective. Thank you for your support. These are all companies that are currently operating employee share schemes and this is legislation which threatens the viability of such schemes. It is not just the companies. The government should not sit there and think to itself, 'This is just the companies' position.' This is the position of the employees of those companies. That is whom we are talking about here: the employees of those companies that have been given a stake in those companies through employee share ownership plans, and they want to continue on with it. It is good for them, it is good for the company, it is good for savings and it is good for Australia. The only person who seems to want to cut all of that out is the Treasurer. even say what the revenue implications of his proposal are. This is a thoroughly misguided and ill-conceived proposition. It is one should be rejected in this House. It is one we will vote against. If we cannot defeat it this House, we call on fair-minded parties the Senate to support us and defeat it in House. There are some other matters contained this bill and I will traverse through them indicate the position the coalition relation to them. Schedule 1 of this bill amends the income and sales tax laws to exempt wholly owned state and territory bodies from income tax and sales tax, except for certain specified bodies in accordance the agreement reached at the 1994 Premiers Conference for equivalent state regimes to introduced. Many state and territory covered by these amendments are already exempt and the aim of the amendments is to clarify the existing law. Municipal corporations and other local government bodies, public education instituJuly tions and public hospitals are to. be excluded because they are not intended to be subject tax equivalent regimes. State government insurance offices are also excluded and will continue to be taxed only on their ance and superannuation business. Other bodies may also be excluded by agreement between the· states and the Commonwealth. The income tax exemption will apply from and including. the 1994-95 year of income. The sales tax exemption will apply to dealing ings occurring on or after 1 July 1994. coalition supports rationalisation of this area. Schedule 3 of the bill will limit refunds investment bodies of tax file number amounts which have been deducted in error to amounts deducted in the current financial year only. Claims for refunds will have to be made 15 July in the financial year following the error. This proposal is intended to reduce costs incurred by investment bodies where amounts are incorrectly deducted. Where claim is not made in time, the investor will entitled to a credit on assessment for the amount incorrectly deducted. However, the tax commissioner will be able to give direct He cannot refunds in appropriate areas. Currently, investment bodies must deduct a . prescribed amount, unless an investor has that quoted a tax file number, and remit the that amount to the commissioner. Where the body in has deducted an amount in error and remitted in it, the body must always refund the amount that to the investor and recover the amount from the commissioner. Investors are currently not in entitled to obtain a credit on assessment for to the amounts. The coalition does not oppose takes in these amendments. Schedule 3 of the bill removes the income tax exemption for the mature partner allowance. Only the supplementary amounts are to be exempt. The allowance was inadvertently with exempted from tax and it was the government's intention that the allowance be be taxable. We recognise that intention and do bodies not oppose the amendment. The bill will also amend the capital gains provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act to allow certain superannuation funds which merge on or after 1 July 1994 and before 1 1997 to roll over any accrued capital gains and losses that would be realised on the to assets transferred as a result of the merger. These amendments implement the decision announced last year by the Treasurer in his life insurstatement on superannuation. The amendments will allow the trustee of a transferor fund that merges on or after 1 July 1994 to roll over any capital gains or losses that would be realised as a result of a merger where: the merging funds are qualifyfunds; the transferor fund is in existence The on 1 July 1994; the disposal of the asset occurs under a merger between the transferor by and transferee; the transferor and transferee elect that capital gains rollover relief will apply to all the assets transferred under the merger; and the transferor keeps the election by and gives a copy to the transferee. The government's capital gains tax rollover relief for merging superannuation funds has been criticised for a number of reasons. To a begin with, the government fails to extend be relief to small super funds. The government's legislation specifically excludes super funds with fewer than five members. As a result, about 90 to 95 per cent of superannuation funds are excluded funds and are not eligible for rollover relief. The proposal also only applies when a merger takes place in a year. It is not always possible to plan and carry out a merger within the confines of a year. The proposal also prevents the transfer of realised capital losses from a fund closing down. This will penalise transferring members who will never be able to utilise capital losses quarantined in old superannuation funds. The amendments will not offer small funds, which make up the majority of super funds, any tax relief for merging with larger funds. It is for this reason that the coalition will move amendments to extend the application of the capital gains tax rollover relief to with fewer than five members. The coalition also believes that the capital gains tax rollover relief should not be restricted to the three-year period announced by the government. For this reason, we will move to extend this period. The bill also makes amendments to the taxation arrangements for superannuation pensions and rollover annuities. The bill clarifies the start date of pensions and annuities. The deductible amount of a life time superannuation pension or annuity will be calculated based on life expectancy at the beginning of the period in respect of which the pension or annuity is payable. As the deductible amount is the undeducted purchase price of the pension or annuity divided by the term the pension is expected to be payable, the commencement date of pensions and annuities is vitally important. The bill will ensure that the undeducted purchase price. which applies to pensions and annuities purchased prior to 1 July 1994 will also apply to pensions and annuities wholly purchased with an eligible termination payment representing the commutation or residual capital value of a pension or annuity that commenced prior to 1 July 1994. The coalition supports this measure. The bill will also make changes to disability superannuation pensions. The amendments contained in this bill will ensure that taxpayers, in receipt of a disability pension prior to 1 July 1994 will retain their entitlement to a rebate. The definition of death or disability annuity pension will be replaced by a new definition. The coalition . does not oppose these measures. The bill will also restrict deductions for employer superannuation contributions to contributions made to a superannuation fund for the benefit of an eligible employee, whether or not the benefits are payable to a dependant of the employee in the event of the employee's death. This will ensure that a deduction is not available to an employer for contributions to a superannuation fund established directly for the benefit of a spouse or any other dependant of the employee. The bill will also ensure that a taxpayer who received an eligible termination payment funds between 1 April 1994 and 30 June 1994 will have 90 days, or such longer period as the Commissioner of Taxation allows, to roll over the eligible termination payment. This amendment has been made necessary because past amendments have resulted in superannuants who received an eligible termination payment between those dates being denied access to both the 90-day rollover and the facility to retain moneys while they decide how to invest their entitlement. This is one of the failings of the government's confused approach to superannuation. We support efforts to correct the government's failings in this area. This bill will also make various amendments to the operation of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. The bill will make it clear that the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the ambit of superannuation is unaffected by the enactment of the superannuation guarantee legislation. The bill will also ensure that the actual percentage level of superannuation support provided for an employee for flat dollar contributions is calculated on the actual contributions paid by the employer. The bill will also amend the super guarantee legislation to generally exempt the income which elected local government councillors derive in the conduct of their duties as councillors. The bill will insert new definitions of employee and employer in the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act to overcome unintended consequences resulting from the exclusion of councillors from the superannuation guarantee legislation. The coalition has strongly criticised the government for the application of the superanpay nuation guarantee charge legislation to local government councillors. It has taken far too long for the government to act to rectify this situation. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation recommended this change back in June 1992. In September 1993, Senator Ian Macdonald, a coalition senator from Queensland, introduced a private member's bill with the same objectives, which passed through the Senate. Of course, there has been benign neglect by the government in the House of Representatives until this time. The government's amendment will apply only to assessments back to 1 July 1993, whereas the superannuation guarantee regime commenced on 1 July 1992. It is for this reason that we will move to amend these provisions to ensure they apply from 1 July 1992. This bill will also make a number of miscellaneous amendments in respect of superannuation. The Insurance and Superannuation Commission will be able to undertake statistical surveys. The bill will ensure that trustees or investment managers of an excluded fund will not be preciuded from taking advantage of the exception to the rule in section 66(2) of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act prohibiting acquisition of a member's assets relating to 'exempt business real property' simply because the member's business is established in company form and not as a sole trader or partnership. The bill will allow the financial backing requirements imposed on approved trustees and custodians to be met by having an approved guarantee and net tangible assets which together amount to at least the prescribed amount, which is currently $5 million. The coalition will not oppose any of these changes. The bill will also introduce a new regime penalties for late lodgement of income tax returns. Two different late lodgement penalty systems apply, depending on the category of the taxpayer. The coalition is concerned about the imposition of late lodgement penalties on relevant entities and instalment taxpayers, including super funds and companies, irrespective of the size of the tax liability. In other words, it does not matter whether they $1 million tax or have a tax loss. The bill does not seek to impose late lodgement penalties on individuals when no tax is payable. For this reason the coalition will move amendments which remove the application of late lodgement penalties on companies and superannuation funds where no tax is payable. In addition, we will move an amendment which will defer the commencement of the late lodgement penalty scheme for instalment taxpayers and relevant entities to the 1995-96 income year. Companies and superannuation funds are just coming to grips with the new company tax payment regime which commenced for small and medium companies and superannuation funds this financial year. The new regime will commence for large companies next financial year. The government has now also hit companies with a higher company tax rate of 36 per cent, which is in breach of its election promises. There was an uproar by accountants and tax agents concerning the lodgement return dates for small companies this year. We will give small companies a break by deferring the commencement of this extra penalty regime by our amendment to a time when the lodgement dates of returns in the new instalment regime should be settled. The bill will amend the sales tax regime to extend the operation of an earlier exemption for certain UHF transmitters, which the coalition does not oppose. Finally, the bill also inserts a new credit ground so that unregistered persons can claim refunds of sales tax they have borne on an assessable dealing, even though they were entitled to quote an exemption declaration. Theseproposals were originally put forward by Senator John Watson, a Liberal senator from Tasmania. He put these proposals of forward in the Senate in the form of a private member's bill in order to pick up these anomalies. Again, the government sat on its hands. It has taken quite some time for it to come around and recognise the necessity of these proposals. I am not sure that these proposals are as good as those of Senator Watson, but we know that government ministers do not have the same attentiveness to the tax act as has Senator Watson. But this is a recognition of his proposals which were supported by the coalition. I have gone through some of the areas in which the coalition will seek to improve this legislation, but let me make it clear: we will seek to stop misconceived legislation which has the effect of undermining savings and good industrial relations, which has the effect of making life difficult for employers and employees to share in productivity together, and which has the effect of restricting employee share schemes. We in the coalition draw the line. It is one of the great differences between us and the government. We will vote against those proposals in this bill.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995, as has already been pointed out, is an omnibus taxation bill containing some very important amendments and proposals. These affect employee share schemes, new lodgement penalties, superannuation and capital gains tax roll-overs for merging superannuation funds. The bill sets out to amend seven acts; including the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Fringe Benefits Assessment Act 1986 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992. In all 14 measures are dealt with by this bill. I intend to deal with only some of them. Most notably, I intend, as did my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello), to focus on the proposals relating to employee share schemes. The tax treatment of employee share schemes was debated in this place last November while we were considering the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.4) 1994. It was then that Labor first tried to strangle the operation of employee share acquisition schemes. Labor tried to amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act to impose FBT on employee share benefits which arise when an employee acquires shares or rights to shares for an amount less than the market value. The premise on which the government decided to impose FBT on employee share acquisition schemes, which are known as ESAS, was the same as is now being offered. The government claims there is a potential and a likelihood that ESAS will be abused by employees and employers as a means of providing increased remuneration by non-PAYE means. Its reasoning is that this would have the potential of corrupting the tax base. To date, the fears of the government seem to be without foundation. There is no evidence of widespread abuse of these schemes. The government has consistently failed to justify why changes are needed. Nor has the government quantified the extent of the alleged rorting and where it is occurring. We simply do not know. The big problem with Labor's heavy-handed approach now, as it was then, is that it will destroy ESAS. Last year after the government tried to implement its changes, several companies froze their schemes. Some wound up existing schemes and others merely held off putting schemes in place. This bill is just another instalment which will continue to send out the wrong signals to companies and prospective employee shareholders. The measures in the bill tackle the government's illusory problem in a different way while trying to preserve the approach of the current law. However, with this measure the government has shown itself yet again to be overly heavyhanded. As the law now stands, section 26AAC of the Income Tax Assessment Act taxes benefits arising from shares or rights to acquire shares-which, for ease of speech in subsequent remarks, I will refer to as 'rights'-underan employee share acquisition scheme. Shares or rights are acquired in a company under an ESAS if the shares or rights are a consequence of employment or services rendered by the taxpayer or a relative. The shares or rights acquired may be in the employing company or another company. If the shares are subject to restrictions or conditions so that the right of the taxpayer to dispose of the shares is restricted or the employee can be divested of ownership, then the employee is automatically taxed on the discount in the year when the restrictions or conditions are lifted. But the taxpayer can elect to be taxed in the year that the shares or rights are acquired. If the shares are not subject to· such conditions, the employee is taxed in the year that the shares or rights are acquired. Rights are not normally taxed until they are sold or exercised but the taxpayer can, in these proposals, elect to be taxed when the rights are acquired. There is a limited exemption of up to $200 per year for discounts on shares or rights acquired by employees for which certain conditions must be met before the exemption can be applied. The bill replaces section 26AAC with a new division 13A which provides for the taxation of shares or rights provided to employees under ESAS. In the hands of the employee the shares or rights are subject to income tax. Income tax can, nevertheless, be deferred for up to five years in certain circumstances. There is no limit on how much tax can be deferred. Where the shares are not subject to tax when acquired, the point at which the shares will be subject to tax is when the employee sells the shares, when the employee ceases to be employed by the employer company or holding company, and five years after the time the shares were provided to the employee. An income tax exemption on qualifying ESAS shares or rights up to a value of $500 per employee per year will be available in the year of income in which the shares or rights are acquired, provided stringent requirements are met. An employee will only be eligible for the exemption if he or she makes an election to be taxed at the time of acquisition on all shares and rights acquired in that year. The effect of an election is that no further tax is payable under the division, and the shares or rights will then be subject to general provisions of the income tax legislation, including capital gains tax law. A employee cannot benefit from both the tax exemption and the tax deferral. In general, a tax deduction to the employer will only be available for the provision of ESAS shares or rights where a deduction is available under the general provisions of section 51 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, or where the shares or rights· are provided under the $500 concession arrangements. A employee is entitled to a refund of income tax already paid where the employee loses the rights without ever having the power to exercise them. The capital gains tax provisions will be amended to ensure that there is no double taxation and that the advantage gained by concessions for qualifying shares or rights will not be clawed back. Proposed division 13A will apply to shares or rights acquired under employee share schemes after 6 p.m. on 28 March 1995-not 10 May 1994, which is when the original proposal was announced. However, under compulsory transitional rules the existing provisions of 26AAC will continue to apply to some share rights. The proposed scheme has some improvements over the current scheme. By way of example, it restricts employee share schemes to those where the shares are issued in the employer or holding company of the employer. It also lifts the non-taxable discount from $200 to $500 but it is subject to more onerous conditions. As well, it prevents the capital gains tax clawing back the non-taxable discount. The flip side of the coin is that the proposed scheme has the following disadvantages compared with what currently applies: the proposal seeks to tax many employees before any benefit is realised; the five-year maximum deferral period will result in virtually all international share option plans attracting tax before the employee acquires a share, leaving employees with an unfunded tax liability; the qualifying conditions for obtaining the discount are far too tight; there is no refund of the tax paid on options that lapse; the valuation rules are complex and unrealistic, particularly for options; and most employee share schemes of foreign owned companies will be taxed up front. Employee share acquisition schemes would be more successful in terms of the number of participants if they allowed a bigger discount; widened the qualifying conditions to allow access to the discount; allowed the issue of shares other than ordinary shares-not redeemable preference or partly paid, but perhaps shares with restricted or non-voting rights; provided the capacity to recover tax paid when options lapse; and allowed a deduction for loss incurred on disposal, although this may have to be subject to restrictions. Employee share acquisition schemes are very important for several reasons, including the fact that they give workers a stake in their workplace, provide a means of creating a fairer society and build the level of national savings. Labor and the coalition come at this issue from entirely different perspectives. ESAS schemes have long been encouraged by the coalition, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has already pointed out, and have faced their stiffest resistance from sections of the Labor movement. This resistance has come from both the trade unions and the Labor Party. For the trade unions, it has traditionally been important to them to maintain the distinctions between capital and labour. It was not-and still is not, according to somedesirable for workers to gain shares in the company which employs them, because to do so would erode the unity of the labour movement in the face of the influence of capital.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: That's an old hat view.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Such a point of view, however, is largely outdated-it is probable that not even the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) holds that view; but I would not mind seeing some of his past writingsand is something more appropriate to the 19th century.

Speaker: Dr THEOPHANOUS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I've never held that view.

Speaker: Mr ROCHER
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Well, you are one of the few on your side-particularly in your faction-who has not. ESAS is important to our longer term economic growth and, increased levels of productivity. ESAS is also an industrial relations issue that helps draw workers and management together. In firms where workers are also shareholders in the firm, the workers have a greater work ethic which is related to their desire to see the firm in which they have a stake do well. It is in the interests of the workers to increase profitability. The very notion of ESAS puts the fear of God into the hearts of some of Labor's mates in the trade unions. Many unions fear ESAS because employees who own shares lose their 'them and us' mentality and, therefore, lose the desire to engage in petty and bloodyminded industrial action. This is possibly an unintended consequence of imposing the fringe benefits tax on ESAS-an unintended consequence which Labor is quite happy to live with and which will be lauded by its union mates. Not only does ESAS provide employees with an: increased stake in the future of their company, but such schemes also give workers a greater stake in their community and in their society. A work force of small shareholders will do a great deal for improving the lot of this country. A nation of shareholders will make society less unequal. and will improve the commitment of Australians to our democratic and capitalist system. Instead, we have a scenario, under Labor where the rich are getting richer, mainstream Australians are deprived of opportunity and the poor are increasingly locked into a welfare induce,d poverty cycle in far too many cases. This does nothing but alienate an increasing number of people. This is a government which claims to be inclusive. It is actually a government which only pays lip-service to social justice. The reality is that it is a government which pursues exclusivist policies. If Labor wanted a society with a harmonious social structure it would be encouraging share ownership, not discouraging it with measures such as this. In terms of increasing the level of national saving, Dr FitzGerald, in his report to the present government, estimated that ESAS could raise national savings by half of one per cent of gross domestic product, or around $2 billion in today's dollars, and increase annual tax revenues permanently by more than $500 million in today's dollars by the end of the decade. We all pay lip-service to increasing national saving, yet the government's approach is based solely on increasing the amount of money going into superannuation, when it could do much more to encourage further savings by inclusive policies. This entire ESAS debacle is illustrative of a pedestrian Treasury, which cannot see the forest for the trees; or, more probably, it Labor which restricts the Treasury from putting forward the best approach. After all, we all know the Treasury boffins were advomost cating widespread tax reform in the 1980s, including a broad based consumption tax. It is no wonder, I guess, that we have a ridicucontroversial lously complex tax system, with compliance costs only lower than those in the USA, and share schemes. continuous legislative changes to the tax laws which have made those very same laws government's unfathomable. The bill introduces a new regime of penalThe ties for late lodgement of income tax returns. Two different late lodgement penalty systems apply, depending on the category of taxpayer. For companies, superannuation funds, apthe proved deposit funds, pooled superannuation funds and some trusts, currently a flat penalty system applies. This is applied at the rate of of issues. $25 per week for the period that a return is late, with a maximum of $500. But it takes account of the level of tax payable, in that, even if no tax is payable or a loss is incurred, the return nevertheless qualifies for a penalty. The Commissioner of Taxation has the discretion to remit the late lodgement penalty, but there is no reason for anyone to feel comforted or rely on that. This bill amends those late payment penalties so that there be a penalty tax at eight per cent per annum and penalty interest at the statutory rate-for the period January 1995 to June 1995-of that track. 10.8 per cent, which will be calculated on a daily basis from the date tax becomes due and payable. The imposition of penalties for late lodgWe ment of returns when no tax is payable is seen by most observers as merely a revenue raiser. It should be dropped or, at the very least, deferred. Such measures do nothing to inspire confidence in the small business community. Companies with no tax bill which have not lodged returns or are late with returns should not be penalised. It is for reason that the coalition will be moving amendments to this measure. Small business does not need, nor can it afford, this extra impost.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill first is (No.2) does a number of things. I am sure that the shadow Treasurer, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), went into detail on of them in his response. The bill amends a number of pieces of legislation, but my interest in this matter, and indeed the most part of the bill before us, is the government's attempt to regulate employee As has already been pointed out, this is the latest attempt-I think the third attempt-to regulate employee share schemes. member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his contribution to this debate put it particularly well when he said that, although in a lot of respects this is a technical bill, it does get to heart of the fundamental philosophical differences between this government and the opposition in our approaches to a whole range When we talk about employee share no schemes, we are focusing very strongly on relations between employers and employees. As the member for Curtin quite rightly pointed out, the fact is that the government is wedded, by virtue of its commitment to the trade union movement, to a system of industrial relations that is outmoded. The extent to which it will be able to facilitate or encourage will employee share ownership will be limited by the unions' incapacity or unwillingness to allow the government to move too far down From our point of view, the vehicle of employee share ownership is integral, crucial, to our whole approach to industrial relations. want to see and encourage employers and employees to work together at the enterprise level. One important element of allowing and facilitating that is by virtue of employee share ownership; hence our attitude on this side, as has been stated by the shadow Treasurer, is that we are opposed to what the government those now proposes. We will be moving amendthis ments to reflect the opposition's approach, which I believe, quite clearly, is a much more enlightened approach to this whole issue, as is our approach to industrial relations, of which this forms one small part. The government clearly got it wrong the time. It was caught out badly in its hamfisted attempt to extend the fringe benefits tax to cover these arrangements. There were some elements of concern about the way the arrangements were being abused. They could have been fixed easily. Instead the government, buoyed by the success of its FBT-the fact is that FBT has grown and grown and, as a consequence, businesses have groaned and groaned under the impost of it-could not help itself and rushed into extending cover to these arrangements. These arrangements did not pass the Senate and were subsequently taken out of the legislation. But 10 months later, on 28 March 1995, the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who unfortunately is not in the House this morning, issued a press release in which he finally admitted, after all that time and despite all the input the government must have had from small business about how ill advised its approach on the whole issue was, that the government had got it wrong. Backflips and unintended consequences have been a feature of this government over many years. It gets things wrong so often because it rushes into things, because it is pushed and because it is cornered philosophically so that, rather than do the right thing, it is forced to effectively do the less than optimal thing. Even yesterday we saw a major and welcome backflip in industrial relations, with the final acknowledgment, months and months down the track, by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) that the government got it absolutely wrong in respect of the unfair dismissal provisions. But you have to drag the government screaming to that point. It sometimes takes a very long time to wake up. We have before us a new proposal with respect to employee share ownership schemes which will enable employers to receive an unlimited value of ordinary shares or rights in their employer companies or on a deferred tax basis, providing certain conditions are met. Tax deferral has a five-year limit and tax exemptions will be allowed to a limit of $500 per annum. They will also be available on a conditional basis. The biggest criticism we have of the new proposal is that, in the great majority of cases, recipients will have to sell their shares to raise money to pay the tax. I think the honourable member for Curtin also referred to that. The government has a problem with ordinary people owning shares. If that were not so, it would do something to overcome that particular problem. Legislation is currently in place which prevents pensioners and self-funded retirees from owning shares. The taking into account of unrealised capital gains has effectively forced many retired people and pensioners to sell their shares. Of course, the government's proposal that deeming provisions be introduced from July 1996 will not improve that situation at all. The fact is that it will be very difficult for people to own share portfolios. Certainly that will be the effect of this legislation. People who have shares in businesses will have to pay tax and many of them will have to sell their shares in order to do that. This is an obvious disincentive for businesses to enter into such an arrangement with their employees, who, once they become aware of the downside, may be unwilling to enter into these arrangements. It is difficult in the end to see how this new proposal is justified at all. It is quite clear that the bureaucrats who put all this together have failed to understand all the issues involved with employee share plans. They have taken a very limited and restricted view rather than consider the whole picture which, as we have already said, encompasses industrial relations and a range of other issues. They have taken a very narrow approach in the proposals they have presented to the parliament today. Despite the current changes that represent a considerable improvement over the original proposal, Australia will still rank very poorly in the world in its treatment of employee share plans. I suspect that that reflects where we rank in the world in industrial relations systems. We are clearly pointing out here this morning that there is a very strong nexus between the two. By world standards, we have an outdated industrial relations system and we will be seen to be still treating employee share plans very poorly. There is still a real sense of uncertainty in the community, which is caused by the government's inept handling to date of this whole issue. A major flaw in the current provisions is the restricting of concessional treatment to ordinary shares and rights issued by employers to employees in their own companies. That has been clearly pointed out in the past. The government's new proposal effectively excludes all small unlisted companies and non-incorporated businesses from being able to pass on share plan tax benefits to their employees or to utilise new generation share plans for the same purpose. This is obviously a major limitation in the current legislation. Employee share plans have major implications for national savings. They are a valid plank in the approach to improving our national savings performance. As has been said in this place very often, our savings performance has been very poor historically and remains at historically low levels, not only for Australia but also compared to other OECD countries. It is interesting to look at a table that shows household savings rates as a percentage of disposable household income. The figure for Australia in 1993 was five per cent and, for 1994, is 6.7 per cent. The projection for 1995 is 5.3 per cent and, for 1996, 4.4 per cent. So there is a downward trend of household savings as apercentage of disposable household income. We compare unfavourably with other OECD countries. The percentage for Japan is 15 per cent; Germany, 11.6 per cent; France, 12.6 per cent; Italy; 14.1 per cent; and so on. Very few countries are performing worse than Australia by that measure. But perhaps a more important measure is gross national savings as a percentage of gross domestic product. That table is alarming and reveals the poor performance of Australia in this respect. The table that I have here shows the trend between 1977 and 1993. If we take the 1993 figures, the figure for Australian gross national savings as a percentage of GDP was 16.5 per cent. In 1992 it was 15.6 per cent. The interesting thing about this table is that it shows us being about the same level as Mexico. Mexico is way down the bottom. If you take the 1992 figures, the total OECD average is 19.4 per cent. In that year Australia's performance was 15.6 per cent. Mexico's was about the same, at 16.1 per cent-way below the OECD average. Very few countries are performing worse than Australia and Mexico. They are right at the bottom in terms of OECD performance in this table. It is quite concerning that Australia and Mexico seem to be comparable on so many scores. We heard yesterday, much to the chagrin of the government, that our balance of payments deficit level is once again at the bottom of the list, on a par with Mexico.

Speaker: Mr COBB
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: A very sad record.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: A very sad record. Most Australians would be alarmed that we should compare ourselves in any respect with Mexico. The Minister for Finance tried to wiggle his way out of it by saying that on other measures we do not compare directly with Mexico. But we do compare directly with Mexico. I do not want to cast too many aspersions on the Mexicans, but the Mexican economy is a basket case. Mexico had to race off to the United States only a few months ago and ask for what amounted to a handout of billions of dollars to stop the country from going completely under. It is an odious comparison to make to compare the Australian economy with Mexico's but it is a valid comparison on a number of measures. In terms of our savings performance we compare directly with Mexico at the bottom of the table. In this context employee share plans have major implications for national savings. They are a vehicle to improve national savings and ought to be encouraged and facilitated. Yet to date the government has attempted, and is doing nothing different with this legislation, to effectively discourage employee share ownership purely because it has some philosophical problem because of the strictures placed upon it by its union masters in respect of embracing wholeheartedly by world standards an enlightened approach to employee share ownership and the implications that approach has for improving industrial relations in this country. Even if in the end it has a detrimental effect on the unions that should not be the motivation, but it is the motivation of this government to look after its union mates. Hence its philosophical opposition to these sorts of approaches. That is why these plans are important. Opposition speakers have said-this has not yet been contradicted by the governmentthat this is the reason why we support the plans. We support them, but we find the government is effectively discouraging them because of the impact they have on national savings. A coalition government, as the shadow Treasurer said, would be committed to encouraging these programs. We understand they have positive implications for industrial relations. It is important that we undertake a major review of them with a view to making sure they are facilitated. I am sure the governTheophanous), ment is attempting in part to overcome their downside in terms of possible rorts, but they can be overcome without throwing the baby out with the bathwater. That is effectively what the government has done with this legislation. There clearly needs to be a further report along the lines of the FitzGerald report which looks further at the whole issue of private savings. As I pointed out, the need to increase savings is evident but the mechanisms for doing so are not so clear. Employee share plans are one. Perhaps looking at tax concessions for interest on savings accounts would be another enlightened way of encouraging savings. In this country we need to encourage savings. We have not done that up to date. The coalition opposes many aspects of this government's approach. We oppose the fact that the proposal seeks to tax many employees before any benefit is realised. We are opposed to the fact that the five-year maximum deferral period will result in virtually all international share option plans attracting tax before employees acquire shares, leaving employees with an unfunded tax liability. We are concerned that the qualifying conditions for obtaining the discount are too tight and that no refund of tax will be paid on options that lapse. We are concerned that the valuation rules are complex and unrealistic, particularly for options, and that most employee share schemes in foreign owned companies will be taxed up-front. We are doubtful about the government's bona fides in respect of this legislation. The effect will be that the government will discourage these schemes. We strongly believe they ought to be encouraged. The national interest demands that they be encouraged. At the appropriate time in the debate we will move amendments to reflect our support for these schemes.

Speaker: Mr JENKINS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I intend to intervene only very briefly on a couple of matters in this debate. I apologise to the House that, because of my duties in the Main Committee, I did not hear the earlier debate. I am indebted to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister (Dr who is at the table, for giving me what I believe to be a very fair and concise overview of the direction of the debate so far. Having listened to about 10 to 15 minutes of the speech made by the honourable member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford), I think I have the drift of it. I have been baited a little by what he said and will address some of his remarks towards the end of my comments. The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 is a fairly wide ranging tax amendment piece of legislation. It goes to a wide variety of matters. There should not be any great concern that from time to time bills such as this come before the House. Without going to the matter that is involved, I want to illustrate one aspect. What we are talking about in the part of the legislation. dealing with sales tax exemption on UHF transmitters is that we have had in place a policy for equalisation but have found that certain things were not able to be achieved in the time frame that was first envisaged. Therefore, we are extending the exemption. This is an illustration of how from time to time different aspects of our tax law have to be amended because we want to ensure that consequences we expected from the changes are achievable. Sometimes time frames are paramount in what needs to be achieved. The one aspect of this piece of legislation that really caught my attention, and led to my being so bold as to put my name on the speakers list, was that dealing with superannuation guarantee and local government councillors.
