There was quite a campaign about the way in which the superannuation guarantee levy impinged upon elected councillors, impinged upon the allowances that elected counciIIors received. One aspect of the case was put to me by the local government in the city of Whittlesea, amongst other municipalities that came to me and sought my assistance. That aspect was that we managed to have the peculiar situation where there were apparently two definitions of 'employee'-one for the purposes of in-ome tax and one for the purposes of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act. I do not often do this but I wrote to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) about these matters, and he quite rightly took advice from the Australian Taxation Office. In replying to my office, he provided copies of determinations by the commissioner. I have to say that, in respect of the reply he sent to me in August 1993, I noted on my file copy 'the logic escapes me'. It was even worse when we had a second go at it. We got a reply back in January 1994 and a member of my staff described the Assistant Treasurer's letter as a disgrace. . I suppose we' should not be so emotive about different aspects, and I am pleased to see that this legislation addresses some of the perceived problems. I think that is fair because the nature of the allowances received by local counciIIors previously, especially in the state of Victoria, was that they were in lieu a reimbursement of expenses. They were hardly a salary. When those allowances were first put in place they were set at the level of $1,200, and that may have reached the level of either $2,000 or $3,000 by the time elected councillors were dismissed by the Victorian government and replaced by commissioners. It was really something that was basically a voluntary effort by those elected to those municipalities. I am pleased that the result of the amendments we see in this piece of legislation acknowledge that. I will not stray too far from the bill but I just want to make some comments. In Victoria, with the changes we are seeing in local government, there is under consideration a different role for elected councillors when we see a return to democratically elected councillors in March 1997. There is some contemplation that they will better represent part-time or full-time positions where the remuneration can be seen as a form of salary. I accept that, if that is the eventuation, salary will come within the ambit of all our tax laws, the income tax superannuation guarantee and the lik- . That move really does highlight the fact that local government in Victoria is going through a great transition. Unfortunately, that transition has led to commissioners being appointed for a period of nearly two years. That is a disappointment. I do not wish to reflect upon individual commissioners but, at the end of the day, they have been appointed by the state government and have been asked to achieve an agenda that the state government has put in place for them. It will be interesting to see whether the role of a local councillor is given a greater status. If during this period the state government is realistic in defining a wider role for local councillors, perhaps that will make the full time positions more attractive to people and that would lead to those elected people getting a remuneration that more reflects a salary rather than a reimbursement of expenses. I make brief mention of the aspect of this legislation that appears to have got the oppoof sition well and truly in a lather: employee share schemes. Unless I have completely and utterly missed the point, I think this really is setting out to achieve a number of thuse things the honourable member for MCPherson tried to say it is not. I understand that there has been the notion that the measures in place in this legislation are as a result of some capital 'I' ideological bent of the government. I do not know that I really agree with that. I often have to reconcile in my own mind that this Labor government is a government of the modem Labor Party. It is the government of a Labor Party that is evolving. Whilst it might give me concern from time to time that that has meant there have been shifts in the ideological basis of a number of things the government doesthe clearest example of that is the government's attitude in certain areas to public ownership-we do see that still it is a government that has many of the fine tradit.ions of previous Labor governments, still it attempts to look at those issues of equity and fairness, and still it looks to the way it can try to achieve things that can be seen as being for the wider common good. Towards the end of his contribution, the honourable member for MCPherson at" least admitted that, in part, what we were trying do with this amendment as it deals with a employee share schemes was-to use his ant words- 'to put a lid on any rorts that going on'. Having come to a realisation that that is the intent, I find it a bit sad understanding, amendments proposed to be moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposihistory tion (Mr Costello) in the consideration in detail stage are to completely delete schedule 2, which deals with all those matters to with employee share schemes. I also understand that the drift of much of the case put by the coalition is that in some way this exemplifies some erroneous attitude that the government has to industrial relations. I would have thought that if we really read the intent of not only this amendment but the basic legislation being amended, we would see that it gives scope for employees to take the option of investing in shares within the companies they are employed in. It is therefore a form by which workers participate in their companies. It tightens way in which any tax concession would be given. It gives options for the way in the employee might decide to have the tax considerations of any discount he or she was to get on the share offer. That appears to very fair. Likewise, I think it goes honourable member for MCPherson highlighted: national savings. I do not think we have to have the great argument, this argy-bargy, about the situation at the moment. We need to have the argument about how we are going to best address it. The FitzGerald inquiry clearly showed that we, as a nation, need to address the level of our national savings. Much of this year's budget provisions went to addressing that. The.. whole intent of what we are trying to achieve in the area of superannuation has as an underpinning tenet that it is a measure to improve our national savings position. The superannuation measures will have a twofold outcome. These measures will not only attempt to give individuals the opportunity to put in place arrangements that will best suit them in their retirement but also attempt to, through these collective efforts, to achieve a pool of national savings that we as nation need. I think that this is most importand it is sotpething that this· government are has had high on its agenda for quite some time. It is something that this government that, to my recognises needs to be achieved. If we look at this Labor government's on superannuation, we find that a national superannuation plan has always been high on its agenda. It is something that has do often been under active consideration. The situation prior to the Second World War was that superannuation was basically restricted to white-collar workers. The situation improved only marginally in the postwar period. Former Prime Minister Menzies-someone I know the honourable member for Warringah also (Mr Abbott) has a high regard for-promised a national superannuation scheme in 1949, but for various reasons did not deliver. Figures from the Bureau of Statistics show that at the time of the Whitlam government in 1974 only can 29 per cent of the employed population the belonged to super schemes. On three occasions-notably, September 1970, April 1971 which and September 1971-the Labor Party was defeated in the parliament on motions calling for the establishment of a national superanbe nuation scheme. Consequently, in the 1972 budget then Treasurer Snedden announced to the issue the such a scheme. At the time, former Prime Minister Whitlam said that it took 23 years and much cajoling from the ALP for the government to honour its commitment. In March 1973, the Whitlam government established a national superannuation committee of inquiry, the Hancock committee. The task of ensuring that Australian workers have access to superannuation has taken a long time. After the experiences of some two decades, we now see that by using different mechanisms-mechanisms that were not envisaged at that time-we have gone a long way to achieving a commitment towards a broad superannuation scheme that is accessible to all workers. If members of the coalition want to highlight in this debate the issue of industrial relations then they should realise and acknowledge that the organised union movement has played its role in getting to this point. Representatives of the union movement have sat down and talked to the government-and they have not agreed entirely with the direction the government has taken on all occasions, but they have been at the table-and they have been willing to make concessions. On behalf of the workers they represent, they see the merits in not only the employer contributions but also the employee contributions. They recognise that to forgo, at this time, salary in lieu of making these superannuation contributions will benefit individual workers-if we are to look at their whole life, which is important. It is true that that money is not in their pockets now and that will have a consequence for them, but it has to be seen in light of the fact that this will have a benefit down the track. If employees choose to forgo part of their salary in order to make superannuation contributions, it will have a benefit for those workers as individuals and it will also have a benefit for the nation. Down the track more individuals will have their own form of income support in their retirement and will not have to rely on safety net provisions or social security payments and other types of welfare payments that the federal government has historically had to provide. If we were to keep the system that we have seen over the past few decades, it would place an almighty burden on taxpayers as we go into the next century. The taxpayers would not be able to sustain the level of income that people enjoy at present. That is an important outcome of our move to this wider access to superannuation. Another benefit of the movement that we see in this area is that it will increasingly give a savings pool of significant proportions. One of the great challenges for future governments will be to ensure that there is proper prudential management of those pools of money so that benefits can be accrued by individuals. The other benefit will be that, in the investment of those funds, those managers will be acting in the best interests of the whole Australian community. I urge those involved in that management to give consideration to being able to place investments in things that will have that wider good. They should look at the different types of mechanisms that have been put in place as it will encourage them to invest in infrastructure. As I have often said in this place, if we do not ensure that we have proper investment in the infrastructure and the maintenance of infrastructure, it will lead to almighty problems that are being illustrated in other parts of the world such as the United States and some European countries. In conclusion, I have great pleasure in supporting this piece of legislation.

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Warringah) (11.22 a.m.)The employee share ownership concept is about working together; it is about turning adversaries in the workplace into partners; it is about establishing property owning democracy; it is about giving workers what they do not always have-the dignity of a stake in their business. I imagine that, if the government was thinking this through properly, it would support everything that is being put by the opposition. I do not believe that many members opposite-there may be a fewhave adopted their position out of ideology. The government's position is basically the result of indolence, thoughtlessness, avarice and the bad habits of a government which has been in power too long. The member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) talked about rorts. This legislation of the government is supposed to eliminate rorts. What rorts? This issue has been debated three times now in this parliament, and not once has the government been able to come up with chapter and verse of the rorts that this legislation is supposed to eliminate. What we in the opposition believe is that workers and managers should be partners in enterprises. They need to be friends, not enemies. This is why we are insistent that everything possible should be done to maximise the spread of employee share ownership. The government says it is in favour of employee share ownership, but its actions speak louder than its words. Under the tax regime that operated until last year,' if an employee obtained. shares at a concessional rate, then instead of paying tax on the value of that concession that tax could be deferred until the value of that share was realised. As I said, three times this government has tried to change the tax regime governing the issue of shares to employees. Twice it has been defeated. Three times it has got it wrong. This proposal will similarly be defeated-if not here, in another place. The result of the government's ham-fisted approach to employee share ownership is that 90 per cent of the employee share schemes currently operating in Australia are on indefiin nite hold. Of companies employing more than 1,000 people in Australia, 60 per .cent at present have employee share schemes. These share schemes are on hold. In other words, companies employing 10 per cent of the work force have these schemes on hold. That is to say, one million Australian workers, who should have the benefit of employee share schemes, are being deprived of the benefit of these schemes because of this government's ham-fisted handling of the issue. These companies are the household names of Australian industry. These companies are a rollcall of blue chips. These companies with employee share ownership schemes are not trying to rort the system; they are not trying to rip off the Australian people. These companies are trying to build a decent economy and a decent society. They include: AW A; Advance Bank; Amcor; Apple Computer; the Australian Industry Development Corporation, which in fact is owned by the federal government; the Bank of Melbourne; Baulderstone Hornibrook; Boral; Brambles; Bums Philp; Cadbury Schweppes; Clyde Industries; CocaCola; Commercial Union Assurance; the Commonwealth Bank of Australia; Country Road;CRA; Fletcher Jones; Gillette; Goodman Fielder; Hills Industries; James Hardie; Jennings Industries; Kraft Foods; Leighton Holdings; Lend Lease Corporation; National Australia Bank; Newcrest Mining; Normandy Poseidon; North Broken Hill Peko; Pacific Dunlop; Pasminco; South Australian Brewing; St George Building Society, now St George Bank; the Austnilian Gas Light Co.; BHP; Tubemakers; W.e. Penfold; Westpac; ANZ; BTR Nylex; CSR; Email; Mayne Nickless; Pioneer International; Rothmans; and Western Mining Corporation. These are companies which this legislation implicitly accuses of cheating and defrauding the taxpayer. Quite frankly, these are not companies that would ever do that kind of thing; these are companies which have employee share ownership schemes in place because they want to do the right thing by their workers and by society. Qantas plans to issue each one of its 27,000 employees $500 worth of shares in the company. That exercise democratic capitalism, that exercise in extending the benefits of government policy to workers, is on hold because of this foolish piece of ham-fisted legislative bungling. As I said, the previous position was that the concessions on shares issued to employees only attracted tax' when those shares were realised. Under the latest government scheme you can do it two ways: if you eleCt to pay the tax up front, then you can get a tax concession of $500 on the shares issued. To just consider for a moment how trivial and how petty this concession is, $500 worth of BHP shares is probably about 50 shares. That is the trivial nature of the concession that this government is offering. The alternative is to take the shares and then pay tax in five years time. Let us consider this: an average worker is offered shares in his company by management. He thinks to himself, 'Interest rates have just gone up three times in the last year. My mortgage is costing me more and more to carry each month, as the government's recovery peters out, as the economy hits the wall. My job is not as safe as it was.' That sort of worker is not going to be able to accept shares on a five-year deferred tax basis. If that worker does accept shares on that basis, what will happen is that he or she will take the shares, hold them for five years and then have to pay tax before having had a chance to enjoy their benefits. This scheme of the government is not a share owning scheme; it is actually a share renting scheme. By saying that workers can take the shares but that then they will have to pay the tax in five years time, the government is not turning workers into share owners; it is turning them into share renters. If a benefit is worth giving, it is worth giving for keeps. This is the shareholding equivalent of saying to people who currently get concession travel on the railways, 'Okay, we'll let you buy your ticket for half price now, but at the end of the year for all those tickets that you've bought for half price you'll have to pay the rest of the full fare.' It just does not make sense. This government is attempting to apply to shareholders the same sort of logic as it has previously applied with the deeming principle to part pensioners. It is really saying, 'You will have to pay tax on benefits that you haven't actually received.' Just as the government has said to pensioners, 'Okay, we're cutting your pension and you can toddle off to Telecom and pay your phone bill with a BHP share,' it is really saying to workers who would like to own shares in their companies, 'You've got to pay in tax good cash before you actually have the cash in your pocket to meet that tax bill.' There are many other problems with this bill. I mention just two of them. The only people who will qualify even for these limited concessions that the government is offering are people who are taking ordinary shares. What that does is exclude from the operation of this kind of scheme companies which do not issue ordinary shares-that is to say, all those unlisted and private companies which employ something like two-thirds of the people in the Australian work force. In other words, this scheme of the government cuts out from the benefits of employee share ownership something like two-thirds of the Australian work force. Sure, these small family run companies can go through all the legal and accounting trouble of establishing a class of ordinary shares so that they can cut their workers into the action and benefits of ownership. But the problem then is, unless those shares are traded regularly, unless there is a regular market in these shares, every time companies issue a share to a worker they will have to call in an auditor to get a valuation. Mr Deputy Speaker, how many companies will do that? The simple truth is: very few. What this legislation is doing is restricting the scope of employee share ownership. It is tying up in endless bureaucratic and accounting red tape the ability of companies to help their workers and help themselves at the same time. Consider the case of employee buy-outs. We all know that sometimes companies go bad-not because the workers are incapable but because the managers are incapable. In lots of instances the workers have tried to preserve their jobs and to keep those companies going by buying them out-by saying, 'Look, management, you haven't done much of a job; let us see how we can go.' Under this legislation, if those companies then issue the shares back to the workers, the workers will have to pay tax on those shares in five years time and the worker buy-out will last only five years. Just as soon as the workerowners of those companies start to get used to being men and women of substance, they will go back to being wage slaves. Everyone in this place agrees that Australia needs to lift national savings. Lifting national savings is important to get interest rates down, to get debt down and, in the long run, to be able to increase the wealth of our society so that real wages-which today are five per cent less than they were in 1976can start to go up again. The problem with this piece of government legislation is that it will actually reduce the ability and incentives for Australians to save. At the moment, employee share schemesschemes which are currently frozen in practice because of this legislation-have an estimated value of $3 billion. Vince FitzGerald, a very respected economist, has estimated that the government would get $500 million more in tax revenue every year under the regime that used to apply to these sorts of schemes than it has under any of the three schemes that the government has tried in the last 12 months. This legislation is an example of the government's propensity to tax first and think later because, if it had thought through, it would understand that it was actually going to make everybody worse off. With a few exceptions that are not of great account and with the exception of a few members of the Victorian socialist Left, everyone in this parliament believes that the free market is the best method humankind has yet devised to generate wealth. There is absolutely nothing wrong with the market principle. The only problem is that the operation of the free market leaves some people with unequal market power. The solution is not to close down the market and thereby abolish people's freedom to buy and sell. The solution is to even up the market power of the citizens who are participating in the market. Employee share ownership is a way of turning workers into participants in the market, rather than leaving them slaves in the market. The Labor Party, as the member for Scullin pointed out, has come a long way. Unfortunately, in coming a long way, it has forgotten some of the enduring values that all members in this House should hold dear. It has forgotten that light on the hill that Ben Chifley talked about-the light to be reached by 'working for the betterment of mankind not only here but anywhere we may give a helping hand'. If the government were thinking of Ben Chifley and his memory and example, it would not be proceeding down this path. It would be encouraging employee share ownership schemes, not talking out of both sides of its mouth. On the one hand, it is saying, 'Yes, we believe in these things,' and, on the other hand, it is introducing legislation which makes it practically impossible for these schemes to flourish and which has frozen 90 per cent of the schemes that are in existence. With this legislation, the government is saying, 'It is okay for the Prime Minister to make a fortune and have his entrepreneurial investments, but we will not give the workers any chance to get a look-in.' The government, through the modem Labor Party, may have betrayed the Australian workers, but there are other people in this House who are prepared to take up the cudgels on behalf of the Austhe legislation tralian people.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLL Y
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The legislation before the House is the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995. The coalition is strongly of the view that the proposals put forward by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in relation to employee share ownership schemes are fundamentally flawed, and this is the subject. I want to discuss in the House today. The concept of employee share ownership in terms of taxation support in this country goes back about 17 years. I think it is fair to say that, when the concept was initially developed, it had bipartisan support. Both government and opposition accepted the clear advantages which were to be found in having a mechanism by which people would be encouraged to make contributions through their income-normally by salary sacrifice type techniques-towards investing in the company which was employing them. The advantages underlying the concept of worker participation through share ownership c-an best be described as follows: they reward good performance and the attainment of specific business objectives; they give the recipients a positive incentive to increase their company's productivity and profitability; they increase industrial harmony; they help to create a greater awareness of the company's operations; they encourage greater employee identification with shareholder interests and with the company's interests; they assist in remunerating staff properly and in line with overall market conditions; they can keep the fixed component of wage costs at a lower level than would otherwise be the case; they are a motivational tool which is good for morale; they can inspire greater loyalty to the company; they can provide another form of saving for retirement and they can do so without restrictions applying to conventional superannuation; they are tax effective; and they can help to attract and retain key staff. This mechanism was developed initially in the United States which is regarded, somewhat euphemistically, as the home of capitalism. What we have seen in recent times-on three occasions in fact-are attempts by this Labor government to tinker with the system, not to improve it, not to make worker participation schemes through share ownership more attractive; but to fiddle around the edges, with the effect that we are firmly of the view that it will make this proposition less attractive than has been the case in the past. Putting it quite simply: the proposals put forward in this legislation are fundamentally flawed. The Treasurer's amendments will question and threaten the viability of current schemes and restrict the potential for the future expansion of employee share ownership in Australia. That is something which the opposition regards as fundamentally important in regard to not only the role it should be able to play in the overall need to increase national savings but also participation-that is the most important word of all-shared ownership, involvement or the ability of the workers of Australia, regardless of whether they are executives, white-collar workers or workers on the floor of the factory, to feel that the success the enterprise to which they make such a real contribution can be reflected not just in their salaries and wages but also in their being part owners of the enterprise to which they have made such a major commitment. This is the third attempt in the last 13 months by the government to deal with this issue. We regard it as a third failure. The essence of the problem seems to be that the government believes that there are new schemes in place which are rorting the system, which are an effective means of tax avoidance and which therefore should be closed off. These schemes have been referred to within the taxation and accounting industry as 'new age' schemes. We in the opposition will be the first to agree that, if there is evidence that people are using these mechanisms to avoid taxation in an illegal sense, they should then be stopped. For example, if there is a means by which people can nominally buy shares in a company or in a trust fund which, in effect, can then be used to buy them overseas trips, to buy them boats, to buy them smart sports cars or even to buy them homes or real estate, one could legitimately say that was a gross misuse of the principles underlined in the original legislation which allowed these schemes in the first place. Of course, we would oppose such propositions. What has been made clear in this whole debate is the inability of the government to specifically identify these problems and then go about changing the law in an effective way to stop them. Instead of that, it is effectively changing the system in a way that will radically transform the whole basis upon which decisions are made by companies-often outside Australia-as to whether or not they are willing to continue to provide worker share ownership schemes to the benefit of their employees. We believe that the government needs to encourage the distribution of shares right across the work force. We want employees to have the opportunity to have a stake in the businesses which employ them. That is really the basic difference between where we stand of on this issue and where the current Labor government stands. We want as many employees as possible to own shares through employee share schemes. Clearly, the Labor Party wants to discourage them from owning shares by introducing new and extremely unfavourable tax treatment. We believe that Australia must encourage and increase employee share ownership to address our critically low level of national savings, as well as being a mechanism for encouraging a further lift in productivity and improved harmony within the workplace. The level of worker participation schemes in Australia still remains far too low. Although the level of private share ownership has increased in recent years and is still increasing, it is still well below that of both the United States and the United Kingdom. Although the Treasurer has attempted to justify his proposals, he has failed over the last 13 months to quantify the extent of the tax minimisation or tax cheating problem which he claims is the basis of these changes. While he continues to do that, he cannot be surprised that the professional organisations, the employer organisations and the opposition will continue to be sceptical about his propositions. There are many aspects of the proposal which we find unacceptable. The proposal seeks to tax many employees before any benefits are realised. The five-year maximum deferral period will result in virtually all international share option plans attracting tax before the employee even acquires a share. This leaves employees with an unfunded tax liability well into the future. The qualifying conditions for obtaining the discount are far too tight. There is no refund of tax paid on options that may lapse. The valuation rules are complex and unrealistic, particularly for options. Most employee share schemes of foreign owned companies will be taxed upfront. The sad fact is simply that today Australia is a derivative economy. Today the vast majority of the work force involved in major companies are employed by international corporations which have in place overseas worker participation schemes which they want to make available to their employees in this country. Surely, that is in their interests. a mechanism by which we can ensure that, while companies may be foreign owned, at least Australians working for them will have the capacity to make a contribution and to gain dividends-from their labour and the result of the success of that company internationally. The opposition wants to see a situation where employees take a stake in the businesses where they work, where employees have a stake in the productivity of the business where they work and where, ultimately, they can see a share in the profits coming to them and to their families. It is very clear that as a nation we have one of the highest rates of home ownership in the world, some 74 per cent. It is equally very clear, as I have already stated, that Australians' share of capital ownership, particularlyon an individual basis, is well below where it should be in relation to other countries. Therefore, this is one of the major problems which have to be addressed if we are to have a nation which is less dependent on foreign capital; a nation where the employees can feel that they are part owners of the corporations and the companies they work for. One proposal put forward by the government is a $500 discount for employees taking shares. The facts are that most people will not even qualify for those shares because they have to take the shares in the year in which they were issued; they cannot see them as an advance which can be utilised later when they have the funds to pay for them; shares should have no conditions for forfeiture; you cannot dispose of them before five years of employment; and the discount is restricted to people who have been employed for 24 months, rather than 12 months as previously. There should be discounts for employees taking shares. They should be open to all employees and they should have the option of holding on to those shares and getting the discount at the same time. The second fundamental flaw in the government's approach is the proposal that taxation liability on shares or options at the end of five years will arise whether or not those options are exercised or you have those It is shares. That is patently absurd. If you have not exercised those options, you may find yourself having to pay a tax liability for something that you never take up. There is no prospect for a refund in the eventuality that you do not take them up or that the options have lapsed. What is also fundamentally flawed in this proposal is that many international companies which operate worldwide, as I have said, have employees around the world involved in share ownership plans and most of those international plans allow a 1O-year period before any tax liability falls due on the options. But that is not what has been offered. This legislation is limited to a five-year period. That means that Australian law, by changing the goalposts at this stage, is effectively cutting out of the action thousands of Australian employees who otherwise would have access to the international worker participation and share ownership plans of their foreign employers. There is simply no logic whatsoever in applying such a law. Any adverse effect upon employees of international companies posted in Australia will obviously arise out of the proposed legislation. The reason is that the legislation directly negates and inhibits the government's important and commendable objective, which I thought we always had, and certainly this government has made much noise about in recent times, that we want to attract to Australia international regional headquarters for operations in the Asia and Pacific region. The class of employee of an international corporation, through international practice for many years, has involved these-various forms of employee share acquisition schemes. If an officer on being posted to a headquarters in Australia is going to be directly discriminated against, clearly it will be a fundamental factor in determining whether or not the headquarters will be transferred to Australia. We welcome the removal of the FBT impost appearing in previous proposals-:..that is, the last three proposals of the government-nevertheless, the current proposals are clearly inadequate, mainly in the following areas: the conditions for qual-fication are too stringent and do not recognise a wide variety of employment practices and conditions; the five-year rule is too short and should be based on the period permitted under the law of the country of issue of the shares or rights, with a maximum period of, say, 10 years; the lack of an adjustment or refund where an option lapses or is unexercised is inequitable; and valuation rules are clearly unrealistic, because employee options are usually non-transferable and non-tradeable. Those factors have been totally ignored in the development of this particular concept. It would therefore appear that while most, if not all, of the concerns the government has announced in the context of the so-called new age schemes, and the clones which can develop from them, need to be resolved-and the opposition has made it very clear that it would consider any sensible proposals in that regard-it is perfectly obvious that what has been happening in this particular set of amendments will make the situation for many people who are within the law, and many companies which have been doing the right thing by their employees and applying principles and practices on an international basis, will be effectively cut out of the action in terms of the Austra1ian circumstance. I conclude by making the point that we in the opposition believe the worker participation schemes are important. They can be a mixed blessing if they are.not properly designed. But the practice of the last 17 years or so demonstrates that it can only be to the benefit of Australia and Australian employees and employers to have in place a rational, sensible scheme of proposals which lock in intern ationalpractice on the one hand and domestic practice on the other.. With regard to employee. schemes, whether you are the employee of an international corporation or whether you are the employee of a national corporation in Australia, the rules must remain consistent in both cases. Unfortunately, after 17 years of practice, after three attempts· to change the rules in recent times, the government has still, regrettably, failed to make it worthwhile. The point needs to be made that Vince FitzGerald, in his eminent report of last year on national savings, made the point that there is a potential to increase revenue by some $500 million a year under the old scheme, provided it is administered effectively. I see no advantage whatsoever to Australia, or to the employees who have previously been covered by these schemes, for the the government to now change the goalposts at a time when it is quite clear that the proposals it is putting forward are not going to achieve the ends it wishes, but will simply reduce revenue, reduce the capacity of companies to want to offer these schemes and share participation arrangements. Consequently, this will directly result in a diminution in the quantum of Australian ownership of foreign shares of companies that operate in this country and will do absolutely nothing to increase Australia: s capacity to be more independent in tenns of capital raising, both here and overseas.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: in reply-I would like to thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate on Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.2) today. I am told that there is only one point of contention that has arisen out of the debate, and that is on the employee share acquisition schemes. So I will say a few things about that, and maybe some more when the amendments are moved. I can say that, arising from the debate today, we see, once again, the opposition with absolutely no policies of its own.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Oh, George! These are policies that you can't steal from workers. We are opposing your legislation. That's our policy.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I do not expect the member for O'Connor to understand. Of course you are opposing it. That is all you ever do-but no policies. That is your policy exactly. The policy of members of the opposition is to oppose-in the words of the member for O'Connor-but not to put forward any positive proposals. They are not doing it today. Today they have put up some amendments which, in effect, would just maintain the status quo. We know that the status quo is highly tilted towards executives getting the benefits of the employee share' acquisition schemes provisions. The government wants to make sure that all employees get the benefits of these schemes. That "is why we have brought the amendments to the legislation in. It is well recognised throughout the industry that the existing legislation is being abused. If we accept the amendments of the opposition, that will continue .. Members of the opposition say, 'Trust us. Once we get into government' - and that is some way off-'we will do something about it.' In the meantime they are happy to see this abuse carryon .. We know that in a lot of public companies the main benefits of this scheme are going to the executives. I rule out the companies like th- BHPs: they do have schemes in place in which all employees can participate. It is not as if the government has not listened to some of the criticisms that are around the place. We made some changes to the provisions when they were here last year. We have made sure that FBT does not apply and that the tax will be paid by the individual but that the tax can be deferred for five years. Currently there is no requirement for the benefits to go to all employees- and mainly the executives get it. . I heard a couple of the opposition speakers talk as though the opposition stands for all employees getting the benefits of these shares. The practical effect of its amendments is exactly the opposite, and the opposition knows it from experience. It is not as though we are talking academically here. We know what is happening in the marketplace now. We are saying that these benefits should go to all employees. We have made sure that that happens. To accommodate some of the concerns there will be a five-year tax deferral. There is no limit on the amount, but it will be taxed after five years. On-e again we are seeing the opposition opposing for the sake of opposing, with no constructive policies. It is a. bit like the mystery flights that we hear about. In Perth now it is very fashionable to buy mystery airline tickets. When you go out to the airport you do not know whether you are going to Kalgoorlie or Sydney or Melbourne or anywhere. You tum up at the airport with your ticket and you could end up in any of those places. It is bit like that with opposition members. They are offering a ticket. You do not know where they are going. They do not know where they are going. It is apparent that they do not know where they are going because all they are doing is opposing. As the honourable member for O'Connor is honest enough to admit, it.is their policy to oppose, but not to put up constructive alternatives. The amendments I will be moving will make sure that .aU employees of a company get access to the benefit of the employee share acquisition scheme, which is something the opposition talks about but, as practice shows, fails to deliver on. . Question resolved in the affirmative. BiII read a second time. Consideration in Detail Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to. Schedule I.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I indicate that the coalition will not be opposing the amendments which have been moved by the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), but we will be opposing schedule 2 after it has been amended. The reason we will be opposing schedule 2, to reiterate our position, is that we believe the government's propositions and proposals are fundamentally flawed and that, in fact, rather than aiding employee share ownership in Australia, the provisions in this bill actually threaten the viability of current share schemes and restrict the potential for future expansion of employee share ownership in Australia. This is the third attempt by the government to deal with employee share ownership in 13 months, and it is its third failure. The justification for much of the changes contained in this bill, and even in the amendments which are now being moved by the Assistant Treasurer, is, firstly, that we want to bring employee share ownership to the availability of all employees in Australia and, secondly, that there are some rorts and abuses of the system. You would think that if it were the case that there are rorts and abuses of the system, the Assistant Treasurer and other members of the government would be able to come into this place and· signal, in chapter and verse, the rorts and the abuses that are alleged to be occurring. But when we ask them to do so, there is a deafening silence which crosses the length and breadth of this nation. All we get is this general assertion that it is known in the industry that there are some rorts and abuses. When the government is making changes to the taxation laws of this country based on the assertion that there are rorts and abuses of the system, it is incumbent upon it to set out what those particular rorts and abuses are, rather than make this general allegation, implying as it does that those persons and companies involved in employee share ownership are somehow rorting the system. The companies involved include some of the most major companies in Australia-the BHPs of Australia and· the Labor government's former icon, the Commonwealth Bank, which it is now selling off. Qantas is about to make offers of this nature in its share release prospectus to the general public and as part of its general transitional arrangements. There is simply no real evidence of what the government alleges. The reason we oppose this particular measure is that there are aspects of the proposal which are simply going to work against employees gaining, in any real sense, a share of the company in which they are employed. For example, the proposal seeks to tax many employees before any benefit is realised. The five-year maximum deferral period will result in virtually all international share option plans attracting tax before the employee acquires a share, leaving .employees with an unfunded tax liability. The qualifying conditions for obtaining the discount are too tight. There is no refund on tax paid on options that lapse. The valuation rules are complex and unrealistic, particularly for options. Finally, most employee share schemes of foreign owned companies will be taxed up front. Rather than aiding and abetting the many hundreds of thousands of workers in Australian industries and Australian businesses to do that which we on this side would seek-that is, have a share in the ownership of those businesses-this legislation will in fact have the opposite effect. It will restrict the ability of employees to obtain a real part of the ownership of the companies in which they work. I hear the Assistant Treasurer saying that we do not have policies. Of course, it piques the government at the present time that the policies of the government are somehow being challenged when flaws are shown to exist in them. What does the government expect? Does it expect that in relation to every piece of legislation, even though industry groups say it is flawed-that happened in relation to this piece of legislation-we are going to get up here and cheer and say, 'Bravo, this is a great piece of legislation?' Of course not. We are going to carry out our responsibilities to bring to the notice of the government and the people of Australia the flaws that exist in legislation, such as those that exist in this piece. As I said, the coalition will not be opposing the further amendments which are being made to the schedule, but we will oppose the schedule itself. Amendments agreed to. text: Menzies) (12.25 p.m.)by leave-I move: (2) Schedule 3, page 49, omit proposed paragraph 160ZZPIA(2)(d), substitute the following paragraph: "(d) the merger beginning is not before 1 July 1994;". (3) Schedule 3, page 50, omit proposed subsection 160ZZPIA(5), substitute the following subsection: "Meaning of qualifying superannuation fund '(5) The expression qualifying superannuation fund means a superannuation fund other than an eligible rollover fund within the meaning of section 242 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993.' ". Part of this bill gives rollover relief from accrued capital gains and losses where certain superannuation funds merge. The amendments allow the trustee of a transferor fund that merges on or after 1 July 1994 to roll over . any capital gains losses that would be realised as a result of the merger where a number of conditions apply. In particular, two of these conditions are of concern to the coalition. The first is that the merger take place between 1 July 1994 and 1 July 1997. The second is that the merging funds be qualifying superannuation funds. These two provisions relate to the amendments which have been circulated in the name of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). In particular, the first amendment deals with the timing of mergers. It is the belief of tht; coalition that the application of the rollover relief ought not be restricted simply to mergers which occur between 1 July 1994 and 1 July 1997. If this is an amendment to the legislation; which in principle is desirable-and that would seem to be the case because the government is moving this way-then why restrict it to mergers between funds that occur only between 1 July 1994 and 1 July 1997? Therefore, the amendment which has been moved seeks to make that time for merger open indefinitely. The second amendment which is being moved relates to the condition that the merging funds are qualifying superannuation funds. We seek to amehd the definition in the legislation because the effect of this bill fail to extend the relief which is provided to small superannuation funds. By specifically excluding superannuation funds with less than five members, the legislation neglects some of the funds which are most affected. Approximately 80 per cent of superannuation funds are excluded funds and are not eligible for the rollover relief which is. provided in this bill. Given that so many funds-about 80 per cent-are excluded by the provisions of this bill, our amendment seeks to allow those funds which have. five or less members to be included in the provisions that the government seeks to implement by way of this bill. They are the reasons that the amendments have been moved.

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: PAIRS
text: In relation to amendment No. 2, the proposal would give unlimited extension of the capital gains tax relief for merging superannuation funds. The capital gains tax relief is designed to encourage superannuation funds to merge so there are fewer and more efficient funds. The coalition agrees with us that this should happen. The government will not be supporting the amendment. I point out that no other unrelated taxpayers who merge their businesses get this relief. This measure is designed to reduce the small amounts problem by trying to encourage the merger of funds so there are fewer and more efficient funds. It is not equitable to extend this relief permanently. In the government's view, three years is long enough to allow these mergers, where they will take place, to take place. In relation to amendment 3, the issue here is to allow superannuation funds with less than five members-that is, the excluded superannuation funds-to get capital gains tax rollover relief. Once again, the government will not be supporting the amendment. The reason for our not supporting this amendment is that capital gains tax relief is designed to reduce, as I said, the small amounts problem, and funds with fewer than five members do not have this problem. So small funds have more control over administration and costs to their funds; the erosion of is to superannuation benefits by fees is now not a significant problem; and excluded funds do hot generally have members with small accrued benefits, such as transient members, et cetera. Amendments negatived. Schedule agreed to. Schedule 4.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: PAIRS
text: I move: (4) Schedule 4, page 62, item 10, omit "1 July 1993", substitute "1 July 1992". This amendment has been circulated to honourable members in the name of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello). The provisions of schedule 4 in the bill relate to local government councillors. The bill seeks to amend the definition of 'salary or wages' and 'employee, employer' in the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to ensure a number of thingsnamely, that persons in the capacity of a local government councillor are excluded from the definition of 'employee'; that members of an eligible local governing body are included in the definition of 'employee'; and payments made to local government councillors, other than those who are members of an eligible local governing body, are excluded from the definition of 'salary or wages'. The amendment seeks to ensure that payments received by local government councillors in the course of their duties are exempt from the scope of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act, but that payments to members of eligible local governing bodies will continue to be subject to the requirements of the superannuation guarantee legislation. Currently the remuneration allowances of members of local government bodies are exempt from the PAYE collection system, unless the body unanimously elects to be treated as an eligible local government body. This amendment applies to assessments of super guarantee shortfall for the year beginning on 1 July 1993 and later years. The government formally announced this measure on 26 June 1994 through the then Minister for Local Government, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who wrote to local government councils in July 1992 advising that, as far as local government elected members were concerned, the new superannuation arrangements would only apply to councillors in receipt of salaries. However, the amendments are only retrospective to 1 July 1993, whilst the superannuation guarantee levy commenced on 1 July 1992. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation recommended in June 1992 that the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 be amended by the government to ensure that local government councillors who receive salary or wages are covered by the superannuation guarantee while other local government councillors not be covered by the superannuation guarantee. We have criticised the application of the superannuation guarantee legislation to local government councillors and the failure of the government to enact legislation to give effect to the letter of the former Minister for Local Government. In September 1993 Senator Macdonald introduced a private member's bill, which passed through the Senate, with the same objectives as the current provisions but dating back to 1 July 1992. The effect of this amendment is to remove or omit the date '1 July 1993' and substitute for it '1 July 1992'. Given that that would then be consistent with the introduction of the superannuation guarantee, we believe that this is an amendment which would then clarify the situation completely and place the situation of local government councillors on a consistent footing with the date of the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy.

Speaker: Mr CONNOLLY
Title: PAIRS
text: The other very important issue which needs to be addressed in the context of this amendment is the effect which the government's rule is having not just on local government councillors but on doctors and other professional people who have been caught up in what could best be described as an unforeseen consequence. Let me give an example: if doctors have a private practice-and have consequently made private superannuation arrangements-and have also worked in a hospital, the effect of the current arrangement is that they are caught by what I call the 10 per cent rule. That is, if 10 per cent or more of their income is related specifically to the activities undertaken in a professional capacity in a hospital, it effectively means that their private superannuation is negatived because they are included in the superannuation guarantee arrangements. The effect that this has had on many doctors-especially anaesthetists and various specialised service providers-has been enormous. It is clearly inequitable. I hasten to add that it does not apply only to those people working under contract in a hospital. There is a perception that this applies only when a person actually has a contract to provide services in a hospital environment. I am reliably informed by representations which I have received that it affects an anaesthetist who is under contract to a surgeon to facilitate an operational procedure. The anaesthetist does not, therefore, have a legal relationship per se with the hospital but is also caught up in this situation. The implications of that are quite wide ranging. I certainly urge the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear), who is at the table, to review this matter. As we have suggested, to make the commencing date 1 July 1992 instead of 1 July 1993 would be a serious attempt to overcome what is becoming a serious anomaly. The 10 per cent rule as it currently applies affects a wider selection of people than just local government councillors. It covers a whole range of professional servicesespecially in the medical area-which are being provided. I suggest to the minister that this rule is having an effect which can only be described as an unforeseen circumstance. I think the government's actions are grotesquely unfair.

For that reason, we are moving these amendments to the legislation.

BANKING (QUEENSLAND INDUSTRY DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1995 Consideration resumed from 2 March. Second Reading

Speaker: Mr GEAR
Title: PAIRS
text: I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The purpose of this bill is to bring the Queensland Industry Development Corporation, QIDC, under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. QIDC is a financial institution which is wholly owned by the Queensland government and which undertakes commercial lending to primary, secondary and tertiary industry within the state of Queensland. While in recent years it has sought to adhere to Reserve Bank standards, QIDC has not been formally supervised by the Reserve Bank. The Queensland government has recently corporatised QIDC and as part of this exercise is seeking to enhance the accountability of QIDC by enabling it to be brought under Reserve Bank supervision. This bill amends the Banking Act 1959 to bring QIDC under Reserve Bank prudential supervision. To this end, the Queensland government has recently referred its banking powers, with respect to QIDC, to the Commonwealth. Specifically, this bill includes QIDC within the definition of a bank in section 5 Of the Banking Act 1959, thereby establishing a legislative basis for Reserve Bank supervision of QIDC. This will ensure that QIDC follows Reserve Bank requirements and is subject to the supervision of the Reserve Bank in relation to prudential matters. The Commonwealth government endorses Reserve Bank supervision of QIDC. As a substantial commercial lender, QIDC effectively operates as a business bank and its formal supervision by the Reserve Bank is entirely appropriate. Such supervision will help to ensure that QIDC remains financially sound and, accordingly, will help to underpin the security of the financial sector more generally. I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains a more detailed explanation of the provisions of the bill. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Mr ANDREWS
Title: PAIRS
text: Menzies) (12.50 p.m.)As the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) has indicated, this bill is before the House because the Queensland government has sought to enhance the accountability of the Queensland Industry Development Corporation by enabling it to be brought under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. That is being facilitated in the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill by listing the QIDC under the definition in section 5 of the Banking Act 1959. This establishes a legislative basis for the Reserve Bank supervision of the QIDC. The bill includes provisions complementary to Queensland legislation, under which the Queensland government transferred its constitutional banking power, as it relates specifically to the QIDC, to the Commonwealth government. The purpose of this measure is to ensure that QIDC follows the requirements of, and is subject to, the supervision of the Reserve Bank in relation to prudential matters. I indicate that the coalition does not oppose this legislation. However, there are two or three concerns which I wish to raise in the House. The first matter I wish to raise is the provision of prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank itself. If it is expected, or told to Queensland people, that this somehow provides a degree of insurance or immunity for the activities of the QIDC, then one only needs to look at the report of the Reserve Bank itself to illustrate that that is a limited immunity or a limited insurance which is provided. For example, the Reserve Bank stated in its annual report for the year ending 30 June 1991: Prudential supervision does not have as an objective the immunisation of banks from the risk of loss. The report went on to say: Managers and shareholders should factor the inevitability of the economic cycle into their decision-making, and they must pay the price for errors of judgment and carelessness. In his remarks to the Queensland parliament, the Queensland Treasurer, Mr De Lacy, pointed to Reserve Bank supervision as an insurance against loss by taxpayers. To suggest that somehow prudential supervision will, by itself, provide an insurance policy against any loss that could be incurred by the QIDC as a bank and an insurance against loss by Queensland taxpayers is somewhat misleading. One has only to look at what happened to banks in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia to see that the ultimate insurance for such activities is not the Reserve Bank through its prudential supervision but, in fact, the taxpayers, the constituents, of those states themselves. The second matter I wish to raise is the activities of the bank and what seemed to be suggested to the people of Queensland that the QIDC would be able to do. If honourable members look at the explanation of the Queensland QIDC bill, they will see that the Treasurer of Queensland, Mr De Lacy, told the Queensland parliament that the QIDC would not be able to call itself a bank because: ... it is not able to fully perform as a bank in that it cannot provide retail banking facilities or provide finance for what are essentially owner-occupied homes. He went on to say: Although QIDC would gain the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank, the State legislation precludes the Commonwealth of Australia from requiring QIDC to possess a banking authority to carry out the business of banking. The Queensland Treasurer summed up by saying: This option means that although QIDC is defined as a 'bank' under the Banking Act 1959that is, the Commonwealth actit is not authorised to operate as a bank in the wider sense because it does not have a banking authority. This bank, if one looks at the speech that has just been made by the Assistant Treasurer, is able to carry out a whole range of banking activities. I quote the Assistant Treasurer's remarks prior to mine in this chamber today: QIDC is a financial institution which is wholly owned by the Queensland government and which undertakes commercial lending to primary, secondary and tertiary industry within the state of Queensland. There is no restriction on the .activities of the QIDC and as a bank it can carry out a full range of banking functions. So for Mr De Lacy to indicate to the people of Queensland that somehow prudential supervision and the passage of this legislation and the complementary legislation in the Queensland parliament are going to restrict the activities of the QIDC is simply misleading. If one takes it further, the QIDC will, under the very provisions of this legislation, be able to entitle itself and call itself a bank in any other part of Australia. So anybody who would be seeking to invest or to have some operation in relation to the QIDC, for example a resident of New South Wales, Victoria or any of the other states, would for all intents and purposes and under the terms of this legislation be dealing with a bank constituted as such under the authority of this bill and the authority of the complementary bill in Queensland. It was somewhat misleading for the Treasurer of Queensland to suggest to the Queensland parliament and to the people of Queensland that this would in some way restrict the activities of the QIDC. In fact, the passage of this very legislation has the opposite effect: it gives the QIDC a wide range of banking authority under the Commonwealth and under the legislation of Queensland as well. The third matter I want to raise is what this means in terms of the direction of banking itself. It is interesting that in some respects this indicates that the Queensland government is moving in a direction which is opposite to that being taken by state governments elsewhere in Australia and, in relation to the proposal by the Commonwealth to sell its share in the Commonwealth Bank, opposite to that which the Commonwealth has taken. We see other states getting out of the business of banking. The Commonwealth is doing that in its budget proposals for the sale of the Commonwealth Bank. Yet under the direction of the Goss government it seems to be moving through this legislation in the opposite direction, namely, by expanding the operation of the QIDC and turning it into a more fully fledged bank than it has operated as at present. That is curious and intriguing because the Premier of Queensland has said in.parliament that he did not resile from the position that 'state governments should not be in the banking and insurance business' . Yet· in an indirect way this does involve the state government of Queensland in the banking and insurance business. Whilst there is nothing to suggest that the activities of the QIDC are anything but carried out in the most professional and most competent manner, it is a curious matter that we have a different direction being taken here in relation to banking by a state than has been taken by the other states in Australia after the disastrous occurrences with banks such as Tricontinental and others, and different from the direction which is being taken by the Commonwealth in relation to the Commonwealth Bank itself. Apart from those concerns, the opposition will not be opposing this bill.

Title: PAIRS

It is a very important institution for the economic welfare of Queensland and Queensland businesses.
