Title: PAIRS
text: I recognise that, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I am speaking about the position that the Queensland Liberals and the members of the Queensland National Party have taken in the state parliament on this complementary legislation that was carried in the state parliano ment. It is clear that under the Goss Labor government the QIDC is no longer going to be used as a political brown paper bag, which was the way it was used under the former National Party administration. Instead of being used as a slush fund for political favours for the rural and regional areas of certain National Party members, under the Goss Labor government the QIDC has now diversified its lending portfolio to include secondary and tertiary industries. The QIDC is now a much broader inVestment portfolio bank, which is designed to support the depth of Queensland industries, and not just narrow sectional interests. That is why we have this legislation before us today. QIDC is a development corporation designed to benefit all Queenslanders and to benefit all Queensland industries, not just the narrow sectional interests that the National Party represented. There is a very good example of that. Recently, on the border between my electorate and that of the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis), a national relay service was established to assist deaf people and people with communication difficulties. That service was established with assistance from the QIDC, which saw it as not only a sound business enterprise, because QIDC would be paid for the phone calls that it is providing the relay service for, but also a major community service. The service will also receive $21 million of Commonwealth funding over the next three years-joint funding from the Department of Communications and the Arts and the Department of Human Services and Health. It was the QIDC that gave that service a start, and that gave it the money to get under way. That national relay service is going to benefit deaf people and people with communication difficulties throughout Australia. It is funded by the QIDC. Such a loan would never have been possible under the former National Party administration because, to get any sort of money from the QIDC, it was then necessary to b- a member of the National Party or a mate of the National Party. That longer occurs because the QIDC is now on a sound financial footing. The QIDC still has a very strong rural focus. Its lending to rural producers has been increased from $250 million to more than $1,000 million in 1995. So the QIDC still has that very strong rural focus, but it has also diversified and broadened its interests into a lot of other areas as well. The reason the legislation is before the House today is that the Reserve Bank of Australia has the power, under the Banking Act 1959, to supervise the prudential standards applicable to this bank, as it does with all other banks. The honourable member for Menzies made some points in his address about the fact that by this legislation the QIDC can operate as a normal bank like every other bank registered under the charter. That is recognised, but it is not the intention of the government to go that way. The Queensland government has made it quite clear that it is not going to expand the role of the QIDC into a full state bank with all the normal operations a bank would have. That is a clear political statement that the Queensland government has made. It believes the benefits to the people of Queensland, by bringing the QIDC under Reserve Bank supervision, is very important. Such an arrangement ensures that all taxpayers in Queensland will know that this bank is adequately and very carefully being supervised, that its operations are open to full public scrutiny and that there will be none of the slush fund and corrupt actions that were the hallmark of the previous National Party administration of the QIDC. That is not just me the politician talking, for the track record of corruption and misuse of QIDC funds was clearly outlined in. an independent examination of the QIDC in 1990. The move to RBA supervision has not been done by stealth. It is not some sort of secret deal. It is being made clear at all times that the QIDC would become technically a bank for the purposes of prudential supervision, but the government has made it clear that there is no intention to expand into that role. What is relevant is that the QIDC is now a prudentially sound financial institution which is free of corruption and political interference and is now subject to rigorous independent supervision. The restructuring and the realignment of the QIDC is just one of many major achievements of the Goss Labor government which has a record second to none in Australia for financial management and prudent dealings with taxpayers' funds. The operation and supervision of the QIDC is just one example of the way in which the GossLabor government has been extremely careful to ensure that the state of Queensland is well run and well administered. There are many indicators to show, as independent market assessments from around the world have shown, that the Queensland state government and the Queensland financial situation is second to none. I will quote from the Natwest capital markets report of October 1994. The report was called 'State of the states' and it said: It would be hard to find a national or sub-national government anywhere in the world that has a superior financial position to Queensland. This unique financial position has enabled businesses throughout Queensland to have a huge competitive advantage. While the other states use, on average, $25 in every $100 of their own source revenue in servicing their $75 billion debt load, Queensland actually earns net interest income. We are net debt free in Queensland. Queensland has the lowest per capita tax collections of any state in Australia. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that in 199495 residents in other states were paying an average 37 per cent more in state taxes than the average paid by Queenslanders. Queensland is the only state to be net debt free. The Goss government has completely eliminated the net debt of $4.2 billion that was inherited from the previous National Party government. Let there be no excuses such as, 'That was all because of the sound policies of the previous National Party government.' When the Goss government was elected it had $4.2 billion of debt and now it is net debt free, and that is due to the sound administration of the Goss government. I commend the QIDC legislation to the House. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: PAIRS
text: I am very pleased to be able to contribute to the debate on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill. The QIDC, as we affectionately know it in Queensland, commenced operation in July 1986 under its new name. Prior to that it had a role as a development bank in Queensland. One of the great things about the QIDC is that it has always kept its base out there in rural Australia. As we have seen only recently, the major commercial banks are continuing to withdraw their presence in a physical sense from rural Australia, while the QIDC has been expanding its operations, particularly in rural Queensland. The QIDC offers very important banking services to the people of rural Australia. In future, the void that is being created by the withdrawal of the major commercial banks from rural Queensland may be filled by banks such as the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. The main functions of the Queensland Industry Development Corporation are the provision of financial services to Queensland industries. These include a broad range of products, such as development capital, interest rate swaps, bridging loans, mortgages, commercial bills and investment services. It is also responsible for the administration of Commonwealth and state business and rural assistance schemes. We all know of the situation out there in rural Australia, because of the high interest rates that are a legacy of the Labor administration here in Canberra. We know what those interest rates have meant to rural communities, not only to the farm sector but also to the small business sector right across this nation. Amongst the schemes that the QIDC administers are the rural adjustment scheme, the natural disaster assistance scheme, the rural housing scheme and the small business debtor scheme. It is a bank that has a major role in rural Australia and in rural communities generally. The QIDC is not only a bank which lends to the agricultural sector, as did the former Agricultural Bank of Queensland, it now lends to a broader cross-section of the community and administers many schemes, both state and federal. The purpose of this bill is to subject the QIDC, for the first time, to prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. These are the same standards which apply to banks, and relate to matters such as capital adequacy and prudential risk management of bank assets. This arrangement will be implemented by including the QIDC in the definition of a 'bank' under the Commonwealth's Banking Act. This bill is a stark reminder of the duplicity of the Goss government and why Queenslanders should not trust it with their future on July 15. On repeated occasions the Queensland Labor Party, both in and out of government, gave cast-iron guarantees that the traditional role of the QIDC would be respected, and that its prime purpose would be to promote the interests and development of Queensland. On repeated occasions the Premier has stated that the QIDC would not become a bank, with all the implications that this would carry for the bank's operations. Premier Goss gave these assurances as recently as last year, when introducing legislation complementary to that now before this House. He said that the QIDC would not become another bank. However, the net result of declaring the QIDC a bank under section 5 of the Commonwealth's Banking Act, will be to give it a complete range of banking powers. The Premier's assurances obviously amount to nothing. Whilst this breach of firm undertakings is bad enough, the consequences for Queensland of the corporation's change of status could well be diabolical. As a result of this legislation, this great Queensland institution will be subject to federal banking controls. The member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) was earlier referring to the corruption or the maladministration of the previous conservative administration in Queensland. He failed to tell the House that the Queensland government inherited a very well managed state. The finances were in excellent order, and the QIDC was a bank that was fulfilling a role. We only have to look at Labor administrations in Victoria and in South Australia to find that a bank under a Labor administration in Victoria cost the taxpayers $2 billion to bailout and in South Australia, notwithstanding the fact that it was under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank: The cost to the taxpayers was $2.2 billion. No such evidence of this sort of failure within a state controlled lending institution can be levelled at the former administration in Queensland. One can witness also the former administrations of Western Australia and Tasmania. The member for Moreton berates the House with points about a previous administration which left Queensland in a great position. The Queensland Industry Development Corporation was not broke; it was not costing the taxpayers any money. In fact, as the member for Moreton said, the rating of Queensland for its financial performance ranks second to none. The Goss administration inherited that position; it did no- build it. It is about time members on the other side of the House told the truth about where the great legacy that was handed to the Labor administration came from, something the people of Queensland know very well. We must also always remind members on the other side of the House that the Labor Party cannot be trusted to be in charge of money, particularly taxpayers' money. Examples which will illustrate the cronyism and downright disregard for taxpayers' funds that have hecome the hallmark of Labor in power include the $170 million of fees to outside consultants hired by its departments to tell the departments what to do. Only recently we have seen a $10 million consultancy go to the advertising agency which ran the Labor Party advertising campaign in the last federal election, a $10 million consultancy to identify the best way to sell and float Qantas. Eighty-six million dollars of taxpayers' money has been given to the ALP for escalating rent on Labor's Centenary House, which is now occupied by the National Audit Office.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: Order! I had to call on the last speaker to stay with the bill, and I repeat the request to the present speaker.

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: PAIRS
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I respect your ruling. I was merely going on from the failure of the State Bank in Victoria and the State Bank in South Australia to how the Labor Party misuses taxpayers' money when given control of it. However, I will come back to the bill before the House. The Queensland Industry Development Corporation, as I said earlier, has a proud past and I hope it has a proud future in developing the state. One of the great visionary projects which have been promoted by independent commentators and investors recently has been the building of the great inland rail bridge between Brisbane and Melbourne via the inland towns of Goondiwindi and Moree, through Narrabri and the heart of the Murray-Darling Basin. Such a bridge could well mean the further development of value adding industries where 50 per cent of Australia's agricultural production comes from. The QIDC could well play a role in the development of that visionary scheme, particularly through the provision of finance. Queensland and the port of Brisbane are so near to the great Murray-Darling basin river system where 50 per cent of Australia's agricultural production comes from. It is those sorts of projects which the QIDC and other development organisations could well look at as projects which would bring benefits not only to Queensland, to the people who live along that rail link, but also to the nation as a whole. The Queensland Industry Development Corporation will now take on the status of a bank and have a wider role in rural Queensland, perhaps taking over the role of some of the major banks. That is a role which I commend to the bank. I only hope that it keeps up a presence in rural Australia. Perhaps it will find a niche under its new charter to be more of a bank out there when the major commercial banks leave rural Australia. I hope that because it is going to become a bank with full prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank of Australia it does not go the way of our major commercial banks that are leaving rural Australia. I hope that it does not in tum, because of the decisions of economic rationalists that are made at a capital city level, withdraw its agencies from rural Queensland. It is vitally important that it consider a service to the community in rural Queensland as well as attempt to broaden its base into more development opportunities by lending in areas beyond the rural and small business sector. I hope that the economic rationalists are not in there saying that it is not commercially sound to have these branch structures throughout rural Queensland. I hope that we do not see the QIDC going down the same path as did many of our major commercial banks that have removed their physical presence from rural Queensland. Whilst it is their right to make those commercial judgments and withdraw their physical presence from rural Queensland, I think there is a role for government to ensure that there are banking services provided to the people who live in rural Australia. I want to touch on a comment made by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) in relation to the Commonwealth Bank and what its privatisation and sale could mean. In answer to a question from the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) the other day whether free banking services would still be available under a fully privatised Commonwealth Bank to almost 4.5 million pensioners, students and veterans, the Treasurer failed to give an assurance to this House and to those peoplethose 4.5 million people, those low income families who bank now with the Commonwealth Bank and those who may have a housing loan-that they will continue to have free banking services once it isa fully commercial bank and there is no longer any ownership by the Commonwealth. It is extremely important that we ensure that out there in rural Australia we still have banking facilities that are available not only to the business sector and the farm sector but also to people on low incomes-families, pensioners and veterans-so that they have access to banking services. It is one of the fundamental services that any community needs. It is not good enough to say that with modem technology you are going to be able to replace banks with plastic cards and electronic funds transfer and that this will be able to be a service that will be understood and be completely adequate for the people who live and work in rural and remote Queensland. In conclusion, I trust that the QIDC, with its changed status as a result of this bill, continue to develop and push its agencies and its branch level activities out into rural Queensland whilst at the same time it develops into a larger, more commercial bank in the activities of capital city lending and opportunities in the wider investment world.

Speaker: Mr DODD
Title: PAIRS
text: Leichhardt) (1.36 p.m.)Listening to the previous speaker and shadow minister, the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), speak on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995, you would think that there were no problems with the QIDC when the Labor government came into power in Queensland in 1989. Nothing could be further from the truth. The reality is that in 1989 the Goss government was faced with a real problem, in that the QIDC presented a great risk to the taxpayers of Queensland at that time. If the situation had been allowed to continue, as happened in other states, the Queensland taxpayers would have been required to pick up the tab for years of National Party mismanagement of the QIDC. The Goss government had to do something about that and in 1990 it got an independent academic, Mr John Polichronis, to undertake a report into the QIDC. The report that Mr Polichronis gave was damning of the previous National Party government and damning of its administration of the QIDC. It showed evidence of political interference in commercial matters under the National Party government. As well, it showed cases of commercial conflict of interest by the National Party appointed directors and staff of the board of the QIDC. It also gave evidence of lack of board leadership and abuse of schemes administered by the relevant division of the QIDC. We should not be surprised about that, given the record of that government. That was the government that would not even introduce a public accounts committee into the parliament of Queensland. It would not even have parliamentary scrutiny of any government institutions. That was the government, as was said earlier, that operated by the brown paper bag. If you wanted to become a knight, that required a financial transaction with the previous National Party government. If you will wanted a knighthood, you sent some money in a brown paper bag to Bjelke-Petersen House. That was the sort of financial transaction that was highlighted by the Fitzgerald royal commission. So that is the sort of government the people of Queensland had before 1989. That is the sort of government that was highlighted by the Fitzgerald royal commission and that is the sort of government  report on the QIDC. SO, far from the picture that was painted by the shadow minister, who is at the table, the QIDC was in a mess. Not only that; potentially it was in the same situation as those other unfortunate financial institutions in the southern states. But a Labor administration in Queensland saw the situation, picked up the report that I referred to and introduced reforms. One of the major reforms is before the House today, that is, bringing the QIDC under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. National Party members do not seem to like that. I can assure them they will not be in government after the middle of next month, but I suspect that they think they have a chance. They want to get their finger in the till again, so they do not want the QIDC to have prudential supervision by the Reserve BankMr Bruce Scott-That's rubbish.

Speaker: Mr DODD
Title: PAIRS
text: The honourable member says that is rubbish. It is certainly the situation that  Goss government acted to reform the QIDC. One of the reforms was the corporatisation of the QIDC. The second reform was to bring the QIDC under the prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank. There was an option of bringing the QIDC into the Queensland Office of Financial Supervision, but that institution looks more at smaller banks and building societies and it was considered more appropriate that the Reserve Bank be the supervisor. It is very significant to note that the Goss government has led the way in terms of national reform of building societies and credit unions. The national financial institutions scheme is the model scheme for other states and territories and the Australian Financial Institutions Commission has its headquarters in Brisbane. So there is no doubt that there has been significant recognition of the Queensland government's achievement in this area. Queensland is widely recognised as having the strongest financial position of all the Australian states and, indeed, its financial position is unrivalled amongst its competitors in the Asia-Pacific region. The Natwest capital market report, State of the states, in October 1994, said: It would be hard to find a national or sub-national government anywhere in the world that has a superior financial position to Queensland That is the true situation. Of course, this unique financial position has given business in Queensland a huge competitive advantage. While other states use on average $25 in every $100 of their own source revenue in servicing their $75 million debt load, Queensland actually earns net interest income. Queensland is the only state to be debt free. The combined debt of the other states and territories is about $75 billion. The Goss government has completely eliminated the debt of $4.2 billion inherited from the previous National Party government. Indeed, by June 1996, the Queensland government is expected to have net assets of $1.6 billion. So let us not hear any of the nonsense that has been bandied about here that somehow the Goss government does not have a good financial record in Queensland. Getting back to the QIDC, the QIDC has been substantially reformed in other areas. The government schemes that I previously referred to, the government schemes that were previously manipulated by the National Party government, have been removed from the QIDC and are now administered by the Queensland Rural AdjustmentAuthority. The QIDC is now run by an independent professional board-no more National Party cronies on the board. It is an independent board that is running the scheme very well. I would not want the House to think that, by changing its emphasis and transferring the government schemes to the administration of the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority, there is a neglect of the rural sector. I think there was some suggestion in the previous speaker's remarks that that was the case. The proof is I in the figures, because lending to rural producers from the QIDC increased from '$250 million in 1986 to over $1,000 million in 1995. Before this legislation could come into place, the Reserve Bank expected and got an audit of the QIDC. The Reserve Bank found that the systems of the QIDC were of the highest standard. One may compare that with the report which was brought down in 1990, which referred to cronyism and to conflict of interest, and see the vast difference between the administration under the Goss Labor government and that under the previous National Party government. This is not the only monitoring of the QIDC that takes place. The QIDC is monitored also by the government owned enterprise unit within Treasury. So there is a whole range of systems. There is now a public accounts committee in the Queensland parliament. Someone coming from any other parliament in the world would say, 'So what? We have had public accounts committees for 10 or 20 years,' but in Queensland it has come in only since 1989, when the Goss government came in. Yet these people claim that they can govern Queensland. These are the people that claim that they are ready to govern again. I think the Queensland people will have a very different message for them and a very different message for the Liberal and National Party government-or the National-Liberal government, I am sorry, because there will never be a Liberal government in Queensland. We know that a vote for the Liberals in Queensland is really a vote for the Nationals, and that is something that we will be very clearly telling the people of Queensland in the next two or three weeks. The Queensland government does have a very good economic record. The previous speaker was talking about economic development. In April this year the Goss government released From strength to strength, a comprehensive blueprint for the state's future economic development, which included public sector reform, micro-economic reform, tax concessions-$9 billion worth of fiscal infrastructure-programs for the development of education and training, research and development, and trade and investment initiatives. There has been some debate in the House about the Queensland government's economic performance in the social welfare area, in terms of social justice. Mr Bradford-What's that got to do with it?

Speaker: Mr DODD
Title: PAIRS
text: There has been a debate, and it is relevant because there has been a wide ranging debate here about the economic performance of Queensland. There are long term structural problems in relation to social infrastructure in Queensland. In 1989 Queensland was the lowest spending state in public housing and in 1989 Queensland had the lowest expenditure on education of any state. That was consistent through the 1970s and through the 1980s-totally consistent. The figures are there and these things do not change overnight. The opposition, in the parliament yesterday, was handing out a document that purported to suggest that poverty was worse in Queensland. The real danger signals that were given by that report were that Queensland would have been in a situation where Queensland taxpayers would have had to bailout the QIDC because of the stated mismanagement of having loans being determined by political cronyism and not by commercial considerations. In some ways, that is what happened in the southern states in relation to other institutions. It was not quite the same thing but, clearly, there were inappropriate loans in the southern states. The difference with Queensland is this: the people in Victoria and South Australia were overly generous with their loans, but there was never any suggestion that there was political interference in terms of who got the loans; and it is very clear indeed that the QIDC, pre-1989, was subject to political interference. That is why this legislation is before the House: if we are to avoid that sort of situation, we have got to have proper supervision. The Goss government, with obvious cooperation from the Keating government, has provided that supervision. I have no difficulty in supporting the legislation before the House.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: MCPherson) (1.53 p.m.) I see that my colleague the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) cannot wait to get going, but I am sure that he will have a chance in a moment. This is a timely debate on the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill because it coincides with the election campaign that is now under way in Queensland. In many respects, this particular debate also brings us, as has been noted on this side, to the important question of credibility as far as the Queensland Goss government is concerned. This may not be a major election issue up there, as I can think of a number of others; nevertheless, this is an important issue and it ought to be an election issue. A lot of Queenslanders, once they become completely aware of what the Queensland government is up to, will be a little unsure about what the government actually proposes to do. Earlier this year, the Queensland Treasurer assured the parliament of Queensland that the QIDC was not to become a bank. Clearly, he misled the parliament when he said that, and he has also misled the people of Queensland. He seems to think that this is a debate about semantics. I note that the Courier-Mail editorial of 9 May makes this point, when it states: But the Treasurer must expect to be closely scrutito nised on any agency within his brief that has large cheques to offer people with ideas. The Opposition was right to ask the question. A clear answer, without semantics, should be put on the public record. It has not been put on the public record. In a sense, the question is still unanswered, the concerns remain-and they are very real concerns as far as many other Queenslanders and I are concerned. When is a bank not a bank? By any definition, the QIDC will be a bank with the passing of the legislation that we are dealing with today. It will be registered under section 5 of the Banking Act. No amount of obfuscation by the Queensland Treasurer, no amount of quick sidestepping, can avoid that issue. It will be a bank. The fact that it will be a bank should be of concern to many Queenslanders because, clearly, governments do not run banks very well. In fact, what this amounts to is the people of Queensland signing a blank cheque for the Goss government, and many Queenslanders would want to think very carefully about whether or not they want to do that. Mr Katter-They had a good history in South Australia and Victoria.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: I am coming to that, which is the point of raising the whole issue. The member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) in his contribution to this debate earlier talked about the previous administration of the QIDC, and I am sure the member for Kennedy will want to talk about that. But the member for Moreton and none of his colleagues want to talk in any balanced way about the state banks of South Australia or Victoria. They really want to avoid those issues. I can understand why they do not want to get into that area because the performance of those state owned banks ought to be-and will be for a very long time-a great embarrassment to the Labor Party because the losses in those stat;'!s amounted to billions of dollars. Let us be quite clear that, when the QIDC was corporatised and went through that process, its debts were guaranteed and are guaranteed by the Queensland government. While it had limitations on its activities, those guarantees may not have been of great concern but, once it becomes a bank, they ought be of concern and that ought to be a worry to all Queenslanders. Let us just get back to what the extent of this problem was. The State Bank of South Australia has so far cost the taxpayers of that state $3,200 million-over $3 billion lost the State Bank of South Australia so far. fiasco in Victoria in banking cost the taxpayshingle ers of Victoria $2,000 million, over $2 billion. Now we have the Goss government going down the same track of getting banking business. Make no mistake: the QIDC is operating a high-risk area. It is essentially lending industry. It is not engaged in lending for home loans, which of course is the safe end of the lending spectrum, by and large. And Queenslanders might not be aware that, by virtue of this authority, it is authorised operate in the derivatives market. I do not Queensland. want to overstate that because, frankly, I am relieved from discussions I have had with the Governor of the Reserve Bank and others ties involved in the derivatives area that there is no real cause for concern about our banks' activities in respect of derivatives, which a genuine part of their operations. Of course, there may be a Nick Leeson hanging around there somewhere. I am not suggesting he would be but, as the Governor of the Reserve Bank told the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration on 20 April: You cannot legislate against incompetence dishonesty. The fact is that this bank, QIDC, will be operating in a high-risk area, as were the State Bank of South Australia and the State Bank of Victoria. Honourable members and should look at the losses they made. I am casting aspersions on the board of the QIDC at all. It happens to be a very well balanced and qualified board, but the point we are making is that there has been some obfuscabecoming tion by the Queensland Treasurer· about whether it was a bank of not. It is a bank and it is operating as a bank. It is guaranteed the Queensland government, and that ought be up-front. Why has the Treasurer of Queensland not admitted that this is the case? At least what he is doing in Queensland would then be in the open. If and when he does do that, Queenslanders should ask themselves: why does the Queensland government want to down that track when everywhere by proved to be a disaster? In fact, people are The heading back in the other direction. But the is up. The QIDC is opening branch offices in southern states. In those states it is seeking retail funds. It is competing in the into the retail sector for funds. That is another fundamental objection in Queenslanders ought to have: the QIDC is to competing with the private sector on less than a level playing field. It has, by virtue of its government guaranteed status, a position of preference as far as credit rating is concerned. That it is competing in the private sector is of to concern to me and should be of concern to We see with the Goss government's activiin this respect that it is no different from any of its relatives in the southern states. It is just a few years behind its southern and are western counterparts, who have all since been thrown out of office, as they might well have been, for their ineptitude and the fact that they cost, by virtue of their entrepreneurial activities, ratepayers in their respective states thousands of millions of dollars. The Treasurer. in Queensland is entitled to rely on the prudential supervision of the or Reserve Bank. That is the peg upon which he hangs his hat in respect of this issue. That might be some comfort, but in the end that is not what this issue is about. There was unofficial supervision of the state banks of Victoria South Australia, but that certainly did not not save them. We know-it is on the public record-the Reserve Bank was well aware of the potential dangers faced by those institutions months in advance of those dangers public. So prudential supervision is not in any sense a guarantee of performance. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank by admitted in a meeting of the committee of to which I am deputy chairman, we cannot legislate or guarantee against incompetence. This bank will be operating as a business and taking risks in the high-end risk spectrum of out the marketplace in Queensland. We hope it does well. It is performing well now, but it is venturing into a new and distinct area of go operation, and Queenslanders should be else it has warned about that. To date our objection and that of the state opposition in Queensland has been that the Treasurer has failed to come clean and tell the people of Queensland the fact about this matter: he wants to get into the banking business. Why does he want to get into the banking business? We are not quite sure about that, but he still manages to maintain his position that this is an argument about semantics-about whether or not it is a bank. The point is that it is a bank and he ought to come out and tell the people of Queensland that it is a bank. So far the Queensland government has had a very poor record for investment. I, frankly, do not trust it with a bank. As a Queenslander, I prefer the Queensland governmentor any (government when it comes down to it-not to be in the banking business. I certainly do not trust the Goss Labor government with a bank. The Goss Labor government invested $6 million in Compass Airlines. That was a brilliant investment! Most of us watching were quite aghast that a state government would want to get into that business at all, let alone so unadvisedly. It only had to look a little beyond its nose to realise what a high risk little venture that was. The government did its $6 million in a matter of hours. The money lasted hardly any time at all. The Indy car race is another example. So far the Queensland government has endured an accumulated loss of around $80 million. We are not quite sure of the extent of the loss because the government has not told us the entire story. It has cost the Goss government, therefore the taxpayers of Queensland, between $8 million and $15 million a year. We are told the race has an economic impact of $30 million a year. By that I assume the government is telling us that the race cost X amount but the government is getting a return. I happen to doubt the veracity of those figures. I am not casting aspersions so much on the accountants who prepared them but rather on the government that trotted them out as some justification for that particular investin ment. Those of us who live on the Gold Coast remain very sceptical. We are not sceptical of the event, except those in Surfers Paradise who are directly affected by the race either because of the noise or because of the effect it has on their businesses. More broadly, we are concerned about why the government should besubsidising it to the extent that it is. We also have some definite and understandable doubts as to whether the event is having that economic impact or how the economic impact is measured because it tends to be such an intangible thing. The plain fact of the matter is that governments are not good at picking winners. I doubt that we ought to have any confidence in the capacity of the Goss government to operate a bank. I say that governments are not good at picking winners, but Labor governments in particular are very bad when it comes to picking winners. In the end they spend other people's money, and sooner or later they fail. There could be no clearer example than this federal Labor government. It has irresponsibly punched this country headlong into an enormous debt burden that will not be repaid by our children or grandchildren. That is an example of how every Labor government in the history of this country, at both the state and federal level, has ultimately proved itself to be incapable of running the country's affairs on a responsible level. I believe this federal government is as culpable as any other has been. The people of Queensland need to be warned about what the Queensland government is doing in respect of the QIDC. I would like to congratulate Mrs Sheldon, the state shadow Treasurer, who has taken up this issue publicly on a number of occasions in both the parliament and other places. She has taken a stand on this issue on behalf of the people of Queensland. She has asked questions that should be answered and have not been answered. Perhaps in the course of the election campaign broader questions may arise about the future of Suncorp and the QIDC and whether fact they might be sold for the benefit of Queensland. The Premier himself said in the Queensland parliament not so long ago: State governments should not be in the banking and insurance business. Yet, despite those words, the Queensland government is rushing headlong down the track of getting into the banking business. No doubt there will be some opposition in the Queensland Labor Party to the sale of those particular instrumentalities but that is the way the rest of Australia is moving. Even here there is a move to sell the Commonwealth Bank, and for very good reasons too. We support that sale but we do not support what will be done with the money. It will be a misuse of the money that will be raised. In principle, governments do not need to be in the banking business. Even the federal Labor Party, for one reason or another, has come to that realisation. All the states except Queensland have certainly come to that realisation somewhat because they have had their fingers very badly burned. Apparently the Goss government has not learned any lessons at all from that and wants to get into the banking business. If the Queensland government were to sell Suncorp and the QIDC, I am sure the money raised from their sale could be put to very good use in Queensland. I could suggest a number of very worthwhile ventures in my electorate that could benefit from the money. We really need some money spent on roads. I will not get too far off the track here, but if I were allowed to I would have prepared a wish list of things that we could put those proceeds towards.

Speaker: Mr BRADFORD
Title: PAIRS
text: I know, and I am not going to tempt you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We want to make the point in this debate that the people of Queensland need to be warned. They need to be made aware of this fact because the Queensland government has failed to make them aware. The members of the Queensland opposition have attempted to do so, and we on this side of the House are helping them by making the people of Queensland aware that this should be an election issue. As I said at the outset, this not be a first order issue. There are a lot more important concerns relating to the credibility of the Goss government-law and order, health and some of the other disasters that have befallen the people of Queensland. The sale of Suncorp and QIDC ought to be an election issue because it gets to the very fundamental issues and credibility about what governments ought to be about. The people of Queensland need to understand that, in terms of the banking business, their government is going in the opposite direction to every other government. I believe that the Queensland Treasurer has been less than honest in his dealings with this matter. He should have come clean. He should have said, 'Yes, we're getting into the banking business and this is why we're doing it.' He has not done that. I believe the people of Queensland need to be well aware that, with the passage of this legislation today, we are giving the Queensland government a blank cheque with regard to the banking industry. The people of Queensland should be very worried about this in view of what has happened in other states.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: PAIRS
text: Capricornia) (2.11 p.m.)I am pleased to speak in support of the Banking (Queensland Industry Development Corporation) Amendment Bill 1995. This bill seeks to bring the Queensland Industry Development Corporation under the. prudential supervision of the Reserve Bank of Australia. I was interested to hear the member for MCPherson (Mr Bradford) talk about Compass. It is my understanding that his colleague the member for Fadden (Mr Jull) was most enthusiastic about the government putting taxpayers' money into Compass. As usual there is very little policy cohesion on the opposition side. We certainly should take a great deal of notice of what the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), who spoke earlier in this debate, has to say. I refer to the member's attempt at policy when he was the opposition spokesperson on regional and rural development. He stated: It is important when considering initiatives in the portfolio of Regional and Rural Developmentwill that is an issue that is most important in relation to the QIDCto distinguish between those which are essentially beneficial to the development of Australian regions and those which will win the Coalition seats in regional Australia He went on to say in relation to infrastructure investment: We need to set a figure ($1 billion, $3 billion-the actual number is insignificant) as an indication of our commitment to putting roads, dams, port, airports, bridges, whatever, into regional Australia. He further stated: A new roadlbridge etc is a proven electoral winner. That is what the member for Maranoa said when he was the opposition spokesperson on regional and rural development. How have those opposite moved on in the area of effective financial responsibility-an issue that they have made much of in this debate on the QIDC coming under the prudential supervision of RBA? The current spokesperson on this issue, Senator Macdonald, a Queensland senator, spends a lot of his time putting out press releases. He outlined his grand vision in this area to the shadow cabinet in Cairns recently. He stated: The policy indicates that prior to the election we would be announcing a list of long term visionary projects we would specifically like the Coun-il to investigate and prioritise, for example: DarwIn to Alice Railway, turning coastal waters inlandthat is always a good policy for the National Party in Central Queensland; it always wants to tum the rivers aroundrejuvenating the Murray-Darling Basin, Adelaide Airport. This gives us the flexibility of announcing a lot of major long term visionary matters but without committing ourselves to actually proceeding with them. That is the sort of economic responsibility we can expect from the federal opposition. Those opposite are now engaging in a political point scoring exercise by having a crack at the Queensland government. Politics is the game we are in and I have no problem with those on either side of the House getting into the political debate, but I think it shows the opposition's lack of policy when the best the member for MCPherson can say is that it wants the QIDC to be a bank. It is quite clear from the statements of the Queensland Treasurer that the government is trying to make sure that the financial status and independence of the QIDC are protected and that it has very high prudential standards. That is why it is entering into this technical arrangement as far as the QIDC is concerned. It is quite clear that what it is requesting of the Commonwealth government is that the QIDC be defined as a bank under section 5 of the Banking Act. That section requires it to be a bank in only a technical sense. The QIDC is not going to be competing with the private sector. It is interesting that those opposite are from the so-called party of competition but, when you suggest a bit of real competition, they say, 'We don't want that. We mustn't have a level playing field here.' The real intent of this legislation is to ensure that there is proper supervision of the QIDC. In doing this, the Queensland government is prepared to refer certain powers to the Commonwealth government. In addition to what the Reserve Bank of Australia will do, the Queensland government has in place very effective supervisory arrangements. As my colleagues the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) and the member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) have previously said, when the Goss government came to power in 1989 an independent report indicated that the QIDC's management had been very poor. There was political interference in commercial matters, cases of commercial conflict of interest with directors and staff, lack of board leadership, poor or no risk management systems in place, and instances of abuse of the schemes of assistance administered by the government schemes division of the QIDC. This effectively meant that the organisation of the QIDC was at very high risk of failure. That had to be turned around, as did a lot of major difficulties that were the legacy of years of Joh's management of Queensland. The corporatisation of the QIDC under the government's own Corporations Act ca-e into being on 1 October 1994. Its mam purpose was to ensure that the taxpayers of Queensland received the full benefits while at the same time being exposed to minimum risk. What we have ensured not only in the Queensland parliament but also here as part of this bill is that those statutory arrangements are effective. One of the important things that the government has done is to move community based facilities, such as the rural adjustment scheme, into an entirely separate organisation. I know this has been most important in the effective operation of the Rural Adjustment Authority and in getting Commonwealth government assistance to people who have been affected by drought. It also means that funds associated with the QIDC are now available to provide investment into core enterprise operations. Mr Katter-You reckon the drought doesn't exist.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: PAIRS
text: We have the member for Kennedy interjecting as usual. I was quite prepared to listen in silence to the member for MCPherson, but it is just too hard for the member for Kennedy to restrain himself. What we do not see from the member for Kennedy is restraint in any direction. After all, he was a member of the Bjelke-Petersen government. Therefore, he has a great deal of responsibility for the criticisms that those of us on this side of the House are making in this debate. As we have moved a number of the community service obligations out of the QIDC, we have a much more effective operation. However, that does not mean that we, with the QIDC, are moving away from supporting rural investment. If you look at the loan book of the QIDC, you see that as recently as 1992 rural sector loans made up 67 per cent of the total loan book. So the QIDC is still very heavily supporting rural and regional development. However, the reliance on a one-industry sector approach constitutes a major commercial risk. It has diminished over time. It has achieved a much more balanced portfolio. Currently, the rural sector represents about 50 per cent of the QIDC's loan book. That indicates a very proper management of development in Queensland. The one thing that is quite clear-I suspect we will not hear it from the member for Kennedy because I heard his contribution in a debate yesterday-is that, while beef and in particular coal mining are major industries for export not only for Queensland but for the country, the great challenge for Queensland is to diversify its industrial and manufacturing base and to bring on stream other competitive export enterprises. What we do know is that commodities are at the mercy of international trading cycles. It is very important to have an effective investment operation in Queensland to provide for that investment. I think the Queensland government has been very successful in the turnaround of the QIDC, giving it a much more effective financial position. That also means that it is part of the achievement of the Queensland government not only to become the only state that is net debt free but also by June 1996 to have expected net assets of $1.6 billion. We are not servicing debt in Queensland because of the prudent financial management of the Goss government, including the Treasurer, Mr de Lacy. My colleague the member for Leichhardt quoted the Natwest Capital Market's report State of the states. I think it is worth repeating. In October 1994, it reported: . . . it would be hard to find a national or subnational government anywhere in the world that has a superior financial position to Queensland ... That is not a bad financial reference. It means that not only are we not servicing debt in Queensland but also we have more money to spend on infrastructure and community services. This equates to there being $2 billion more now available to not only keep taxes down but also provide quality infrastructure and community services. A Queensland government report recently indicated massive infrastructure projects. I am particularly delighted to see that Central Queensland will be the recipient of those. This is going to mean investment into regional and rural areas of Queensland which will translate into jobs and support in areas where we need it. Mr Katter-What are those projects?

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: PAIRS
text: In my own area, Central Queensland, the government will be providing increased dam infrastructure which is vital, particularly to the coal industry and to the agricultural industry-issues that I would have thought the member for Kennedy would be interested in. Effectively, that is about $9 billion worth of proposals. Mr Katter-What are they?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: PAIRS
text: Mr Hollis)Order! The honourable member for Kennedy is listed to speak next. He will have his opportunity then.

Speaker: Ms HENZELL
Title: PAIRS
text: Effectively, this blueprint includes public sector reform, micro-economic reform, further tax concessions but $9 billion worth of infrastructure, programs for development of education and training, research and development, trade and investment. The problem with the National Party is that it can only think about dams and railways, but one of the most effective infrastructure developments is training and developing people skills, human resources, so they can make a contribution to the service sector, which is making a huge contribution to our export income. So we have $3.6 billion worth of capital expenditure already allocated in the budget. Infrastructure spending has increased enormously under the Goss Labor government. For instance, I will mention the family services portfolio. In 1989-90 the budget for the Department of Family Services and Aboriginal and Islander Affairs was $159.57 million. Today, in the current budget, it is $500.9 million. So there has been an increase not only in family services but in police, education and hospitals. We had to tum around years and years of neglect. What is happening to the QIDC's operations in Central Queensland? Just yesterday the official opening of the new premises in Emerald took place. At that opening the chairman stated that the loan book for the branch had gone past $100 million, which makes it one of the largest loan books of any branch of any financial institution in Queensland regional areas. There has been a necessity, both in Rockhampton and Emerald, to move to larger premises and put on more staff because of the development of business investment in those regions. This is also happening at the Mackay and Longreach branches. QIDC's economics department has just completed a study of the beef cattle industry, with particular reference to Central Queensland, to assist with trade and finance for the export of live cattle. This is one of the key issues in my region of Central Queensland and is very important to our economy. The Queensland government is effectively providing support for the cattle industry. That is all just too hard for members of the the National Party because they are still back in the bad old days of pork-barrelling and providing a bit of infrastructure here and there to win a few votes. Of course, at that time that was a lot easier because we had a gerrymander. The National Party could govern in its own right with 36 per cent of the vote. We have moved a long way from that period of corruption. This bill is about finalising arrangements that have already been put in place by the state government, having learned from the mistakes made in other states about the support of various state banks. The kind of furphy the member for MCPherson peddles is that state governments cannot be responsible in providing infrastructure investment. What is very clear from these arrangements is that the Reserve Bank will have very effective powers of supervision. The Queensland government itself has effective auditing requirements in place to make sure that not only will the QIDC work in the interests of investment in Queensland, but also taxpayers' money will be effectively looked after. In fact, it has already made a profit and will continue to make a profit and put money back into the Treasury for further infrastructure investment and for further services to the people of Queensland. The problem for the opposition in the state campaign is that they have not got any policies. They have no track record of financial management on which they can build. Therefore, we are having particular debates in this House along the lines of the ones the opposition is running on this bill and ran yesterday in the MPI on the poverty issue. The opposition can run those arguments and can put that case, but the track record of the Goss government is that of a very effective financial manager. What it is doing with the QIDC indicates its responsibility. Making the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority a separate organisation has meant effective Commonwealth support for primary producers in my electorate and in other parts of Queensland who are still suffering from drought. There is a lot of money available there. I am glad to see that the Queensland Rural Adjustment Authority is advertising the fact that it would like to talk to· primary producers who are in difficulty. This is about efficient, effective and responsible management of the state finances of Queensland, and indeed it is about the Commonwealth government taking an approer, priate role to provide a technical definition banking. The QIDC will still be an mechanism for the benefit of the people of Queensland.

Speaker: Mr KA TTER
Title: PAIRS
text: You have taken three minutes of my time. Let me talk about the Polichronis report on QIDC. The honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Dodd) was quite right in saying that I was very heavily involved. I was in fact the secretary of the review committee of QII)c. I read the Polichronis report and analysed it in great detail. I found it absolutely staggercent. ing that the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), the member for Leichhardt and the member for Capricornia stood in this place and said that the report referred'to corruption. There was not a single reference in the Polichronis report to corruption, from the first page to the last page. The report was highly technical and demonstrated classical economic rationalism throughout. Clearly the three members who quoted extensively from the report had no- read it. They had absolutely no idea what was in the Polichronis report. Polichronis recommended that QIDC stop being an agricultural bank or anything of that nature and be,come a: purely commercial bank. The reason he recommended this is that he believed QIDC should offer purely commercial interest rates, not preferential interest rates. At that stage, all of QIDC's loans to the public were at two per cent less than those being offered by commercial banks in Queensland. He was reflecting the attitudes, philosophy and self-interest of the other banks in Queensland. Our policy was completely opposite to that. In fact, Bill Gunn, the Deputy Premier of Queensland, and I served on the committee of review, and we said, 'In a commercial field, we can borrow the money at two per cent less than the banks; therefore, we can loan it out at two per cent less. We can choose our blue chip lendings.' Quite frankly, we thought that, if that was going to be to the detriment of the private banks, that was a criticism we would have to bear. I do not think anyone in Australia--even our harshest cri-ics-ever accused us of incoll).petence when it came to financial administration. Heaven only knows how we left the state in such good order, but we did it with our policy and philosophy. Polichronis threw that out completely. This is the staggering part of the report. Interest rates were 20 per cent at that time. Polichronis· advocated that we abolish all of the special loan funding arrangements via the QIDC special lending arrangements to people in trouble in small business or the farming sector. He said that that should be abolished and the interest rates should become 20 per He got his way, even though it was over the broken backs of tens of thousands of Queensland small businessmen on the land and in the cities. That is what happened as a result of the Polichronis report. I wish to heaven that the members who spoke before me knew something about the report or had read the report's foreword. They made mention of the fact that the Queensland government is in a very strong and sound financial way and its resources are in a marvellous way and, therefore, it should be a,llowed to run the bank in a right and proper manner. Previous speakers on our side pointed out the ALP's record in running state banks. The State Bank of Victoria fell over, with a loss of $3,000 million. The South Australian State Bank broke that record and fell over with a loss of $3,100 million. I would have thought it would be the last thing on the planet that an ALP government would want to become involved in. But that is what is happening here today. The Queensland government is going into the field of banking. If you looked at Rothwells as a state bank-if I could be facetious and say that Rothwells was a state bank-you would see that it fell over, with a loss of $1,000 million, as well. We come to whether these people are capable of running the financial administration of Queensland. Quite rightly, the speakers from the government side said yesterday that the poverty report in Queensland was a 1990 report. It was a 1990 report. It would be very unfair to blame the present Queensland government for that 1990 report. So what did I do? I got the figures out and upgraded the report to find out whether or not the government in Queensland was culpable. I suspected that things were going all right in Queensland and the figures would not be as bad as the ones in the report. The first statistics that I chose, naturally, were the figures for average weekly earnings. I found out that Queensland has by far and away the lowest average weekly earnings in the entire nation. In Queensland average weekly earnings are $496 a week, whereas for our. two neighbours, the Northern Territory and New South Wales, average weekly earnings are $593 a week-almost $100 more in the Northern Territory, and almost $70 a week more in New South Wales, with $567. The only other state that was low was South Australia, with $522, which is still miles ahead of Queensland on $496 average weekly earnings. Even more worrying for Queensland is that it is the only state in Australia where average weekly earnings have fallen since 1993. So if the situation was bad in 1990, it is now. Yet these are the people who are saying to us that they should be running a state bank. The previous speaker, the member for Capricornia, said that we on this side of the House do not take into account investment in people. That was the expression she used. It is very unfortunate that she used that expression because investment in people comes down to education, for example. In Queensland we have the lowest retention rate in Australia, with the exception of South Australia, for people between 15 and 24 years of age-which is the education age, if you like, We have the lowest TAFE participation rate in Australia. Those two things come under the auspices of the state government. In Queensland gross state product per head of mean population is the lowest in Australia, household disposable income is the lowest in Australia and its main income source is government benefits. We are the second highest in Australia there. Only South Australia has more people on the public purse in Australia. It pips us out there, but then Mr Bannon gave South Australia a great head start on us. I have already mentioned the mean total weekly earnings of all employees. So in every indicator that exists in Australian social trends, which one of the other ALP speakers was referring to as the social wage, Queensland is the worse in Australia bar two, and in both those cases we are slightly behind South Australia. In the other six we are well ahead of South Australia and are the worse in Australia. As far as the retention rates in schools go, everyone of the speakers has said, 'Queensland has had a massive increase in spending on education.' It has massively increased spending on education. Ms Crawford-Well, they had to.

Speaker: Mr BRAITHWAITEAITE
Title: PAIRS
text: That is right. If we go back to the start of the QIDC in Queensland, we see that the opposition supported its formation. It was obviously a transitional stage. It was formed out of the Rural Reconstruction Board, and it also took up the Agricultural Bank facilities. Let us not be embarrassed about what the Agricultural Bank and the QIDC were set up to do. They were set up so that higher risk loans could be made to the people on the land. Those loans were made for a purpose. They were made for .the development of the farming and grazing sectors of Queensland. The farming and grazing sectors still help out to a large extent the balance of trade. Advantages were also being given by the Commonwealth. The bank was set up to make sure the resources of Australia were strengthened. We have heard of the repayment of the debt that the Labor government has been able to effect over the last six years. I can recall that the day the Queensland Treasurer, Mr De Lacy, arrived on the treasury bench the headline in the Courier-Mail-not a friend of ours-was that the set of accounts handed over to the Labor government was the most competent of any legacy given to a Labor government in any state in Australia. That is on the record. It does not matter how much it is denied or how much that is corrupted by the government, that is a fact. Since I have referred to the repayment of the debt, I should say that the debt was created by providing resources through the Agricultural Bank and others to make the farming sector strong, provide us with powerhouses, railway electrification, mining ventures, roads, dams, weirs and water conservation. It is all those sorts of things that have made Queensland great. If we had a $4 billion dollar loan on that type of productive infrastructure, think in terms of what has happened since. We have a nil debt, apparently. But we do not have any major water conservation scheme. We have tolls being put on our roads. Our railways are to cease operating. Worst of all, we are now to buy power from New South Wales. We cannot produce enough power. Our resource is unemployed people. Our resource is a highly funded hospital system and education system and all the other systems catering to a lower degree of need or want than they were before. It seems strange to me that the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) comes in here to complain about these things when at the beginning of the year he was complaining about his own redistribution. If it looks as though things are not going his way he is the chief complainant. He said that Mr Longmans, the redistributor in Queensland, was biased and did not understand the principles of his act. So much for the member for Moreton. The QIDC was established initially to provide rural loans at reasonable risk rates and reasonable interest rates. When people criticise the board they must remember that the initial chairman, Graham Tucker, was a very competent person. He never saw eye to eye all the time with the Premier of the day but he was able to bring a degree of integrity to that bank which I believe has survived to this day. It is still providing a larger range activities to the industry of Queensland than it did before and certainly at a higher rate. This brings me to the point: what are the activities of the bank? I want to mention, in particular, its activities in connection with rural reconstruction. Rural reconstruction was the activity of the old Agricultural Bank right back in the early days. It is important to understand that the bank will continue to be the distributor of these funds. While I have a lot of respect for some people working within the rural reconstruction area and the rural adjustment area, I believe that the QIDC and the government of Queensland are profiting by the fact that this money is not getting out as readily as it should to those people in grave need. Part of my electorate is now going through the fifth year of drought. I can speak for a lot of the rest of Queensland that is not getting the funds required to help these rural people, experienced people on the land with a future in front of them. One aspect of the reconstruction where there seems to be a deficiency-and I have heard this right throughout Queensland-is that the amount of funds to reconstruct farmers off the land and give them a place in a town or somewhere are only available if arrangements are made with the rural reconstruction area of the QIDC before the event of reconstructing that debt with the major lenders. This has not always been the case. We have seen many people thrown off their property because of the lack of security, because of the high interest rates, with nothing to go to. Any application after that date is not a viable turnout. I did mention that the incorporation in 1986 of the QIDC was a move designed to assist, in particular, those people in rural Queensland. Since that time it has picked up many other aspects of help to industry, as the title suggests. In that period it has had a chequered history. There have been loan write-offs. We have heard the member for Kennedy say that in the time of the National Party government the write-off was the lowest of any of the banks throughout Australia. Since that time it has had massive write-offs of debt, particularlyon high risk ventures. I mention Compass of Airlines. I believe it lost on that. I am not sure whether it is putting money into the Indy participation on the Gold Coast, but obviously that is money that has gone too. So there has not been that same history of accountability, in spite of what the Labor government says. Perhaps the supervision to be given by the Reserve Bank will assist in some way in ensuring that that risk factor is not as high as before. But I say again: don't count on it too much because many banks in Australia have failed even with that supervision.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The eighth Accord comes after the successful seventh accord, which had an employment target of 500,000. We reached that target in two years and have now created $2 630,000 jobs since the time it was signed. This Accord shows that the Accord process of managing an economy-that is, not putting all the burden onto fiscal or monetary policy but having a third instrument such as wages-is the way that the Australian economy can best operated and run in the context of a set of cooperative agreements between the government, the work force and the trade union you'll movement of this country. I am happy to advise the House that the government has today agreed to and entered into its eighth accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions entitled Sustaining growth, low inflation and fairness. It states: This accord is based on and consistent with maintaining an underlying rate of inflation of 2 to 3 per that, cent on average over the cycle. talks about the prospect of creating 600,000 Jobs over the cycle of the agreement. It talks about the further extension of enterprise bargaining and the provision of an award safety net. It refers very specifically to the of putting a safety net under those a two people who cannot access the enterprise bargaining system. It states: Accord I?arties will support an approach to the to deliver three further annual adjustments to $12 per week available at the award level. For low paid workers, particularly those on award rates, this range will be $11 to $14 per week. This provides an element of redistributive support from the growth the economy is enjoying. It is that very great change to a flexible enterprise bargaining based system of industrial relations underpinned by the equity of a safety net, which is the quite revolutionary way in which Australia has changed from a centralised wage fixing system to a system that guarantees economic efficiency and equity-and it guarantees it with low inflation. Is it not a change to see the trade union movement of this country, under the Accord Mark VIII, committed to low inflation and sustaining economic growth? We should ponder for a moment the success of the accord. We had the original stabilisation of the economy in 1983 and its return to growth, the extension to superannuation and the productive and skills formation accords of the 1980s. Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: We have seen the change to the award system through award restructuring and a shift to productivity, the devolution of the wage system away from centralised wage fixing to an enterprise bargaining system, with the seventh accord, jobs being put first with employment and the 500,000 jobs target and, now with the eight accord, sustainable growth with low inflation and fairness and equity. This is the model for running an OECD country with higher rates of growth than would normally be able to be obtained with low inflation and high productivity. We have developed skills changes in the labour market, coming under the accord, through productivity, award restructuring and the education and training system. We have come to the point where we can run a growth economy and can have a naturally contestable market producing volumes of productivity naturally from the system while holding the inflation rate down. If you look at the production of a sustainable rate of economic growth with low inflation you would find that the government has engaged three policy instruments in the last 12 months: adjustments to monetary policy late last year, which were relatively small; adjustments to fiscal policy through a strong change to the budget balance, but one that protects the social wage through outlays; and, there is a lot of weight on the third instrument, the accord and wages. By spreading the weight over the three instruments and not over two we did not have to pull the monetary lever hard with a massive increase in interest rates and we did not have to cut government spending to pieces. We have seen the economy come back to 3.7 per cent economic growth and we have seen inflation remain at low levels. This accord says that we will have low inflation and good growth for the coming four-year period. Could you imagine the coalition being able to produce a document like this providing low inflation for four years? Could you imagine those opposite having the wit or the courage or the faith in the Australian working person to actually enter into a real discussion of principle and integrity with them and producing in parliament a detailed document of commitments to a two to three per cent rate of inflation in this country and at the same time the equity under the safety nets, the equity of those people who cannot access the enterprise bargaining system? We saw in this parliament last week the sort of quality that we have coming from the opposition. The regional infrastructure policy document from the Liberal Party says: This gives us the flexibility of announcing a lot of major long-term visionary matters but without committing ourselves to actually proceeding with them. This is deceitful, unprincipled policy.

Speaker: Mr MARTYN EVANS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and it also concerns Accord Mark VIII. Can the minister inform the House of the implications today's Accord agreement will have for employment growth? What will be the impact on the government's commitment to reduce unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. Indeed, Accord Mark VIII has very significant and important implications for the government achieving its job target of five per cent unemployment or better by the year 2000. The government has been committed to the Working Nation initiatives, prior to this Accord, for achieving that target. It is interesting to observe that· in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald Ross Gittins, having talked about the things that are important to get unemployment down and also paying due regard to the initiatives under Working Nation, said: So, if all these things come together ... we may come a lot closer to 5 per cent unemployment in 2000 than many people dare to hope. I think it is a very important recognition by a significant economics writer that these are policies that are working. Today, Accord Mark VIII is another one of those significant things coming together. What Accord Mark VIII does is commit the parties, and the trade union movement in particular, to working with the government to achieve a minimum 600,000 new jobs over the life of the agreement. Another important dimension of the Accord is the way in which it describes the significance of achieving that five per cent target. It says: So important is the jobs target to the social and economic well-being of Australia, that the union movement agrees that wage claims will be assessed against satisfactory progress being made on the employment goal. In other words, not only is it an Accord that is important for jobs growth and the jobs target, but it is an Accord that is important to sensible wage outcomes and to low inflation. This is an Accord that, in terms of its 600,000 jobs, builds on the commitment in the previous accord-Accord Mark VII and its commitment to 500,000 jobs over three years. As has already been noted, we have achieved in excess of 600,000 jobs in two years. The Prime Minister has indicated that we will not hear much from the opposition about the Accord in relation to wages and jobs, but let us just recall what the former opposition spokesman on industrial relations, now the Leader of the Opposition, had to say when Accord Mark VII was handed down. Back on 20 February 1993 he said: Accord mark 7 is, 'an insult to the intelligence'. Its target of 500,000 jobs over the next three years is 'unachievable' . He said that on 20.2.93. Further, he went on-seeing he was so buoyed up by the fact that this was not only unachievable but it was an insult to the intelligence to say: It insults the intelligence of the Australian people to suggest Accord Mark VII can help generate a half a million jobs.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Did you say that?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: None of the more than 600,000 people who have jobs feel insulted. Yours is the insult to the intelligence of the people by hiding your policies in terms of how you would produce job outcomes. But, in that same article, the Leader of the Opposition went on to say: We would not have an Accord approach. So here is a document that is producing jobs growth, producing low inflation, producing a wages policy that underpins that low inflation, commitment to superannuation and building the national savings of the country-and you would reject it. The simple fact of the matter is: these are people bereft of ideas. The reason they are bereft of ideas is that they have no talent sitting on that side of the parliament.
