Speaker: Mrs EASSON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. It also concerns Accord Mark VIII. What contribution will Accord Mark VIII make to maintaining fairness in Australia's industrial relations system? Will Accord Mark VIII ensure that those workers who need protection get it?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I am delighted to answer the honourable member's question about Accord Mark VIII, the Accord that is so much in keeping with the totality of our IR reforms, and, I might say, the Accord that continues the process of encouraging federal award employees into the enterprise bargaining stream. In doing so, at the same time we maintain fairness and at the same time we maintain employee protection, the very hallmarks of our policies. Already under the framework established by the Industrial Relations Reform Act, we have seen some 60 per cent of all federal award workers covered by enterprise bargains-a figure more than double that achieved by any state system. At the same time we have achieved high economic growth; we have achieved record jobs growth; and we have done so at a time of industrial harmony, low inflation and wages moderation. It has been a fantastic outcome. Accord Mark VIII released today will maintain that. It will do so while delivering responsible safety net wage increases to the low paid and to all employees unable to secure enterprise agreements. For the benefit of the House, I will just outline the five or six key elements of that Accord announced today: firstly, a strong emphasis on workplace bargaining underpinned by a comprehensive award safety net-the sort of award safety net that you would rip away; secondly, safety net adjustments from $9 to $14 to protect those unable to benefit from bargaining, particularly the low paid; thirdly, the maintenance of an effective and comprehensive award safety net-the award safety net those opposite would destroy-but also making it more understandable, user-friendly and relevant to the needs of enterprises and individual workplaces; fourthly, support for phased-in employee contributions to superannuation to coincide with safety net wage increases supplemented by employer and government contributions; and, finally, assistance to families and the encouragement of work practices that better balance work and family responsibilities. These are the key elements Accord Mark VIII. In combination, this Accord and the Industrial Relations Reform Act guarantee Australia's industrial harmony. They guarantee the continuity of the processes of decentralising our labour market, but they do so while maintaining all the vital protections required to give employees confidence as they move into the bargaining process. Together they deliver workplace change and productivity increases, but they ensure that employees get a fair share of the dividend. Whether through bargaining or through safety net adjustments, no-one under this system is left behind. The opposition can deliver no such promises at all. All it can promise is the end of industrial peace, the end of wage moderation and the end of worker protection. That is what its policies stand for. The anti-worker policies that have been advanced by the member for Flinders and the Leader of the Opposition can only return us to the industrial chaos, the high unemployment and the inflation that we saw from them in the early 1980s. This week the member for Flinders spoke about safety net adjustments, but there is never any detail about safety nets or any mechanism for how the coalition would adjust its existing policy. The coalition can guarantee only that workers will be worse offbecause, as the Prime Minister said today, it stands for the abolition of the no-disadvantage test. That is one of the great fundamentals underpinning our whole system. It is a fundamental that you would remove. The very cornerstone of your policy is to remove the no-disadvantage test and to replace the award system with four miserly minimums: four weeks annual leave, two weeks non-cumulative sick leave, 12 months unpaid maternity leave and a minimum hourly wage-not even a minimum weekly wage. That is all we get from the opposition. When it comes to workers' penalty rates, their leave loadings, their shift allowances, their overtime and their family leave-all these things are on the chopping block under the opposition's policies. No contrast could be of more stark: the opposition' s recipe for industrial mayhem and for wage slashing, and the proud accord we have released today. Real Household Disposable Income

Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is directed to the Treasurer. Has the Treasurer seen reports that Australia is heading for an 'economic apocalypse' and that 'severe corrective measures' are required? What is the Treasurer's response to these reports?

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Werriwa for his question because it does raise an interesting issue. I have seen these reports. They relate to comments made by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition yesterday following the release of the OECD half-yearly economic outlook. The sorts of things that he talked about, as the member for Werriwa said in his question, were 'an economic apocalypse occurring unless drastic action is taken'Mr CostelIo--No, no, no; quote it correctly.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: The Deputy Leader of the Opposition! Mr CostelIo--He should not misquote.

Speaker: Mr WILLIS
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: and 'they, the government, ought to be announcing some severe corrective measures which they will take to fix things up', and 'what is absolutely clear now is that the government has been running a fiscal policy which is too loose and the OECD has made that point'. The fact is that the OECD made no such point. What the OECD said in its half-yearly economic outlook was that the forecasts for Australia were very similar to those the government has. They were slightly different at the margin because it was talking about calendar years, not financial years. But with that minor difference they essentially endorsed our forecast. What they said was that we would have economic growth in 1995 of 3.8 per cent and in 1996 of 3.5 per cent-no sign of an economic apocalypse there. What needs to be clearly understood is that those rates are quite high by the standards of other countries. In 1995 that rate of 3.8 per cent is the fifth highest of all Western developed countries, that is, there are only four other countries with a higher rate of growth expected in 1995. For 1996 we are the fourth highest, that is, there are only three others with a higher rate of growth forecast. So, far from saying this country is facing an economic apocalypse, the forecast of the OECD is that this country is going to grow with the very top rates of growth in the OECD this year and next year. What about employment growth? The forecast by the OECD for this year, 1995, is 2.8 per cent employment growth and for 1996 2.6 per cent. Again, these are relatively very high rates of employment growth-the equal third highest rate of employment growth in the whole of the Western developed world in 1995 and in 1996 the third highest. No sign of economic apocalypse there. The OECD expects the continuance of very good outcomes with relatively high rates of economic and employment growth. What the deputy opposition leader said yesterday was based on the fact that we had a forecast for the current account deficit by the OECD in 1995 of six per cent. That reflects the six per cent figure that is in the budget for 1994-95. So there is nothing new in that figure; it is just endorsing the figure that we had in our budget. Like us, the OECD forecasts that that current account number is going to come down. They say that in 1996 it will be 5.3 per cent. They do not see it getting worse; they see it coming down with the breaking of the drought and reduced growth in imports. . The government cannot be accused of being complacent about the current account. We have taken very substantial steps in this budget, as everyone in this House knows, to address the need to reduce the current account. We have done that by reducing the public sector dissaving through moving to budget surpluses and by the very important additional development built up under the Accord process, which we have talked about a lot today, to develop the new superannuation initiative, which will be an enormous boost to household and national savings in years to come. What is the opposition's position in respect of both of these major steps towards reducing the current account deficit? In relation to the budget opposition members are desperately trying to prevent the corrective measures that the government has announced and is trying to put in place being put through the parliament. They are opposing $1'12 billion worth of tax increases this year and $2.6 billion worth next year. So whilst we have the Deputy Leader of the Opposition parading around saying that what this country needs is severe corrective measures he is doing his very best to stop the corrective measures in the budget from being put into place. What abundant hypocrisy! It does not stop at taxation, either. The opposition is also opposing expenditure cuts. We have already seen the opposition in this budget debate oppose the cuts in child care which limit the number of non-work related hours of child care to 12. They are saying that they will not support that; they are voting against that. That saves $150 million over the four year:s of the forward estimates. They are against expenditure cuts as well as increased taxes. So we have the broad 'Oh, yes. Let us have severe corrective measures. There is a terrible problem.' But when it comes to dealing with individual measures, which this government has responsibly put before this parliament, to reduce the pressure on interest rates and to reduce the current account deficit, they are opposing them one by one. That is incredible hypocrisy and shows how shallow this opposition is. The same goes for the superannuation initiatives. The opposition opposes them too. They are not in support of those initiatives to give a major boost to household and national savings. What we are seeing is an opposition opposing much of the measures that the government announced to ensure that the current account deficit is reduced and then calling for more severe corrective measures. The fact is that this economy needs the budget measures to be passed. The forecasts that are made by the OECD are a follow-on from its spelling out in that document of the budget measures-that is, in the broad, the move to surplus. On the basis of that it says this country will grow by almost four per cent in 1995, will be at the top level of the OECD and will have similar results on employment with those measures. If those opposite try to take away those measures, they are simply sabotaging our efforts to produce good economic outcomes in this country. That is what is being done. Doing that and at the same time saying this country needs more severe corrective measures is just an extraordinary amount of abundant hypocrisy and it shows how abysmally unsuitable the opposition is to govern this country. Telephone Services for Low Income Earners  Minister for Communications and the Arts; Can the minister advise the House about action being taken to improve access to home telephones for people on low incomes? Can he also advise the House about the outlook for other changes to telephone services?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: Given the alleged interest of the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Kooyong in the interests of low income earners, let us see what they have to say about the new service which the honourable member for Chifley was kind enough to ask me about. Last November I advised the House that Telecom would be trialling a new service to make it easier for low income earners to get a telephone on at home. It is the government's view that, with telephone carriers investing billions of dollars in cable and with telephone companies investing large sums of money in improving the mobile telephone service around the country, we think the least they can do is also make it easier for the one million Australians who do not have a phone on at home by bringing in this service as soon as possible. Yesterday the chief executive bf Telstra, Frank Blount, and I launched this new service, which is called InContact. It will allow households to receive calls and to ring the 000 emergency number. InContact will be provided with no rental, connection or service charges. However, where there is not an existing telephone line there will be a connection fee. But the good news is that, in the 20 of per cent of cases where Telecom estimates there will be a need for some cabling to be done, people will have that credited against the normal connection fee if customers subsequently upgrade to the standard telephone service. Mr Speaker, as you would know, this service has been trialled in Wollongong. The feedback suggests people who are looking for work find it easier because they can leave a contact number with prospective employers, and people believed they were safer and more secure knowing they could contact the emergency services number, especially those with young children and especially the elderly and retirees. Also, families and friends were more confident that they could ring to check people were safe, and children found it easier to ring their parents to let them know where they were or that they were safe. At the launch yesterday, Gwen George from the Older Women's Network made a point about how important the telephone service is for elderly Australians in particular. She gave examples of where people do not buy food because they know how important it is to maintain that telephone contact. We have had support from the Telecom Australia Consumer Council including the Smith Family and ACOSS, and The Pensioner and Superannuation Federation; who said that this is a great new initiative. There was one lone voice across the Commonwealth saying he was against this new service. It was the voice of the spokesman for the Liberal Party on communications, Senator Alston. text: Has the minister's attention been drawn to claims by the United Graziers Association of Queensland that students of farm families do not qualify for Austudy? Are these claims accurate?

Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Leichhardt for his question. I am aware that the United Graziers Association of Queensland has written to a number of provincial and rural newspapers on this matter. Its claim is that 'the government has consistently maintained that unless a farm is in exceptional circumstances, students from farm families do not qualify for Austudy'. This is untrue, but, worse than that, these allegations have the effect of deterring farming families with student dependents from applying for Austudy when they may be eligible. Austudy is a financial grant to help students from less well off families. It is income and assets tested. If a family operates a farm or a business in which the owner works for more than 17\12 hours a week-and we are not talking about Pitt Street farmers, obviouslyAustudy grants a generous discount on the business or farm assets. For Austudy purposes, only 50 per cent of the net worth of the farm assets is counted. Net means the value after subtracting any debt owed on the assets. A family can have a business, such as a farm, under these rules valued at around $750,000 net-that is, three-quarters of a million dollars-and still get Austudy. Mr Bruce Scott-But a Prime Minister can have a $2.5 million home.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

Speaker: Mr FREE
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I suspect that the member for Maranoa is an accomplice in this. It is a pity he will not be here to hear the rest of the answer. For farmers, the value of the home and curtilage of up to two hectares is also a us deductible item. The United Grazier Association refers in its letter to exceptional circumstances. What it is talking about are areas declared as drought affected special circumstances. In those areas no assets test applies at all. According to the latest ABARE statistics, the average net equity which the owner holds in broadacre farms in Australia, given over to mixtures of livestock and crops, is $663,630. That is below the Austudy assets test threshold, even without deducting the value of the house and the surrounding land. For wheat and for other crop farms the ABARE figures show the average net value of about $790,000, which is about $40,000 over the assets limit. But, when you deduct the value of the house and curtilage, again it comes below the threshold. For sheep and beef farms pretty much the same applies. The average equity is $790,000. For sheep properties the average net value is $707,000, which is again within the assets test. In other words, the average farming family is not disqualified under the Austudyassets test. Of the 208 farms valued by the Australian Valuation Office in New South Wales, Queensland and Western Australia for Austudy purposes in 1993-94, only 33 were over the limit in gross value. More than five farm families in six had no difficulty qualifyMayo! ing under the assets test. Apart from that, there is the drought assistance package which I mentioned which provides a safety net for those in special circumstances. The Australian Valuation Office will provide valuations where weather or market conditions have forced the value of a property down. I should point out that farming families can apply for Austudy at any time during the year if their assets fall below the threshold. I would ask all honourable members, particularly those members of the National Party, including the member for Maranoa, to disown the claims of the UGA. Telling farmers that they should not apply for assistance is quite wrong. Nuclear Testing in the Pacific

text: On 8 June, I wrote to President Chirac urging the continuation of France's moratorium on nuclear testingMr Downer-Table the letter.

Speaker: Mr KEATING
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I will table the letter if it suits me to table the letter. You don't get letters between governments. You lost the election. You came second, mate. On polling night, you came in second. As a consequence, the government met as a cabinet to consider the position in detail and I wrote to the President, as I say, on 8 June. The moment the announcement was made by President Chirac on 14 June I immediately issued a statement deploring the decision. Defence activities were frozen until the cessation of French testing, visits by French military aircraft or vessels, except those relating to humanitarian or surveillance activities which benefit South Pacific countries, were denied and the transits which, in any way, supported the testing program were forbidden. I foreshadowed contact with Pacific leaders. On the same day, the acting foreign minister, Senator MCMullan, called in the French ambassador and issued a formal protest. Our ambassador made similar protests in Paris. On 15 June, I issued a statement on behalf of my South Pacific colleagues condemning the French decision and announcing that a delegation from the forum would go immedi, ately to France. On 15 and 16 June, Australian representatives at the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva and the UN in New York took action to protest the French decision. On 19 June, I moved a motion in this House condemning the decision. On 20 June, Australian time, the foreign minister, acting as leader of the forum delegation, conveyed to French foreign minister de Charette the strong opposition of forum countries to the decision. On the same day, I sent an immediate report on the results of the delegation meeting to other forum heads of government and asked them to consider what further steps the region might take to reinforce our concern about the French decision. Senator Evans returned to Australia last night. He and I had a discussion upon his return. The government, as we have said all along, will now consider the report from Senator Evans and what further steps might be taken to register our opposition. We have begun receiving responses from our partners in the South Pacific. We look forward to their last replies and being in a position to announce some coordinated regional responses. I think that on those issues the government's position has been a very strong one. Let me say this also the government of France: the decision taken by the government of France is no deterrent against the greatest nuclear threats now facing Europe and the world-that is, the emergence of new nuclear weapon states, the rotting carcasses of old Soviet reactors in eastern Europe, stockpiles of degrading nuclear weapons and weapons systems and contaminated nuclear sites. It is worth reminding the House there are 21 Chernobyl type RBMK reactors, which are considered to have an inherent design fault, operating in Russia, Lithuania and the Ukraine. When I saw Prime Minister Balladur in France over a year or so ago, he said to me that one of the great concerns facing his government and Europe is the state of the 21 Chernobyl type reactors that are sitting in Russia, Lithuania and the Ukraine. We have seen already the damage that came from Chernobyl. Could you imagine if there were any further reactor failures of the kind we saw spread across 21 reactors which have to be, over time, replaced? If the government of France wants to worry about the protection of its people, it needs to worry about a nuclear cloud over Europe, threatening a civilisation of people, which can come in a very real way from the design fault and collapse of this reactor system in Russia, Lithuania and the Ukraine. Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PAPERS
text: I am out of horses. Whilst the Prime Minister's performance has its usual entertainment value, you would have to say that, in a way, it is a very sad reflection on the state of public debate in Australia. When you think about it, the history of economic management in recent years for a lot of Australians has been no laughing matter. It was again a classic, I thought, that the two principal operators for the labour movement in this country-the Prime Minister of a Labor government and the head of the ACTU-should appear on television to announce the latest political deal that they have done. The perception they were creating was one of Moses coming down from Mount Sinai with the word in tablets of stone. Yet I the reality is a very different one for many so late and little Australians. The truth is that the accord is not an instrugovment for constructive economic reform to that provide benefits to the average working but a political deal to foster the 13 political position of this government and to keep this government in office. It would be a thing if an accord were directed to genuine economic reforms but, sadly, after 12 years of this government that has not been the Let us look at the history of a few of the abuse accords. The accord arose out of Bob Hawke's win back in 1983 when Labor came into office. That accord saw the government on a spending spree, the like of which we had not seen since Whitlam. It led to massive demand pressures in the Australian economy the and, as has happened on so many occasions in Australian economic history, it basically blew out the current account deficit and led to the current Prime Minister announcing that Australia was on the path to a banana republic and to the economic policy of the following few years. That is not the only example of the accord I would remind the House of. The 1989 accord was a classic in itself. The 1989 accord included some significant tax increases. That fed into demand. Again, as h"as so often happened, that led to a blow-out of the current account deficit. Whilst promising as the government went into the 1990 election that we were going to have a soft landing, the government so jacked up interest rates that it brought on the worse recession in this country's history since the Great Depression of the 1930s. So much for the accord. All through this period we have had promises of better economic management but in reality a different picture. As the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello) said, as Australia attempts to go past a growth rate of about three per cent, we always, given the current structure of this economy, blow the current account deficit. In 1983, ours was the fifth worse in the OECD; in 1984, it was the fourth worse in the OECD; in 1985, it was the third worse in the OECD; by 1994, it was the worse in the OECD except for Mexico; and, in 1995, we finally get to the top of the tree-we are worse than all in the OECD, including Mexico. It is an interesting reflection to go back one of the few times the Prime Minister has ever really told the Australian public the truth about the Australian economy. It was on 14 May 1986 that he said that we were heading towards a banana republic. If we are to give those many hundreds of thousands of Australians who today are unemployed the real chance of a job as we go through to the year 2000, we will have to do a hell of a lot better than three per cent. Only last year the Prime Minister said that if you could not do four per cent then you ol!ght to get out of the business. When he is asked that question, he always fudges 3--e answer. People say to him, 'We are not at four per cent now. So are we not matching your own criteria for your continued stay as Prime Minister?' He says, 'Oh, well, we are near four per cent: we are 3.25; we are 3.75.' The fact is that we are nowhere near four per cent. We are moving away from four per cent. The prospect is not of more jobs in the future but of fewer jobs, particularly of full-time jobs. If you look not only at the current account deficit situation, you see that the underlying nub of this debate is whether or not Australia can achieve the gains in efficiency in the way in which we run our economy so that the average Australian family can enjoy a higher standard of living. If you look at labour productivity in Australia. I do not have the figures for the last two or three years-the labour productivity figures have picked up during the recession, which is a cyclical effect. But, if you take the figures from 1985 to 1991, the latest OECD figures which are availableMr Brereton interjecting

Speaker: Mr REITH
Title: PAPERS
text: I will come to that if you like, if time permits. Give me an extension of time, Minister, and I will give you a real burst and give you something to answer, instead of the usual rhetoric we have from you. Over that six-year period on only one occasion did Australia do better on labour productivity than our OECD trading partners. People should ask themselves: after 12 years of Labor, am I any better off? The answer is no. They are not better off because those opposite oppose the to sorts of changes that would make our economy a far more efficient place and that would give people real prospects for increases in the future. People should ask themselves: why it is that we have a poor productivity result? They do not have to take the opposition's view on this; they can take the latest OECD economic survey on Australia. The language the OECD uses is sort of Byzantine, polite, indirect and very often constrained, but its message on the labour market is crystal clear. The OECD report says that the industrial relations system still remains very complex and highly prescriptive. It says that our industrial relations reforms generated considerable confusion about the role of the commission and unions, and that, as a result, the negotiation of enterprise agreements is time consuming and costly. The OECD report says that it was questionable 'whether awards are best suited to perform a safety net function' and that the complexity of the safety net structure constrains 'the capacity of the labour force to adjust to change'. It is the change we want, Minister. You stand here and say you are moving us in the direction of that change, but the OECD report-it is very informative; only a short read, but well worth reading-notes that the government's rhetoric on enterprise bargaining goes back to 1987 and that even the changes made in 1988-89 were cumbersome, too complex and unable to achieve the productivity benefits that we need. So you have been talking about these things for years and years, but the Australian people have suffered as a result of your failure to get the productivity gains. The impact of the accord process on individuals again is not a happy picture. Real average weekly earnings, for example, have fallen by 0.4 per cent. If you look at the nature of our society-whether it is a fairer and a better place-you will see that the distribution of income, even allowing for the social wage, has become less equal. Basically, the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer under you. We have suffered the worse recession for 60 years. Our current account deficit, as I have mentioned, is now worse even than Mexico's and worse than those of the OECD. We have had record numbers of bankruptcies and small business failures. There are also the social implications, including the impact on Australian marriages and the impact on young people-the high suicide rates and the absolutely disgraceful high youth unemployment rate we have in this country. It is a disgrace, Minister. We have a society with all the riches and a good democracy, but 25 per cent of our young people cannot get a job. Why is that? It is because of the constraining, rigid, inflexible policy that you have. The accord process over the last 12 years has a very poor record at the economy level, the macro level and with its impact on individuals. I ask anybody listening to this: how have the accord and the government's economic policy affected you in the last 12 years? After the last 12 or 13 years of Labor, are you and your family better off? It is not a politically generated question. I think most people would say they are not better off. The truth is. that in that time a lot of people have lost their businesses and the opportunities they otherwise would have been provided. Then those opposite have the gall to front up, as they did to the Australian people, and attempt to be the incarnation of traditional Australian values. We had plausible Martin Ferguson saying he represents workers. He does not represent workers; he represents a minority of workers and, furthermore, the minority of workers he has are deserting him in droves. They are so desperate for members that one union in Sydney last year advertised discount strippers to attract more members. That is how low your union mates have gone. Instead of fronting up with Martin Ferguson, the Prime Minister would have presented a more accurate picture if he had turned up with his shadowy troika including George Campbell. He is the one with 100,000 scalps on his belt from the 1980-81 gross campaign they waged, which cost a lot of people their jobs. George Campbell is the bloke who knocked off Bruce Childs to come in here and be the Prime Minister's lackey in the upper house. The troika would include that bloke Coombs from the Maritime Union, the doyen of the aristocracy of the working class-the bloke whose members, generally speaking, earn three times what the average Australian earns and the bloke who has done more to retard, with your acquiescence, Minister, decent workplace reform on our waterfront. The last one I would throw in would be Bill Ludwig-your mate from Queensland-who is the man who provides the factional clout to keep Wayne Goss in power, and Keating and Brereton, with their numbers in Queensland. When you look behind these operators, he is the man, far from supporting the average battler, who is actually raiding the battlers in his own organisation because he has a request out to his own organisers that they surrender their long service leave entitlements-a pool of funds of about $3 million-to the union to pay for the mismanagement of the AWU by Bill Ludwig and people. So, far from representing decent Australian values, when you look behind some of the powerbrokers and the crude factional dealing and operations of some of these people, you see not Australian values but in fact the grubby, political, cynical· deal playing which is so much part and parcel of the way in which you people operate. The accord is a con. If people think they are going to get something out of the latest deal, the truth of the matter is, based on what has happened in the last 12 years, they will not get anything out of it. We would like to see people get real wage increases. Under us, of course, application could be made for a safety net increase. And we will genuinely look after those low paid workers who have had such a rough time under the Labor Party. Until we have real productivity gains in this country, the accord is a mirage. It is simply a deal, as you always do, with your union mates, with the union bosses-not to the advantage of Australian workers but to the disadvantage of Australian workers. You are not the champion of workers; you are the champion of low wage rights. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAPERS
text: Kingsford-Smith Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport) (4.53 p.m.)-What a welcome surprise. What an absolute little gift from the new shadow minister, the member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who has just returned to industrial relations. And what a day to do it on. What a wonderful day to contrast our industrial relations policies with theirs-on the very day that Accord Mark VIII has been released. I have looked over at the embarrassed faces behind the member for Flinders. You would really think the member would know better. You would have thought by now that he would have worded it better and that he would understand that this is the last day he calls on the debate the opposition can never win. What is even stranger is that he has called it on on the very day we have released the details of Accord Mark VIII, the very day we indicated to the House that we have tied up this wonderful package-a fantastic package-of expanded enterprise bargaining, of safety net increases, of industrial protection, of commitments to low inflation and of commitments to employment growth. Yet the member for Flinders has walked into the House and said, 'Oh, no, the Accord is not an instrument of constructive economic reform.' This is the Accord that gave us Medicare. This is the Accord that stabilised the economy. This is the Accord that repaired the social wage. This is the Accord that gave the Australian economy productivity, that gave us skill enhancement. This is the accord process that gave us worker superannuation. This is the last in the line of accords after the one that gave us the concept of the trade union movement committing itself to putting jobs first. The Accord is committed to low inflation at two per cent to three per cent, to high growth and to sharing the benefits of that in a way that is absolutely fair. Yet the honourable member comes in here and says that it is not an instrument for constructive economic reform. What does he come armed with? He comes armed with Jobsback, the document that has persistently been on the nose with the electorate, his IR policy, a document which earlier this week he tried to apply a bit of perfume to, it is fair to say, by talking about safety net rises. You try to deceive the public by pinching a little of the government's rhetoric and pretending that your safety net is a real safety net, as we provide under the Industrial Relations Reform Act. The fact is that there is no mechanism in Jobsback for any safety net rises and for the honourable member to change his leader's views. We all know his leader's views. Mr Reith-You are shadow boxing.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAPERS
text: I am not shadow boxing. I am indicating to the House the absolute paucity of your performance in coming in here and raising this matter of public importance in the House. At the last election the member for Flinders was trying to have the debate on the GST wrapped right around his neck. Now he has Jobsback. He has a document that has about as much credibility as the Hitler diaries. Jobsback was drafted by a man whose record is irrevocably tarnished by the wages blowout of the early 1980s. It is a rerun of the Victorian model that has led to the great exodus of workers from the Victorian IR system. More than half a million workers have flooded into the Commonwealth system, the national system. That has left its architect, Phil Gude, a national IR joke. That is Jobsback. That is what you will do to the whole of Australia-industrial relations Victorian style, the industrial relations that you champion. Having been given the job of arguing the policy, the honourable member has probably got a bit of a reason to be bitter. He has probably got every reason to be a bit bitter. This is not the choicest of jobs. Why does he keep bashing his head against the wall, arguing that Jobsback is some decent alternative to our policy? Jobsback is now in its fourth run. It has been rejected thrice already. Within the next 12 months it will be rejected for the fourth time. Whom does the honourable member think he is going to convince? How is he going to convince people that tearing away the award safety net is going to be good for them? What chance have you got? You have no chance at all. How does he think he can rationalise this while his leader is out there saying, 'I'm for the battler. I'm for the families,' when he wants to tear away the award system that is so central to protecting the very interests of families and so absolutely fundamental to protecting the interests of the battlers in the community? Yet the member for Flinders and his leader know that their policy would tear away penalty rates, shift rates, loadings, award based superannuation, family leave and a multitude of award conditions that battlers and families depend upon. Why is he bringing himself forward in this debate? Why does he do it today? The member is just playing into our hands. With the Accord and the success of the reform act behind us, all we have to do is point out to the people of Australia that the opposition's policy will only guarantee them those poor miserly, Dickensian conditions. That is all they will get. We all remember that the opposition was going to release its draft bill two days after the last federal election. Remember that? It was going to be ready beforehand, but then they said, No, it won't be ready, but we guaranteeMr Beyis-John Howard said that.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAPERS
text: That is right; the now Leader of the Opposition. The opposition guaranteed that it would release the draft bill two days after the last election. Have we seen it yet? Not on your Nellie. We are still waiting. All we have is four Dickensian conditions. Sure, there will be plenty of obfuscation and plenty of pinching of rhetoric, but no-one will be conned by that because we know those opposite hate the award system and the idea of a comprehensive safety net and they are revolted by the very concept of a compulsory application of a no disadvantage test-all the things that fundamentally underpin a Labor style IR system. The very conditions that workers won over the last century would be Mr Reith-They would be swept away! Decimated!

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAPERS
text: They would be swept away. Workers would be left with four Dickensian conditions. What sort of a policy is that for families? What sort of a policy is that for battlers? I will tell you what it is: a disastrous policy. We have told people this before. Every time we tell them, they believe us. All the surveys show, at a rate of five to one, that people believe we are better at handling IR-not those opposite. The conservative governments have at every tum helped us underline this very reality. There they are, the Victorian IR system and now the Western Australian IR system, like big beacons. People only have to read this morning's West Australian to see an editorial openly and very comprehensively criticise the model being pursued by Graham Kierath. The Western Australians are flat out going down the Victorian path. They are flat out being trailblazers for the policies of Jobsback. Mr Deputy Speaket:. you would have really thought they would have learned by now that while they have Howard they will have Jobsback and while they have Jobsback they will have one great big dud. No matter what Mr Representation over there, the member for Flinders, says, he will be able to put no decent light on Jobsback at all because it will get the thumbs down, as it has every time it has been tried out in the past. Yet he comes into the House and misrepresents the success of our system. The success has been outlined-seven accords now and the latest one done today. Success is guaranteed under Accord Mark VIII. Those opposite will not be able to deny the statistics, and nor will they be able to babble on about unfair dismissals. Both employers and unions have today very warmly welcomed the amendments that we announced yesterday. Opposition members will not be able to obfuscate any longer. They will have to produce their own policies. They will find them standing up very badly against ours, the achievements of the accord process and the benefits that will flow from Accord Mark VIII. Just look at the success we have achieved. It puts the very real lie to what has been said in the chamber today by the member for Flinders. Since 1991, 4,500 agreements have been completed, with 2,300 of them since the IR Reform Act came into effect. Mr Reith-How many have expired?

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAPERS
text: They have all been rolled over. Sixty per cent of all federal award employees are in the enterprise bargaining stream. How many do you have in Victoria? Three per cent, is it, in your discredited system? Seventy-five agreements have already been ratified in areas where no unions are available, the non-unions areas, to provide the benefits of representing employees. Look at the performance of inflation against the backdrop of the accord process and the Industrial Relations Reform Act. It is sitting on two per cent to three per cent at an advanced stage of the recovery, with economic growth of up to five per cent. Since the last election, 640,000 jobs have been created320,000 of them since the new IR act was put into place. We have an average wages growth of four per cent to five per cent for people under agreements. Inflation is down at two per cent to three per cent and we have four per cent to five per cent average wages growth as a result of the productivity that has flown from the enterprise bargaining process. Of course, there have also been three $8 safety net adjustments for those who have not been able to get agreements. Under this new Accord, there will be safety net adjustments of up to $14 for those who are least well off in the community. All of this was achieved under the accord process against the backdrop of the lowest level of industrial disputes for 50 years. This is an unparalleled success story. It is going to be mighty hard to rationalise those statistics with your allegation that we have in some way failed in the area of labour market reform. It is going to be even harder to rationalise it when your Jobsback policies have failed so dismally in so many of your own conservative states. It will be harder still with people who remember the wages breakouts, your miserable performance, the high inflation, the high unemployment and the industrial mayhem that you gave us in the early 1980s, particularly now when the man responsible is your leader today. The opposition will not be able to deny history or the statistics. It will not be able to convince people that Labor has failed them when they have enjoyed industrial stability, improvements in the social wage, low inflation and rapid employment growth for almost a decade. Whilst the opposition has Jobsback, you can bet your life on one thing: the public will not support it. The public knows, we know and you know that your policies are, and always have been, anti-worker. They are anti-worker policies from an anti-worker party led by two of Australia's most anti-worker politicians-the member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard); and the member for Higgins (Mr Costello). Mr Bevis-The member for Higgins has a big record in industrial relations.

Speaker: Mr BRERETON
Title: PAPERS
text: He has a huge record of being one of the most anti-worker politicians ever to sit in the House of Representatives of this country. We will keep reminding the electorate of this fact right up to polling day. Come polling day, the result will be the same as it has been for the last five elections. Once again, Jobsback will be one of the major reasons for that result. So please do us a favour: keep sticking to it. We think it is terrific. On every point we know that the facts favour the government. Those facts counter everything that the member for Flinders says, everything his leader says and everything ACCI says. We know we have the balance of policy right, and we know that our policies are working. Over the last 12 years we have got the results, and that is why people still support us. I repeat: every issues survey on IR shows very comprehensively that we have the results. You will not listen to the people in IR, you? You cannot listen to them. You are determined not to listen to them. You are determined to punish them on IR. No-one will believe your rhetoric about being pro-family or having pro-battler policies. No-one will care about whether it is opt in or opt out because it is still anti-worker Jobsback. We will be delighted if you go on with all the humbug you have trotted out today. But the facts, and the people of Australia, will support the current federal system-the one we are so proud of.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: PAPERS
text: Hinkler) (5.08 p.m.)Today's Accord Mark VIII is the eighth accord since 1983 and should be seen for what it is. It has more to do with providing the government with an election platform than improving the real conditions of ordinary workers. Today's statement is full of rhetoric, like the fatuous rhetoric we have just heard from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). But, like the previous accords, it will deliver very little to Australian workers. One has only to look over the government's record of the last 12 years to see how this is true. We have had the worse recession for 60 years. Let me stress to the minister that, during that recessional period, we had four of those eight accords. So they were not very successful and I doubt whether this eighth one will be any better. We had record bankruptcies among small business. We had unemployment rocket to one million people out of work-800,000 of whom are still out of work-the highest in the nation's history. Now we have a massive balance of payments crisis which, according to reports this week, puts us in the same league as Mexico. Is it any wonder that the workers themselves do not have any confidence in the government? Is it any wonder that the workers doubt the credibility of the ACTU? One has only to look at the dramatic fall in trade union membership for evidence of this loss of faith. ABS statistics between August 1988 and August 1994 show that trade union membership dropped seven per cent to 35 per cent of Australia's 6,5 million employees. Today's Accord Mark VIII agreement has will been framed with tomorrow morning's newspaper headlines in mind. But the hundreds of thousands of ordinary workers around the country will be saying tomorrow morning, 'Here we go again.' It is more smooth talk from Keating and Ferguson. The question they are asking is: what is it going to do for me? This is the sort of questionI get asked every day as I move around my electorate and talk to small business operators, shop keepers, factory employees, trades people and young people. I get asked: why can I not get a job; why am I not getting ahead; and why am I little better off than being on the dole? If they are in small business they ask: why is government taking more and more off me the harder I work? These questions are not being addressed by this government.  who is a public servant in my electorate. He is a very focused and hard working man with four teenage children. He is married and his wife does not work. Mr Hajenko's gross income is. $34,600 a year. One of his teenagers has reduced Austudy and another is on an unemployment benefit. After allowing for the basic family payment,' the home child-care allowance and deductions for superannuation, the family nets $1,146 per fortnight. If he had exactly the same family circumstances but was unemployed-and I am assuming $100 per week in casual employment-the family would earn $1,272 per fortnight. That is a difference of $126 per fortnight. Where is the equity? Where is the incentive for battling Australian families to get ahead? It is ironic that oli the day of this new Accord, in the local Bundaberg newspaper, the News Mail, Mr Hajenko's story has been told under the headline, 'Average working families ignored'. Mr Hajenko is quoted in that article as saying: I am just very concemed that the government honouring its commitments to the of the country and I was under a false impression that those who work get some reward for their labour. He obviously thinks they do not. It is obvious from true stories like this that workers concerned about their job security and dard of living, yet this government's coaster approach to economic policy served to create uncertainty and division in the workplace. I will now deal with the issue of unemployworking ment. Today's Accord claims to create proprietor, 600,000 new jobs by the end of the decade. Yet unemployment remains a critical issue regional Australia. I wintake you on a trip the Queensland coast. In my electorate of Hinkler in Central Queensland, one in every three teenagers looking for work cannot a job. That situation extends from the Sunlevel shine Coast to Ingham.' In the Wide Bayeconomy, Burnett region, the southern part of my regulations. electorate, the figure is closer to 40 per cent. The general unemployment rate, according to the DEET small area labour statistics, is 9.9 per cent in Gladstone, 10.5 per cent in Rockhampton and 12.4 per cent in Bundathat, berg. They are all well above the Queensland and national unemployment averages. The facts are that this government the answers and its inability to perform even permeates Working Nation-the government's closing big attack on unemployment-which is they clearly faltering. The statistical decline in long-term unemployment since Working Nation is largely a government inspired mirage. It has more to do with the government redefining 70,000 longof term unemployed as short-term unemployed after putting them through a labour' market program. In other words, if you keep them g()ing through labour market programs, you can say that they are no longer long-term unemployed. What a hopeless fraud. Comresponsibility mencements in jobstart, the government's most successful labour market program-l do not knock it, but those opposite boom it up with rhetoric-in the first six months of Working Nation collapsed to 30,000 fewer than in the same period the previous year. is not Commencements in other programs have also working families fallen well behind. The unemployment figures are further fudged by redefining certain groups of unemployed. For instance, the Department of Social Security figures now exclude those previously are unemployed people who receive the mature stanage allowance and the widows allowance. rollerLast month these redefined unemployed has represented a total of 46,000 people. Last week in some 48 hours I was confronted with three gut tearing cases of hardsmall business people-a nursery a stainless steel fabricator and a locksmith. The nursery, the Pennyroyal Herb in Farm, is a marvellous tourist attraction and up production nursery. It was a state finalist in the Queensland tourism awards and a finalist in the business executive of the year awards get in Queensland. This nursery has reached a of exasperation with the market, the raising finances and government All of this was heightened by the fatuous statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Brisbane on 11 May this year that 'this is as good as it ever gets' for small business and if they cannot hack it, they should 'get out'. The nursery proprietor in a letter to the Prime Minister-a copy of which she gave does not have me-asked rhetorically: Please tell me how to tell my 15 staff that we are down-if that is what you suggest and that should join the unemployed-as we will have to do. Mr Nehl-And Labor laughs.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: PAPERS
text: Yes. I am not a bit surprised that those opposite laugh about the fate these 15 employees in a provincial city. But we will see what happens to them in the upcoming state and federal elections. The other two small businesses have been through the ringer with the recent unfair dismissal actions. This is the area of the minister's on which he has been forced to back down ignominiously this week. One of these small businesses is also having trouble with inconsistencies between state and federal superannuation regulations. The other is having a horrendous paperwork war over sales tax, which has been exacerbated by the proposed 12 per cent sales tax on certain building materials. These are just three small businesses in my electorate that have come to my office in 48 hours. If you multiply that by 800,000 small businesses in Australia, who I remind this House are the nation's biggest employers, you have the formula for a disaster in a sector which could offer considerable hope for our unemployed. I would have liked to touch on a recent report on poverty in Queensland but time prevents me from doing so. It is an outrage that in Bundaberg, which is in my electorate of Hinkler, 46 per cent of all households are living on an income of less than $25,000 per annum. Mr Forrest-Shameful.

Speaker: Mr NEVILLE
Title: PAPERS
text: Indeed, it is shameful. One of the key provisions of today's accord agreement relates to the government's backdown this week on the unfair dismissal provisions of the current Industrial Relations Act. It was just three weeks ago in this House that the Minister for Industrial Relations defended these provisions. He said: The fact is that we have got the balance of policy right and our policies are working. Those policies are not working and neither will Accord Mark VIII.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: PAPERS
text: Werriwa) (5.18 p.m.)Every member of this House would know that the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has had some pretty low moments in his political career. You only need to go back to the night of the last election to understand how his baby, Fightback, blew the coalition right out of the water. He must have had that same sinking feeling this afternoon when, after having lodged this MPI at the Speaker's office before midday, he came to read the text of Accord Mark VIII, which has quality, reform and improvements written all over it. The blood must have drained right out of his face as it did on the night of the last election. What the member for Flinders and the opposition are saying through this matter of public importance is that they do not believe in cooperation with the Australian trade union movement, Australian workers and the Australian work force. They do not believe in the accord process which has created over 600,000 new jobs since March 1993. They do not believe in the target that has been established in accord mark 8 of another 600,000 new jobs over the next four years. Just as the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was wrong two years ago when he said that could not be achieved, the opposition is wrong again in 1995 in saying that the target set by the government and the ACTU will not be achieved. This MPI is proof positive of how the opposition does not believe in an accord process which can produce sustainable low inflation for Australia through cooperation with the trade union movement. The opposition does not believe in a process which provides an achievable target of underlying inflation in Australia of being between two and three per cent. This MPI is proof positive of how the member for Flinders and the opposition do not believe in a system which has lowered industrial disputes in Australia since 1983 by 66 per cent. They do not believe in a system which has the sophistication, the guile and wit to link industrial relations to rates of money wages in Australia, to the fabric of the social wage. They do not believe in a sophisticated safety net in Australia, how a government can put together a package of flexible industrial relations, skill development and training in Australia, employment growth and a strong social wage and do it in consultation and cooperation with the trade union movement. The proof is there again today. The union movement in Australia is leading the cheer squad for low inflation in a manner that could never be achieved by the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) or a coalition government. Quite simply, the trade union movement in Australia in 1995 has the sophistication, experience and good sense of national interest to know that there is no point pursuing aggressive money wage increases if that produces undesirable economic outcomes. The sophisticated model is to understand that dollar in the hand from the social wage is worth just as much as a dollar in the hand from the money wage. The union movement can cooperate with the government to coordinate those two aspects of economic policywage claims and the social wage. Dr Kemp-Battlers are not impressed by sophisticated models.

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: PAPERS
text: That happens in this country because of the purpose and unity of political and industrial labour. The member for Goldstein, with his jackboots on, might scoff but the truth is it can only happen in Australia under a Labor government through the purpose and unity of political and industrial labour. This MPI today is proof positive of how the coalition does not believe in an award safety net through cooperation with Australian trade unions and how it does not believe in enterprise bargaining and the growth of enterprise agreements through cooperation with workers. At the end of the day, the coalition does not like the accord. It hates the idea that it has been successfully renewed seven times, including today's historic Accord Mark VIII. At the end of the day, the coalition does not like trade unions. It does not like talking to trade unionists. It does not like consulting with Australian working people. It does not like the idea of the Australian work force having a legitimate say in the way in which this nation and its economy are managed. Only Labor has demonstrated the unity and purpose of political and industrial labour to put together a sophisticated economic and industrial model. This has beet! the historic transformation. The MPI seeks to talk about industrial relations reform. There has been a bucket load of it in the last decade. Only under Labor has the nation made the historic transformation-80 years of centralised industrial relations out of the court in Melbourne-to a flexible, workable, cooperative industrial relations environment. If it had been the Liberal Party and the National Party, spearheaded by the member for Goldstein, attempting that task over the last 10 years, what would have happened? We would have had the jackboots style of the a H.R. Nicholls Society. We would have had legislation drafted by the wordsmiths at the H.R. Nicholls Society with the member for Goldstein scribbling away. He would not be able to scribble the words down fast enough, as John Stone, Judith Sloan and the member for Higgins (Mr Costello) put the jackboots on and try to deregulate the Australian industrial relations system through confrontation and disputation. That would have been the inevitable result. There would not have been a single productivity improvement. We would have seen the closing down of Australian industry through confrontation and disputation-strike after strike after strike. Only under Labor have we seen 4,500 enterprise agreements formalised by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission60 per cent of federal award workers under an enterprise bargain. This applies not just for big business but also for small business-70 per cent of the agreements cover enterprises with fewer than 100 employees. The member for Goldstein asked about productivity. There is a bucket load of productivity out of these enterprise agreements because 75 per cent of them address specific productivity measures, with a positive flow-on impact for standards of living in this nation. The member for Goldstein should forget about all the neanderthals and jackboots at the H.R. Nicholls Society. He should just start writing down the notes of the Labor government. He should write down the sophisticated model for a smaIl trading nation. He should get his pen out and write it down-industrial relations flexibility in cooperation with the trade union movement, genuine enterprise bargain. Mr Cleary interjecting

Speaker: Mr LATHAM
Title: PAPERS
text: Mr 45 per cent wants to join the debate. We are talking about productivity. Mr 45 per cent, the member for Wills, has joined the debate. He is the sort of person who would drive productivity down. If we took him as the model worker, productivity in Australia would be halved. We would go back to the centralised industrial relations system in Melbourne with the member for Wills out there writing out productivity agreements for every workplace in the country-not 100 per cent under Labor, but 45 per cent. It would be half rates under the member for Wills. So he has no right whatsoever to be interjecting in this debate. He is the least distinguished worker in this place. In terms of the sophisticated model, I will round out the model for the extreme Left and the extreme Right. One thing about politics is that, if you come around far enough, you reach a point of consensus. The extreme Left and the extreme Right in the end agree with an authoritarian approach to public policythat is, bash people. That is the style from both the extreme Right and the extreme Left. The truth is that only Labor knows the middle way. Only Labor has the sophisticated model of IR flexibility, the genuine enterprise bargaining, the productivity focus, the low disputation and low strike rate around Australia and, in the end, low inflation and wage restraint because workers know the relationship between wages and productivity. It is not 45 per cent productivity with the member for Wills and that authoritarian, extreme Left, Albanian style of industrial relations. Instead, it is the sort of approach that produces gains in cooperation with the trade union movement and produces employment growth. There have been 600,000 new jobs since the last election. With the new accord comes the promise of another 600,000 jobs in the next four years. This is a beautiful, sophisticated model for a small, successful trading nation. It all adds up and the bottom line is higher standards of living. That is the point of the historic Accord Mark VIII. It shows that in the food chain of public policy it is an advanced species. While the Liberal Party and the member for Wills are still dragging their knuckles with an old authoritarian style of industrial relationsMr Cleary-Albania.

Speaker: Mr CLEARY
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Brian Howe's departure from the deputy prime ministership calls for some reflection on the nature of politics, particularly as his seat of Batman, adjoining my electorate of Wills, is now being targeted-as is my electorate and the electorate of Maribyrnong-by a trinity of retreating state Labor MLAs. Brian Howe's departure has opened the way for yet another state Labor MP to run up the white flag and lay down arms in the battle against Kennett. These are the same characters who run around the northern suburbs telling us how devastating life is becoming because of Kennett. All the while they deceive people about their own intentions and the complicity of the federal government in the privatisation, freeway-widening juggernaut that is consuming Victoria. I did not agree with the member for Batman's position on the Medicare surcharge, and I think he should have been a stronger critic of Kennett and the state ALP's freewaywidening agenda. Nevertheless, I acknowledge several of the initiatives which he has taken, particularly in urban policy and the needs of the inner city residents of Melbourne. The electorates of Wills and Batman-and indeed Maribyrnong-share distinctive qualities. All three electorates are situated in the northern suburbs of Melbourne-areas where free market policies of the kind that the Whippet from Werriwa endorses have destroyed manufacturing industry and created rising rates of unemployment. And hardly a person has taken up the Whippet's offer to fly to or ring Sydney to escape their own social reality. The Whippet's hero, Margaret Thatcher, had a simpler solution. She just told displaced workers to get on their bikes. The better cities program facilitated by Brian Howe goes some way to fostering a distinctive inner urban culture. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), by contrast, is more interested in his grand vision for waterfront Sydney, the restoration of 18th century Paris and the redesign of Berlin-all of which show that he is a cultural aficionado but none of which will enhance the lives of the battlers, which both sides of the parliament claim to be so concerned about. In the northern suburbs of Melbourne, the future of the material resources of the locality is open to question. Sydney Road, the spine of the suburbs of Brunswick and Coburg, has in the past been a vital and lively urban environment. Along the street are a number of heritage listed buildings, including the Presbyterian church in Sydney Road, Coburg; St Ambrose church and school; Cumberland Arms Hotel; Duke of Edinburgh Hotel; and the Mechanics Institute-all, excluding the first mentioned, of Sydney Road, Brunswick. Only a Francophile or a textbook architect would be oblivious to the grand Victorian streetscape of Brunswick. Around these buildings are rows of two-storey shops which locals claim make Sydney Road the longest shopping street in Australia. Many of these buildings still support a rich Brunswick Mechanics Institute, the Retreat Hotel and the Duke of Edinburgh Hotel, for example, are favourite places for regular music concerts, drawing on all of the rich multicultural traditions of these suburbs. I may not hear Mahler in Sydney Road but come the Brunswick Music Festival you will hear some of the best and most diverse traditional music in the world. It is buildings such as these in Sydney Road which need funds for recycling so that the whole street, rather than merely a handful of bUildings, can once again playa part in the community life of the northern suburbs. We need to extend the better cities program into new areas of social need in inner city areas, especially areas ravaged by the free market policies of the last 15 years. I know that this government has set up REDOs to promote local investment. These, I believe, are too broad in their geographical reach and so ALP driven that they cannot truly reflect the political and cultural aspirations of local communities. We do not want 'yes men' and 'yes women' on REDOs. We want people with independence and vision. While the opposition's recent briefing paper on regional development alludes to this problem, it is based on the assumption that regions do not exist in the city. Looking at the list of ALP candidates lined up to run for inner city seats in Melbourne at the next federal election, we have to wonder whether Brian Howe's vision is about to be passed on. Why do Bob Sercombe, Kelvin Thomson and Theo Theophanous want to run away from state parliament? Where do they really stand on the widening of the Tullamarine Freeway, the privatisation of public assets beyond the ones targeted by Kennett-the Commonwealth Bank, Telecom and Australia Postand the rejuvenation of the northern suburbs? It is a sad fact that the Brian Howes of the world are not being replaced in the parliament; they are being replaced by the likes of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham)devotees of free market policies. This is a bloke who wants to point the finger arrogantly at people and who really gets about one point out of 10 for substance and about 3Y2 cultural life. The points for gall. Brumer, Mr M.

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In the adjournment debate this evening, honourable members may be surprised that I will speak not on Jeffrey Kennett but on a constituent of mine, Mr Maurice Brumer. Maurice is a qualified second generation optometrist who has had continuous sole practice in Frankston for over 25 years. He is actively campaigning on behalf of children who, through no fault of their own, are condemned to a life of reading difficulties and early departure from the education system. Maurice has been punished for raising concerns about current standards of optometrical practice and the need to better incorporate findings of research into current modes of practice. In a paper entitled 'Optometry: light of a perverted science', he initiated a discussion on the issue of spectacles being a harmful drug when not prescribed properly. He canvassed a number of matters relating to prolonged and intensive near-seeing, which he believes is not good for our eyes and our health. He firmly stated that the public has a right to know how glasses may adversely affect good health. Maurice made the point that he did not think this would happen while the optometry profession put the public interest in second place to its own selfinterests. For his efforts, Maurice Brumer was expelled from the Victorian division of the Australian Optometrical Association, a first in history. He dared challenge the cabal that rules optometry in Victoria when he spoke out at a 1992 annual meeting of the Victoria AOA and the national AOA. An extensive body of theoretical and clinical evidence already exists to show the harmful effects of current optometrical practices. The analogy could be made to tobacco companies, where no amount of research and evidence will convince them of the health related problems of smoking and to the scandal it would be if they could successfully suppress such evidence. In the belief that the burden of proof lies with the profession to show that its current standards of practices are in the best interests of its patients, Maurice presented a paper before 400 optometrists. The only response since was for the Australian Optometrical Association to make him the first member ever expelled from the association. The Australian Optometrical Association rigidly enforces the code that the first obligation of the optometrist is to his professional colleagues. Maurice insists it is to his patients. Speaker: Mr SMYTH
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Mr Speaker, I have a question-in fact it is almost a riddle that my little girls would ask. It goes like this: what do the following all have in common-the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission now located in Sydney, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal now located in Brisbane, the Industry Commission now located in Melbourne, Australian Defence Industries now located in Sydney, the Australia Post national stamp collection now located in Melbourne and the CSIRO headquarters now located in Melbourne? They all used to be Public Service bodies located in Canberra, and it is this Labor government that has moved these bodies and staff out of Canberra. If the government had had its way, it would have done more. It would have moved the Maritime Safety Authority to Newcastle, but it backed down under intense pressure. It was the federal Labor government that voted for the Australian National Training Authority. to go to Brisbane rather than to the ACT. It was this government that suggested the transfer of the Australian Broadcasting Authority to Sydney. Yet it is this government, through Senator MCMullan, that is attempting to ridicule the coalition and wrongly and incorrectly say that the coalition will move departments and public servants out of the Australian Capital Territory, when it is those members opposite who have been doing the moving. They are hypocrites. There must be an election in the air! What is more, the Labor Party trots out the old chestnut that it is the coalition that slashes the Public Service. Let us look at the government's recent record. The front page of the Canberra Times on 11 May 1995 says 'Budget '95: The Aftermath: Many to be out of job, says Johns'. The government should come clean. When will it say how many jobs will be lost in the federal Public Service through its budget? What hypocrites and deceivers government members are. Let us look at some of the figures for last year. In 1993 there were 143,100 permanent public servants employed under the Public Service Act. A year later, in December 1994, there were only 132,500 left. If it is not the Labor Party slashing the Public Service, then who is it? Admittedly, some of those public servants moved across to the Australian Capital Territory health department, but it is about time Senator MCMullan came clean on what his party is doing to the Public Service instead of trotting out old lies and deceptions. Senator MCMullan said in a press release that I should stand up for Canberra. Perhaps he should have listened to my maiden speech. Perhaps he should practise what he preaches. I have written to the responsible minister, the foot-in-mouth member for Petrie (Mr Johns), and asked about his comment that large numbers of public servants would be out of a job after the 9 May budget. I am yet to get an answer. Perhaps Senator MCMullan, as a representative in Canberra, could hurry him up and get an answer for all Canberrans and all Australians about their Public Service. While he is at it, he might ask the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) when the promised Lake George upgrade will begin. Let us go a step further. What about the jewel in the crown of the government's cultural policy in the lead-up to the 1993 election? 'We will build a National Museum of Australia,' it said. Here we are in 1995, another election in the air, and do the people of Australia have a museum? No. Are the numbers of public servants who will be employed at the National Museum of Australia growing? No. Here is a promise, which has been made several times, that the coalition will fulfil: will build a National Museum of Australia at Yarramundi Reach here in the ACT and there will be public servants employed at it. Unlike the Labor Party, which is full of deceivers and tellers of half-truths who pull out chestnuts before every election just to bolster their own aims and to scare ordinary Australians, the coalition, when we are elected, will build the National Museum of Australia and we will staff it with public servants. It is about time the old myth that the Public Service and the Liberal Party have no affinity with each other is put to rest. I am proud to say that during the Canberra by-election-a by-election at which I must admit John Howard was more than welcome to attend, unlike the Prime Minister who will not be going to Queensland-John Howard made it abundantly clear that the Liberal Party has never been philosophically anti-Public Service. Indeed, we will have an effective and efficient Public Service-unlike under the Labor government-that will allow us to put in place our party's policies and to build a better Australia. Nuclear Testing in the Pacific Mr GmSON (Moreton) (5.41 p.m.)-Over the past few days there have been a lot of words said, both inside and outside this House, about the issue of resumption of nuclear testing by the French.· There have been a lot of words spoken by members of the opposition who have suddenly newly discovered this issue after having ignored it for some 20-odd years. I want to welcome the support of the opposition on this question. I am pleased to see that the opposition has discovered the fact that nuclear testing in the South Pacific is a risk to all the peoples who live in the South Pacific. I welcome the fact that the opposition has finally, after some 20 years, decided to support the peace movement in Australia in its continuous campaign against nuclear testing. I hope this means that the opposition will support motions in this place which condemn the development of nuclear weapons, in any country. I hope it means that the opposition will become a strong supporter of the peace we movement around Australia. I hope that, in the next couple of weeks when rallies are held in various capital cities around this country campaigning against the nuclear testing by the French, we will see opposition members at those rallies. It will be a new experience for them because they have never been to a peace rally in their lives. They do not even understand what a peace rally is. They have usually bagged the peace rallies and called them all sorts of names. But I am delighted that they have now joined the peace movement and that they are prepared to support end nuclear weapons throughout the world and to end nuclear testing in the South Pacifjoin ic. Mr Speaker, you will be aware that I have sent a petition to every member of the parliaAustralian ment - all members of the House of RepresenFrance tatives and of the Senate-because this issue is one that is above politics. This is an issue that affects all Australians. All Australian members of parliament should be nuclear behind the campaign to stop testing in South Pacific. I distributing it to every community group, sports club, senior citizens group and pensionsignatures er group in my electorate.
