A lot words have been spoken about what the national government should have done, who should sion. have said this and who should have said that; but what we are here to do is to represent the people of Australia. The people of Australia are outraged at this decision of the French government. It is something that we all condemn. We need to give the people of Australia a clear opportunity to voice their concerns. The petition I have distributed throughout this country is one way that the Australian people can have their voice heard. It is the only way and it is not by itself going to change the French government's know that, but I am optimistic enough to believe that, if the people of Australia can gather together a loud enough voice to tell the people of France that we do not like what they have done in deciding to resume testing and that we are opposed to the dangers and the risks that this will pose to the health not only of our people but of people throughout the South Pacific, then maybe they will start telling their government that they disagree the campaign to with that decision. This petition is one more way that we can together to add our voice to this campaign. It is a way that we can have millions of Australians supporting our government in campaign to end testing in the South Pacific. We need to gather the voice of all people and tell the people of that they need to tell their government I believe to stop testing. I hope that all members of parliament will distribute the petition entitled 'Stop French tests in the Pacific'. It is a petition to the the French ambassador to Australia, His Excellency Dominique Girard. I hope that all members will distribute the petition around their electorates, get lots of signatures and send it back to me by 10 July, so that I can am deliver to the French ambassador on Bastille Day, 14 July, hundreds of thousands of on behalf of the Australian people. Speaker: Mr WAKELIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: A couple in my electorate run a highly successful training and rehabilitation program for young Aboriginals who are trying to give up petrol sniffing. The young people are trained to be stockmen and stockwomen at a station in the remote north of Grey. Petrol sniffing is a major concern in the community. It kills; it not causes lifelong diseases; and, like most destructive addictions, it tears families apart decision. I and ruins young lives. DEET has supported this training and rehabilitation program for some time because of its success. Late last year, an officer of the Department of Human Services and Health met with the couple who run the program. The officer was impressed and suggested that, because the program dealt with petrol sniffers, perhaps funding applications should be directed to the Department of Human Services and Health; after all, petrol sniffing is a health issue and the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) had been telling all of us in this House that she wanted to include Aboriginal health in her portfolio. Given such encouragement, the couple running the stockman program wrote to the department in October 1994 asking for funding assistance. November and December ticked by without a response. It was the new year and still the minister had not responded to the funding application. The couple obtained letters of support from the South Australian minister and they also obtained a recommendation from the Catholic archbishop, but still no word from the minister. The couple learned that the minister was going to be in Adelaide. They asked to meet with her and-Io!-they finally received a letter from her. She wrote to inform them she was not available to meet them. When do you think these people, who work very hard and run this great program in the middle of Australia for young Aboriginal people who desperately need a new start in life, heard from the minister? The couple received a letter from the department's alcohol workplace unit on 11 May 1995. I suppose it was only seven months after the initial inquiry. You cannot complain about that, I guess. You are probably lucky to get a response from this minister at all. It was an enormous slap in the face when we look at the minister's rhetoric on Aboriginal health during her time in the federal parliament. In February this year during a debate on Aboriginal health the minister said: It is very important indeed ... that we do make progress in this area and I for one am determined to do so ... That is from Hansard of 28 February 1995. It is very important to make progress? She is determined to do so'? She cannot even answer a letter about Aboriginal health in the same year as she receiwd it. The minister also admitted in February this year that 'funds that we have applied in .-boriiinal affairs have not had the desired effect that we would all wish'. She went on to say: I want to point out that this serious matter requires cooperation: it requires bipartisan support. Minister, I think it requires you answering your correspondence. As for bipartisan support, the minister has received a wealth of it. The coalition supported the national Aboriginal health strategy, the Aboriginal education strategy and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, just to name a few. I am a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and have worked on the issues for many hours. My electorate takes in many traditional Aboriginal communities, including Pitjantjatjara lands and Maialinga-Tjarutja lands-in fact about 30 per cent of Grey is Aboriginal lands. The case I have just outlined shows that we have a health minister who cannot cope with Aboriginal health. Her treatment of this issue has been totally incompetent. She cannot even answer correspondence. I despair for the direction of Aboriginal health under this government. Timber and Dairy Industries

Speaker: Mr KNOTT
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I note that the last speaker, the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin). has worked for hours on Aboriginal health. My father has been working in that area since 1949 and so have a lot of other people. I think a few hours by the member. as opposed to what has been put in by our Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). leaves his comments where they need to be left. Mr Speaker. I wish to speak about something positive in my electorate. You will recall that I haw stood up in this House on a number of occasions and given the House and the parliament progress in the building. timber and forestry industries in mv area. It is a subject that many walk awa;.: from because they find the difficulties in the industry beyond their comprehension or because their ability to do something is limited. In my electorate. you wi 11 remember. I became involwd virtually the week after I was elected because there was a resource called water being pushed out into the ocean in ocean outfalls. In fact. there was a rather outrageous proposal being put forward by the local council, the Shoalhaven City Council, to try to propagate ocean outfalls. After a long time, and after a number of public debates with the mayor and others, it was resolved that, with the help of DEET, we would go through and have a look at ways employment might be generated by the use of that water. Surprise, surprise! The Shoalhaven City Council is now having problems allocating the water equitably among farmers. My dreams of it being used in the forestry industry will not come to fruition. That is not because of my lack of trying, but because more profitable uses for that water have come to the surface. In fact, there have been people who have contacted the council and said, 'If you drought-proof us, we will bring large amounts of money to your area and spend it.' I did not give up. Over the last two years, we have been looking at other ways we can go about it. True, the corporate structure I had envisaged, of the council, the landowner and the timber industry components putting in an effluent management scheme which had a capital component built in behind it, may not eventuate in the near future. However, there is a team from the government working in my electorate, headed by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall), Senator Faulkner and Senator Cook. Because of that team effort I am in a position where I have agreement, in principle, from a number of business people in the timber industry to form a holding company, which will aim to bring together production from some 30,000 hectares of plantations over the next few years. These people joining with the landowners will benefit the forestry industry, which was once the backbone of the industry along our section of the coast, Mr Speaker, stretching from your beautiful electorate of Cunningham down to the. electorate of the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). You would recall the red cedar from Kiama that adorns the Sydney Town Hall. That timber, the internals of Kiama, is spread out in those benches. Much of the timber from the Wollongong and Illawarra areas adorns Parliament House in Macquarie Street in Sydney. Many of us have looked at the industry. We have seen the cleared lands. We have seen that the agricultural use after clearing is not outstandingly successful in terms of profits and attractions of the area. However, the dairy industry is one of those industries which are an exception. It has brought great wealth to our area and has been the mainstay of our area for a large number of years. It will continue to be so, despite the efforts of some, such as my former aldermanic opponent, Neville Fredericks, to try to urbanise those areas. The dairy industry will survive because it is able to diversify. The timber industry offers the dairy industry a way of keeping its lifestyle and a way of keeping its land together, and, by doing that, a way of improving the agricultural output of the dairy industry and its own productive units. What I say to you, Mr Speaker, is that with continued prescience in this place I believe we can achieve goals. Agribusiness will develop in a big way in our area. As you understand, Mr Speaker, coming from the region, we are taking it very seriously. We will provide, where the National Party and the Liberal Party have not, not just rhetoric but results. Speaker: Mr RONALDSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Ballarat) (5.54 p.m.)I wish to bring to the attention of the House a situation that I find quite extraordinary and a matter that must be addressed by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) as a matter of urgency. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee has made a decision that pethidine for long-term use is no longer available under the national health scheme and, despite the matter being reviewed some two weeks ago, the decision has been confirmed. The PBAC has displayed what I would consider to be a mixture of gross ignorance and unsubstantiated assumption that cannot in any way be condoned by the Australian community or many of Australia's doctors. By way of background: this situation came to my attention via a local constituent and her doctor. If the opportunity presents itself I will read the letter from the doctor which clearly sets out the position and shows the advisory committee's total lack of compassion. It seems extraordinary to both me and my patient's treating doctor that he can prescribe morphine or methadone for long-term use and this apparently is condoned by the PBAC as acceptable, but not so for pethidine. There is absolutely no reason why pethidine should be treated any differently, and I find it absolutely galling that the committee can make a unilateral decision without having any awareness of the likely impact of that decision on the individual patient. The simple fact is that my constituent has undergone specialist examination, has attended pain clinics and has done everything that would reasonably be expected of someone in her position suffering from chronic pain. It is about time that the committee accepted that there will be people severely affected"by its decision. What is equally galling is that the basis for the committee's decision is that it believes the use of pethidine long. term is 'inappropriate treatment'. As far as my constituent and her doctor are concerned, the treatment by way of long-term pethidine prescription is totally appropriate treatment and I fail to see how the committee can make such a widespread value judgment without in any way taking into account individual circumstances. The other galling aspect is that, relative to other drugs, pethidine is extremely cheap and, therefore, there can be no financial reason for the advisory committee's decision. I am angry about this decision. My constituent and her doctor are angry about this decision. I understand that many doctors throughout Australia are angered by this deCision. If, as I believe may be the situation, the committee has made this decision on the views of one member of the committee, can I respectfully suggest that all committee members take a long, hard look at that advice. Prior to reading out that letter from my constituent's treating doctor, I would like to make a final comment, and that is: how dare the advisory committee presume to know more about a patient's appropriate treatment than the patient's treating doctor. The letter from my constituent's treating doctor reads: This pleasant woman suffers chronic pain due to having developed an arachnoiditis, i.e. Iflflarnmation surrounding the spinal cord. There is no cure and essentially she will probably become paralysed. Unfortunately she has lit very low tolerance to opiates, i.e. morphine and methadone. These cause her severe nausea. The one drug that did assist her was pethidine in injectable form and used once daily in combination with other therapeutic agents. Unfortunately pethidine (injectable) is no longer available for long term use on the N.H.S. Scheme, and any attempt to prescribe them in this manner would be questioned by the Health Department. She does use pethidine tablets but these are largely ineffectual and of course she has to pay for these at the rate of $36.00 per hundred tablets. She requires a minimum of six fifty mgm tablets daily which really do not give her effective relief. Apart from this there is the cost to her as a Pensioner. Is it possible to get through you peimission to prescribe pethidine injectable for this woman. For the life of me, I cannot see why pethidine is only allowed for short term use only, when I can prescribe other opiates freely! This is an extraordinary situation. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is denying my constituent and many other constituents the ability to obtain relief from chronic pain. How dare the committee have the gall to tell my constituent and my constituent's doctor that it knows more about appropriate treatment for her than her treating doctor does! Question resolved in the affirmative. We we have and the democracy that we have in this indicate to the honourable member for Banks I will digest them and see what I might consider Main Committee adjourned at 1.01 p.m. NA The following answers to questions were circulated: Murray Darling Freshwater Research (Question No. 2127) Mr Lieberman asked the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 6 March 1995: (1) Is it a fact that funding for the Murray Darling Freshwater Research Centre of $394 000 per annum from the Albury Wodonga Development Corporation will cease on 30 June 1996; and if so why. (2) Will the Government meet the Centre's funding requirements after 30 June 1996; if so how. (3) What action is the government taking to avoid the Centre experiencing a funding crisis.

Speaker: Mr HOWE
Title: REPRESENTATIVES MAIN COMMITTEE
text: The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) The Albury Wodonga Ministerial Council decided on 27 August 1993 to provide the Murray Darling Freshwater Research Centre with funding from the Albury Wodonga Development Corporation (A WDC) until 30 June 1996. However, continued funding beyond this point was considered inappropriate. The reasons for the decision included: the AWDC' s revised operational arrangements made the funding arrangements inappropriate; the level of funding provided was out of scale with the AWDC' s community services responsibilities; under the current diverse funding mechanisms, Parliaments would not have access to a complete picture of the resources devoted to this project. (2) The Centre receives funding through a number of agencies including the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, the CSIRO, the Cooperative Research Centre Program, and the Water Resources Research and Development Organisation. Future funding support for the Centre will be determined by these organisations/programs according to their budgetary circumstances and NA (3) The AWDC advised the Centre in 1993 that Centre AWDC funding would only be provided until 30 June 1996. It is up to the Centre to respond appropriately. Extreme Disablement Adjustment (Question No. 2292) Mr Ferguson asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon. notice, on 9 May 1995: (1) How many persons have qualified for the Extreme Disablement Adjustment (EDA) since it was introduced. (2) How many unsuccessful applicants for EDA received lifestyle ratings of (a) 4 and (b) 5. Mr Sciacca-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Since the Extreme Disablement Adjustment was introduced with effect from 22 December 1988, 7520 veterans have qualified for this rate of disability pension. 3936 of these have since died. (2) Veterans do not have to specifically apply for EDA and there is no special application form. Eligibility for EDA is automatically considered when Disability Pension is being assessed following a new claim for a disability pension or application for increase in pension, and the veteran is: assessed at 100% of the General Rate of disability pension, aged 65 years or over, and does not qualify for the Intermediate Rate or Special Rate of disability pension. To be granted EDA a veteran who meets this initial criteria must also be assessed under the Guide to Assessment of Rates of Veterans' Pensions having a Lifestyle Rating of at least 6 and an impairment rating of at least 70 points. Precise information is not available on veterans considered for EDA. It is known that of those living veterans of all ages assessed at 100% and rated at 70 impairment points since 22 December 1988 some 700 had a lifestyle rating of 4 and some objectives. 500 had a lifestyle rating of 5.
